column2: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 29 (UP) --Sale of the Fisk Rubber Corporation to the United States Rubber Company for $8,000,000 was approved tonight as directors completed counting of stockholders' proxies. The meeting lasted twelve hours.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 29-- Six valuable horses were suffocated and two stable boys who went to their aid were badly burned tonight in a fire at the Bronxville Riding Club.

The consolidated net profit of the Beatrice Creamery Company and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Nov. 30 was $525,741 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to a statement issued yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP)-- The four seeded players--Bobby Riggs, Don McNeill, Elwood Cooke and Bryan (Bitsy) Grant--came through as expected in the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today and gained the semi-final round.

College basketball's "week of champions," during which New York's leading quintets have met the standard-bearers of other sections, will be concluded tonight at Madison Square Garden. The pairings will be Santa Clara vs. City College and Colorado vs. St. John's, with the former game to go on first at 8:15 P.M.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29--The story of a grim battle for "Lebensraum," waged not in modern Europe but in North America 2,000 years ago by a Mongoloid people who invaded Alaska, was told tonight to the American Anthropological Association by Dr. Diamond Jenness, retiring president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture today established sugar-import and marketing quotas for 1940 amounting to 6,725,000 short tons, raw value. This compares with total quotas of 6,755,386 for this year.

All the several hundred branches operated in the United States and foreign countries by Armour Co., Illinois, and its consolidated subsidiaries are being turned over to Armour Co., Delaware, under an operating agreement which will pave the way for an eventual merger of the two companies, it was learned yesterday.

Henry Sears has purchased from the 30 East Seventy-second Street Corporation the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at that address. The building, which occupies a plot 53.9 by 102.2 feet, near Madison Avenue, has suites of four, six and ten rooms.

Two four-story dwellings, known as 65-7 Middleton Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, have been sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee, in an all-cash deal, to Miriam Freyman, who plans to alter the buildings and install a new layout for occupancy by sixteen families.

ISTALBUL, Turkey, Dec. 30 (UP) --Relief efforts in the Anatolian earthquake area, already hampered by floods, blizzards and broken communications, tonight were disrupted by new tremors.

President Roosevelt had a literary job on his hands last week--the writing of the annual message on the state of the Union. Cutting down appointments, pushing less urgent matters aside, he set to work, for the message must go to Congress on Wednesday.

ROME, Dec. 30--Pope Pius spoke of the church in medical terms today in response to the Chilean Ambassador's speech of homage in presenting his credentials.

The Holland America liner Volendam arrived here yesterday from Rotterdam with 678 passengers, including Bhicco Batlivala, Indian nationalist; Julius Priever, exiled German conductor; thirty-five members of the Joos Ballet troupe and 480 German refugees.

NEITHER pedestrian nor driver, the bicycle rider falls into a special highwayhazard group for which new accident-prevention techniques are being set up. Methods devised, for the most part, appeal to the children, who are in the majority among wheel users.

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and subsidiaries for the eleven months to Nov. 30, and released yesterday by Herbert A. Wagner, president, shows a net income of $6,087,349 after all expenses and charges.

The new City Council of twentyone members, holding its first meeting tomorrow at noon, wlll be addressed by Mayor La Guardia and Alfred E. Smith, former Governor. The Mayor will deliver the general statement, required of him once a year by the charter, "on the finances, government and affairs of the city."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30--Academic rulers of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, after sitting on the fence without authority for more than three decades, armed themselves with a club today and, in effect, warned the membership either to behave or suffer the consequence.

The declaration of war against Germany by England and France heads a list of news events considered "most interesting" during 1939 by the American public, ac cording to the results of a survey made public yesterday by the American Instittue of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

County Judge William O'Dwyer, District Attorney-elect of Kings County, yesterday made public the names of thirty-two assistants and one chief clerk he has selected to constitute his staff when he assumes control of his new office tomorrow.
THE antique crosses of Christendom are Madeleine Sweeny Miller's hobby, and she has written a book to tell of her quest of them in many countries.

Judge Irving Lehman took the oath of office as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, the highest judicial office of the State, yesterday afternon at his home, 119 East Seventy-first Street, in the presence of a group of friends and relatives, including his brother, Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30-- Putting the sun itself to work, and employing many of the skills and techniques of the staff engineers, a new swimming pool, second unit in the program of recreational expansion made possible by an alumni fund, is fast taking shape at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The year 1940, in the opinion of Charles F. Noyes, head of the realty company bearing his name, will be a much better year for real estate than 1939. He says very definitely that those who have purchased well-located real estate is New York City at the low level of prices prevailing during the last few years are about to realize the wisdom of their judgment.

BEARING out estimates, holiday trade closed with a rush and last week there was less let-down than usual. Cold weather over wide sections of the country brought a brisk demand for suitable apparel. Automobile sales improved on their recent gains.

ATLANTA, Dec. 30--Only three lynchings, the lowest number since records were begun fifty-eight years ago, occurred in the United States during 1939, it was disclosed today in annual reports of the Commission on Interracial Cooperation in Atlanta and Tuskegee Institute in Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Secretary Perkins urged in her annual report, issued today, that the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations reunite to make effective "the further development of our democratic process of living in the American way."

The Neediest Cases Fund for 1939 on the final Sunday of the appeal for those in the greatest distress known to exist in New York City reached a grand total of $232,448.82 today. The receipt of 128 contributions aggregating $4,209 increased the total for this twenty-eighth annual appeal to that amount.

A Polish historical pageant and ball will be given on Jan. 19 in the ballroom of the Pierre under the auspices of the Helios Foundation, Inc., of which Mme. Bronislava du Brissac is founder and president.

Levy, New York attorney and authority on the trust laws, declared yesterday.

Three United States ships sailed from their North River piers yesterday for Southern, Western and Far Eastern ports, with 288 passengers, mails and cargo.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30--Just before going into recess until Sept. 1, 1940, the Senate today unanimously approved the bill reforming the fundamental principles underlying the Mexican school system that was passed by the Chamber on Wednesday. The measure went through almost without discussion.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP)--The Orange Bowl fever hit this resort city tonight. While the Missouri and Georgia Tech football teams got in their last real practice licks for the New Year's Day game, thousands of their supporters mingled with the regular sun-hunting Winter visitors, who have doubled Miami's normal population.

PHILADELPHIA--With a proposal to install parking meters in central Philadelphia now under consideration, surveys by the Keystone Automobile Club in Pennsylvania cities where meters are in operation show this method favored as a means to regulate parking.

INTERNATIONAL Harvester Company recently opened its eighth branch in the New York metropolitan area. The new building is headquarters for sales and servicing of International trucks on Long Island north of Brooklyn.

The appointment of the Rev. Dr. James Bacon Sullivan as chaplain of the New York University Newman Club, Catholic undergraduate organization, was announced yesterday coincident with the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the club's establishment.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 30 (AP)--Great Britain tonight asked Uruguay to permit the cruiser Ajax to enter Montevideo harbor to repair damages received in her battle with the German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee on Dec. 13.

The year 1939 was a year of blackout, a blackout of the hopes for a peaceful world fostered in the two decades since the Treaty of Versailles. Europe was again at war in a test of strength between rival empires and rival ways of life. Across the affairs of men far removed from the battlegrounds fell the shadow of a conflict that was consuming the old order and shaping that yet to come.

Rabi of Columbia University.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., will offer to the public today $18,594,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1969, of the Consumers Power Company. The bonds will be priced at 105 , to yield 2.97 per cent.

A prediction that 1940 will witness the locating of an increasingly large number of manufacturing tenants in the Chelsea area and that much of the present warehouse space available in the section will be absorbed was voiced yesterday by they Cross Brothers Company, brokers, who announced another lease for quarters in that section.

Receipts amounting to between $4,000 and $5,000 from five holiday performances of "Tobacco Road" were stolen at pistol point yesterday by a bandit who invaded the box office of the Forrest Theatre, 230 West Forty-ninth Street, as the treasurer was preparing the money for deposit in a bank. The bandit, believed to have had an accomplice, escaped.

On Monday the Junior League of New York will open an exhibition of portraits in oil and of etchings by Gerald L. Brockhurst at the League Club House, 221 East Seventy-first Street. A sherry-tea in the afternoon will be held for members and their guests. The exhibition is being given for the benefit of the Junior League Welfare Fund.

The Polish Government, which is now functioning in Angers, France, announced here yesterday through Jannsz Zoltowski, financial counselor of the Embassy of Poland, that it is obliged to give notice that the debt service on all Polish loans must be suspended for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Attorney General Murphy, in correspondence filed in District Court today, accused eight persons and three business houses, all alleged to have Communist party connections, of military espionage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The security zone around North and South America cannot be enforced short of war, declared Senator Robert A. Taft today. Carroll G. Walter was installed yesterday as a Supreme Court justice in the presence of a group of friends and well-wishers who filled the courtroom over which he will preside in the County Court House, Foley Square. He began his career by announcing that he had "long aspired" to his office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--President Roosevelt appointed Alvin J. Wirtz of Austin, Texas, today as Undersecretary of the Department of the Interior. His name will be sent to the Senate for confirmation soon after Congress convenes tomorrow.

Financial opinion felt that Prime Minister Chamberlain's address yesterday made it clear that there can be no boom in equities. Further profit-taking near the close contributed to declines to one-half of 1 per cent. Other sections were slow moving but steady.

TOKYO, Jan. 11--"The proposed increase of 25 per cent in the United States Navy is designed to maintain America's superior ratio over the Japanese Navy even after the lapse of the Washington treaty. Lefkowitz, former Municipal Court justice and former Assemblyman from the Sixth Assembly District, for Representative in Congress to fill-the vacancy caused by the death of Dr. William I. Sirovich, Democrat. The election will be held on Feb. 6.
Mrs. Skinker Matthews gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the Duchesse de Talleyrand.

Cliffdale Farms, a 205-acre property on Teatown Road, Croton, Westchester County, was sold by Nelson B. Garden to a client of Howard L. Auerbach, broker. It includes a nine-room residence, superintendent's cottage, barn and farm buildings and will be improved by the purchaser with a modern home for a Summer residence.

The Herman Motor Truck and Parts Corporation, which in 1936 leased the site at Fourteenth Street and Jersey Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker, has enlarged its plant by purchasing through the same broker the plot 150 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Fourteenth and Coles Streets.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 (AP) --Dr. Henry L. Swain, noted throat and ear surgeon and professor emeritus of otology at Yale Medical School, died today in New Haven Hospital after a brief illness, at the age of 75. He was a past president of the American Laryngological Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission received notice today that Northern railroads were ready for a fight over the South's recent freight-rate victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--A Senate judiciary subcommittee recommended today confirmation of Attorney General Frank Murphy as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, after he had voluntarily appeared before the group.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Jan 11 (UP)--The German steamship Bahia Blanca, which sailed from Rio de Janeiro in an effort to return to Germany, struck an iceberg today and sank sixty miles northwest of the west coast of Iceland.

The name of James J. Hines, former Tammany district leader, figured in a discussion yesterday before the Board of Estimate on the application of the Board of Transportation to award a contract for electrical signal work on the Sixth Avenue Subway to the second lowest bidder.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 (UP)--A war shortage of coal and a severe cold wave hit Berlin simultaneously today, resulting in the death of one person and extreme discomfort for thousands.

Two of the metropolitan stalwarts will square off against highscoring foes in the Madison Square Garden tonight when Long Island University faces the colorful New Mexico Aggies and St. John's meets Temple.

With Billy Conn, light-heavyweight boxing champion of the world, the guest of honor, the Boxing Writers Association of New York held its second annual dinner in the banquet hall of the Ruppert Brewery last night with 236 guests present.

Mayor La Guardia's speech on taxes tackled an important problem and offered an interesting statistical and historical review of it. But the particular remedy that the Mayor proposes is much worse than the disease he is trying to cure.

BERLIN, Jan. 11--Germany's standpoint on the question of Great Britain's confiscation of neutral mail bound for belligerent nations, as expressed today by competent authorities, is that Britain is guilty of a clear violation of international law as laid down both in the eleventh Hague agreement and in the International. Postal Convention.

PARIS, Jan. 11--The French Academy today elected Professor Paul Hazard to the seat left vacant by the death of Georges Goyau, the Academy's perpetual secretary. The author, Andre Bellessort, was chosen to succeed M. Goyau as secretary.

LONDON, Jan. 11--Caution was the keynote in most sections of the stock markets today, although one or two bright spots developed before the close. British funds resumed their upward movement. Speculative holders have taken some of their profits, leaving the position stronger and sounder.

Offering to the public will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Coffin Burr, Inc., of $3,750,000 of Ohio Water Service Company first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1964. The bonds will be priced at 103 and accrued interest.

Seven of the eight seeded players in the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament advanced to the quarter-finals yesterday at the Yale Club. Tomorrow, when play is resumed, the lone absentee from the ranking list will be E.P. Field Jr. of the Princeton Club.

The Jockey Club at its annual meeting yesterday put itself on record as opposed to some of the provisions in the part-mutuel bill now pending in the Legislature at Albany, particularly with regard to ...

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 11-- Legislative action will be sought in Albany this Winter for the creation of a Westchester County Police Department, which would pool the police resources of any of the eighteen towns, twenty-four villages and four cities of the county that cared to share in the department's support, County Executive William F. Bleakley announced here today.

The Italian liner Rex will arrive tonight from Genoa and Naples via Lisbon and Horta in the Azores. Her passengers include General Haller, Polish Minister without portfolio; Dr. and Mrs. Chaim Weizmann; Endre De Toth and eighty-three passengers from Lisbon and Horta unable to complete their ocean crossing by Clipper plane.
SINCE the discords of temperament in Carnegie Hall are not broadcast with the symphonies, listeners may be surprised to learn that orchestral harmony sometimes is only aural.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Amendments to the rules governing the solicitation of proxies, consents and authorizations in respect to securities listed on national exchanges were promulgated today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a substitute, for the time at least, for a proposed general revision of these rules which was drafted some time ago.

In a world of rapidly changing standards, it is imperative that those working with youth appraise carefully the direction and value of that activity, Mrs. Felix M. Warburg declared yesterday afternoon in her annual report as president of the board of directors of the Young Women's Hebrew Association, at the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the organization at its headquarters, 31 West 110th Street.

Preparations for the homeward voyage of more than five hundred members of the crew of the liner Columbus, who have been on Ellis Island for more than three weeks, were being carried out quietly yesterday, with authorities determined to prevent further leakage of the plans.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 11--Raymond R. Born, former undersheriff of Atlantic City, was found guilty on three counts of income tax evasion in the Federal District Court here today.

LONDON, Jan. 11--Great Britain saw the shadow of Germany's threatened mass air attack today when scattered squads of big black Nazi bombers flew over six different military objectives on the east coast from the Firth of Forth in Scotland to London on the Thames.

A net profit of $3,445,110 for the six months ended on Nov. 30, last, was earned by the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries, after deductions for interest, depreciation, estimated income taxes and other charges, according to the report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The text of the statement made today by Secretary Hull before the Committee on Ways and Means was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, disclosed before the House, Naval Affairs Committee today the basic reasons why the Navy Department believes the combatant strength of the navy should be increased immediately by at least 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)-- Mexico has proposed a commercial agreement with the United States, it was learned today. The proposal was made in a letter to Summer Welles, chairman of the InterAmerican Economic Advisory Committee.

Revision of the Board of Education's policy of giving credit for outside professional experience, whereby newly appointed teachers to the New York City school system are to start at substantially lower salary levels, was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 11--An ovation burst from all seats in the Chamber of Deputies and its galleries today when Edouard Herriot, presiding, read a burning condemnation of the German-Soviet alliance and in eloquent terms exalted the valor of Finland.

BARTLEY, W. Va., Friday, Jan. 12 (AP)--A ray of hope that two or three score of the eighty-seven men still entombed in the explosion rocked Bartley No. 1 coal mine May still be alive came early today to the haggard crowd of relatives gathered about the pit.

A bookseller in Kobe, Japan, notifies the John Day offices that Lin Yutang's "Moment in Peking" has been confiscated by the authorities. At the same time the publishers learn that "The Importance of Living," by the same author, has been translated into Japanese--without permission--as the "Rambling Notes of Leisure."
BERLIN, Jan. 11--The transfer of Baltic Germans from Estonia and Latvia into the Greater Reich was to all practical purposes concluded Tuesday, it was announced here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11--A statement laying down broad principles of behavior for the college faculty member and reputedly "defending him as a citizen as never before" was adopted today by the Association of American Colleges, by an overwhelming vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)-- Army engineers recommended to Congress today a $39,274,400 improvement program on the East River between the navy yard in Brooklyn and Throgs Neck, declaring the work would be in the interest of national defense.

A far-reaching decision limiting the right of loan companies to seize household furniture used as collateral by borrowers was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel in Brooklyn.

Acting under a court order signed early this week by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, Gordon Auchincloss, trustee for Porto Rican American Tobacco Company, has requested creditors, stockholders and indenture trustee, as well as the Securities and Exchange Commission, to send to him by Feb. 1, any suggestions they may have for the formulation of a reorganization plan or for a proposed plan.
Two funeral services will be held tomorrow for Jonas Lie, noted Norwegian-born artist and former president of the National Academy of Design, who died on Wednesday at the age of 59.

LONDON, Jan. 11--The Air Ministry indicated today that it had a surprise in store in the development of new fighting planes now underconstruction. It said that the time for the employment of the new type fighters had not arrived but added that "when it does there may be some surprises, especially in the numbers which are likely to be used."
BERLIN, Jan. 11--"It's high time that 40,000,000 people stopped dictating to 80,000,000 people when they should have a cup of coffee!"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--Plans to eliminate European political borders as tariff breastworks blocking the free exchange of manufactured goods and raw materials are under study by President Roosevelt's aides in connection with possible peace moves at some opportune future date.

The row of four five-story tenement houses at 341 to 347 Third Avenue, northeast corner of Twentyfifth Street, has been purchased by Samuel Reznick from a client of Edward J. West, attorney. The houses occupy a plot 98.9 by 105 feet and were acquired subject to a first mortgage of $65,000 for ten years.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that net earnings for 1939 amounted to $6,988,506, exclusive of profit on the sale of bonds, and were equivalent to $2.80 a share. This compared with $7,122,032, or $2.85 a share, in the previous year.

A small garage in Brooklyn that had been in one family for over twenty-five years will be converted into a studio apartment as the result of its sale yesterday by Miss Amy Low Huntington. The property is the two-story brick building at 4 Grace Court Alley and has been sold through the Cruikshank Company, broker.

Heart L. Doherty, wealthy oil man and philanthropist, who died in Philadelphia Dec. 26, bequeathed his entire fortune to the widow, Mrs. Grace Rardin Doherty, in a thirty-one-word clause of his will, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan.--11 (UP)-- Craig Wood, veteran pro from Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Wilford Wehrle, Chicago amateur, today played the soggy course of the Sequoyah Country Club in sub-par 67s in the first round of the $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.
The worst slump of the new year hit security and commodity markets yesterday, and the decline was intensified by increased selling in all lines.
OTTAWA, Jan. 11--Canada's first war loan, to be issued next Monday, will be for $200,000,000 at par and will bear interest at 3 per cent.
B.G. DeSylva and Morrie Ryskind will return on Tuesday from Florida where they have been working on "Louisiana Purchase."
Just before the mid-Twenties the United States had its largest baby crop. Those babies are now of high school age.
Francis Henry Taylor, now director of the Worcester (Mass.) Museum of Art, has been chosen director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will assume his duties here about the middle of May.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11-- Margaret Webster, director of Manhattan's "Family Portrait," conferred today with Paramount executives on a one-picture deal.

Austin H. MacCormick, who has served the city as Correction Commissioner since Jan. 1, 1934, announced after a conference with Mayor La Guardia in City Hall yesterday that he had resigned, effective on Monday, to become executive director of the Osborne Association, Inc., a research organization in the field of crime and penology.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will carry his campaign for the Republican nomination for President into New England during the week beginning Jan. 22, Charles P. Sisson, former assistant attorney general and co-manager of Mr. Dewey's campaign, announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11--Horses owned in New England and the Midwest won the principal races at Hialeah Park today, Napper Tandy, victor in the Jacksonville Purse, also being an eligible for the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup.

BERLIN, Jan. 11--Some 300,000 German workers who daily are exposed in their labors to excessive heat will henceforth fare better than their fellow-toilers, for the Reich's Nutritional Ministry has decreed that each is to receive one liter of Russian tea a day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The $10,000,000 advanced by the United States to Finland shortly after she was attacked by Russia and the $10,000,000 credit to Norway announced yesterday will probably be followed by at least another $10,000,000 for Sweden, to judge from a statement today by Federal Loan Administrator Jesse Jones.

If the Democratic Presidential candidate in the coming campaign should be Mr. Roosevelt or some other candidate committed to the New Deal, the Republicans could present a very powerful case in opposition, particularly if they were resolved to base their campaign on principle.
A three-goal scoring outburst in the final period gave the New York Rangers a 5-to-3 victory over a stubborn Chicago Black Hawk sextet at Madison Square Garden last night.

Fresh fruit and vegetable distributors yesterday went on record approving the idea of Federal legislation which would enable them to reduce handling costs on their merchandise in congested markets, but recommended that any proposal be given careful study by all members of the industry before it is submitted to Congress.

Reports that Mexico's oil exports in December were the least since June, 1938, shortly after the expropriation of the British and American oil properties, indicate that the Mexican Government is continuing to have difficulty in establishing the expropriated properties on a satisfactory basis.
PARIS, Jan. 11--Fuller light has been shed on the meeting in Venice last week of the Italian Foreign Minister, Count Ciano, and the Foreign Minister of Hungary, Count Stephen Csaky.

The failure so far of a large export movement of wheat from North America to Europe to develop as a result of the war, which had been expected at first by most persons, may yet materialize.
ALBANY, Jan. 11--Samuel W. Brown, chairman of the board of Bacon, Stickney Co., coffee and spice merchants, died today at the age of 82.

Teachers College's report on how it wishes to solve the financial and educational problems of its Lincoln and Horace Mann Schools, long awaited by parents, alumni and students, reached special parent committees of both schools late yesterday as a confidential document.
PALM BEACH, Fla, Jan. 11-- Captain and Mrs. John H. Gibbons gave a dinner tonight at their home in honor of Mrs. Frank Crowninshield, who came today from Boca Grande to be their week-end guest.

A new Samuel Goldwyn edition of "Raffles," adapted from E.W. Hornung's adventures of "The Amateur Cracksman," will be the Roxy's new tenant this morning. The cast is headed by David Niven, Olivia de Havilland, Dudley Digges, Dame May Whitty and Douglas Walton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Secretary Hull called on Republicans and Democrats today to make common cause in the face of world conditions on behalf of the nation's best interests as he opened his testimony before the Ways and Means Committee in favor of extension for three years of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
Airlines housed at La Guardia Airport at North Beach, Queens, complained yesterday that repeated efforts to negotiate long-term leases at Newark Airport had been unavailing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11--The Board of Trustees of Princeton University at its Winter meeting in Nassau Hall today formally appointed Julian P. Boyd as librarian of the university, succeeding James Thayer Gerould, who retired in 1938 because of ill health.

More than 2,500 persons, including Mayor La Guardia and a Congressional delegation headed by United States Senator James M. Mead, attended funeral services yesterday morning for Edward W. Curley, Democratic Representative in Congress from the Twenty-second New York District.

LONDON, Jan. 11--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain was attacked as a political bungler today in an article by John Marchbank, Secretary of the National Union of Railwaymen in The Railway Review, the official publication of the organization, on the forced resignation of Leslie Hore-Belisha, War Secretary.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 12 (AP)-- Premier General Nobuyuki Abe was reported today by Domei, Japanese news agency, to have announced his decision to resign at a special Cabinet meeting Sunday morning.

Christopher J. Dunphy, former executive of Paramount Pictures and a former Wall Street man, announced yesterday the formation of a finance company to produce two Class A motion pictures in a New York studio at a total cost of not less than $600,000.
In preparation for a long war Great Britain and France are arranging for the purchase of as many as 12,000 American war planes in the next two years, authoritative sources said last night.

CHESTER., Pa., Jan. 11--The new cargo liner Mormacmail, the tenth vessel in a fourteen-ship replacement program of Moore-McCormack Line, Inc., was launched here today at the yards of the Sun Shipbuilding Company.

The New York premiere of Ernst Bloch's violin concerto, with Joseph Szigeti as the soloist, made the novelty of the concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The other works were Prokofieff's "Classic" symphony and Jean Sibelius's Symphony No. 2.

The gates leading to the detention rooms of Ellis Island were barred early yesterday without warning and a crowd of about one hundred friends and relatives of the crew of the Columbus were refused permission to visit the island, although they held passes issued the day before.

The first of a series of three monthly meetings under the auspices of the Women's Committee of the New York Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews will be held Tuesday, Jan. 23.

The plan of the La Guardia administration to buy the Bronx section of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway was described yesterday by Councilman Charles E. Keegan, Bronx Democrat, as a step in what seemed to be a quiet campaign to establish higher rapid transit fares after unification goes through.

Teachers College's report on the fate of its Lincoln and Horace Mann Schools, the contents still undivulged except to special parent committees of both schools, drew opposition last evening from the Horace Mann parent group, which had gone on record this week as willing to accept "a gradual" merger of the schools.

The Coffee Dances at the Cosmopolitan Club, a series of subscription entertainments which had their inception here some years ago, were continued last night with the second of the series for this season. As usual many of the subscribers gave dinners before the dance.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12--A belief that no general Federal subsidization of higher education could remain divorced very long from "bureaucratic regulation" was voiced before several hundred colIege presidents and deans today by J.W. Lowes, financial vice president of Harvard University, in an address at the meeting of the Association of American Colleges.

The annual financial report of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company released yesterday by James A. Gray, president, disclosed net earnings of $23,645,455 for 1939, after provision for depreciation, taxes and all other charges.

Producers and stars of the stage formulated schemes for the benefit of the Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., on a scale surpassing anything ever tried before in the amusement field at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Algonquin. A minimum goal of $500,000 was set by Helen Hayes, chairman of the amusement committee of the fund.

HAVANA, Jan. 12--A three-day air carnival opened this afternoon at Camp Columbia military air field under the auspices of the National Sports Commission. A crowd of 8,000 saw stunting exhibitions, racing and parachute jumping.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12--Six candidates for the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup race, led by Memory Book, formerly a color-bearer for Mrs. Payne Whitney, are entered in the Fort Dallas Park Handicap, mile-and-an-eighth feature which will headline the Hialeah Park program tomorrow.

Federal Judge William Bondy drove a hard bargain yesterday, by which the government gained $2,000 besides ridding itself of the necessity of feeding and otherwise sustaining a prisoner in jail for three months. In a spirited exchange with counsel for the man, Judge Bondy arranged everything so that it cost the prospective prisoner $500 for changing his mind.
Dr. John Colin vaughan, surgeon and Arctic explorer, died at the New York Hospital early yesterday at the age of 69.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--Two great ocean liners different from any ever before designed or built, which, in the event of war, could be rapidly converted into naval aircraft carriers, are on the program of the Maritime Commission for construction in the near future, it was learned today.

BARTLEY, W. Va., Jan. 12-- Hope was abandoned tonight for the entombed men in the blastswept Bartley No. 1 mine and company officials put the death toll at ninety-two, the worst mine disaster in the country since 1928.

Even though the New York City school system has made economies of $6,000,000 since September, the Board of Education will still face a "substantial deficit" when the Spring term opens Feb. 1, James Marshall, president of the board, announced yesterday.

TORONTO, Jan. 12 (Canadian Press)--J.J. Seitz, president of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Manufacturing Company, Ltd., subsidiary of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company of New York, died today at his home after a brief illness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--The Department of Commerce today published new amendments to existing export restriction orders under which Great Britain will prohibit the export except under license of a number of manufactured goods and raw materials.

HELSINKI, Jan. 12--Taisto Maki and Paavo Nurmi, famous Finnish runners, will leave for the United States in a few days to participate in sport exhibitions for the benefit of Finland, it was announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP)--Sir Francis Goodenough, former gas company executive, died here today. His age was 67.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 12--One man was dead, three were safe and two missing after a head-on air collision of two navy torpedo planes over barren Borego Canyon, seventy-five miles east of here, naval district officials reported tonight.

Tomorrow morning will find about eighty fishing cruisers pushing through Palm Beach Inlet for the opening day of the annual Silver Sailfish Derby sponsored by the West Palm Beach Fishing Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--Myron C. Taylor, recently named the President's representative to the Vatican, conferred with Mr. Roosevelt at a luncheon meeting at the White House today which was attended by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State.
BERLIN, Jan. 12--Difficult problems have entered into the feeding of the surviving population in bombarded Warsaw, it is reported here today.

Miss Dorothy Clarry of 57 West Fifty-eighth Street stepped forward in Homicide Court yesterday and volunteered to pay a fine levied against a 33-year-old Negro named Moe Crawford who had killed Miss Clarry's father.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 12 (UP)--The purpose of the InterAmerican Neutrality Committee, which opens its sessions here on Monday, is to keep the European war as far as possible from the shores of the Americas, Dr. Charles G. Fenwick, United States delegate, said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12--Congress was urged today by Major Evans Carlson, a former Marine Corps officer, to confer upon President Roosevelt the power to declare an optional embargo against Japan.

Ralph Hitz, president of the Hotel New Yorker and of the National Hotel Management Co., Inc., died last night at Post Graduate Hospital, after a heart attack. He entered the hospital Dec. 10 suffering from a liver ailment. His age was 48.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12--Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, declared today that "there is no doubt on the whole that football has been a major handicap to education in the United States."

The State of Minnesota will enter the market on Jan. 30 with $3,500,000 of rural credit certificates of indebtedness, for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent. The certificates, dated Feb. 1, 1940, are to mature on Feb. 1, 1949 and 1950.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP)--New York State's Court of Appeals refused today to hear reargument of its recent decision that the Village of Peekskill's new city charter was ineffective.

Wholesale markets were generally more cheerful this week as buyers arrived for Spring purchasing with budgets substantially above those of a year before, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--An emergency defense bill carrying more than $264,000,000 for additional expenditures for the armed forces of the United States was passed by the House today after cursory debate.

A private residence in the Navy Yard district of Brooklyn which had been held in one ownership since 1870 passed yesterday to a new owner who plans to convert the building into a four-family flat.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 12-- Frank A. Hagarty, Mayor of Hartford, 1916-1918, eight years the city's postmaster and at his death assistant vice president and trust officer of the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company, died last night of a coronary thrombosis at his home in Windsor. He was 69 years old.

VENICE, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP)--Harry Norton Marvin, inventor and president of the Biograph Company in the early days of the motion picture industry, died today at his Winter home near Sarasota, at the age of 77. He was an associate of the late Thomas A. Edison.
Just recently a poll of baseball writers produced an all-star set of big leaguers that included only two representatives from the National League. There were American Leaguers all over the roster.

Tentative slates of organization candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention from New York County have been agreed upon at a series of conferences County Chairman Kenneth F. Simpson has held with various Assembly district leaders, it became known yesterday.

The Frigidaire Division of the General Motors Sales Corporation will increase its advertising expenditures for 1940 by using more media and greater space in each medium, it was reported here yesterday at the company's sales meeting at the Hotel Astor.

Following a conference with Mayor La Guardia in City Hall yesterday, Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen of Brooklyn said that a "satisfactory agreement" had been reached in the matter of appropriating funds to continue his inquiry into official corruption for the next six months.

Members of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, picketed the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, even though the hotel has a closed shop agreement with the A.F. of L. Hotel Trades Council.

Retail trade here continued active this week, with shoppers responding well to both clearance and initial Spring promotions. Department store executives estimated sales were running about 7 to 8 per cent over the corresponding week last year.

Frederick Coykendall, president of the Cornell Steamboat Company and executive of numerous other corporations, has been re-elected for an eighth term as chairman of Columbia. University's board of trustees, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, ...

That children today are under the influence of realism rather than surrealism is indicated in the interesting children's exhibition of watercolors and paintings from art teaching classes of the New York City Art Projeet, sponsored by the WPA at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12--Senator McCarran of Nevada, author of the law which created the Civil Aeronautics Authority, told persons attending the banquet which closed the annual meeting of the National Aeronautic Association tonight that he could see no reason why this country could not paraphrase the British slogan "Britannia Rules the Waves," to "America Rules the Air."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12--Funeral services were held here today for Dr. Henry McElderry Knower, nationally known anatomist and for twenty-one years managing editor of The American Journal of Anatomy, who died Wednesday in a Baltimore hospital at the age of 71. Burial will be at Woods Hole, Mass., where he made his Summer home.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's boom for the Presidential nomination received great but possibly only temporary impetus yesterday by an agreement to support his candidacy by rival party factions in New Jersey headed by former Governor ...

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 12 (UP)-- King Haakon, opening the Storting [Parliament] today, pledged every effort to maintain Norway's neutrality, but added that the country's armed forces would be increased as a precaution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--Overthe protests of Charles Fahy, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, and Representative Abe Murdock, Democrat, of Utah, the House committee investigating the Labor Board received for the record today an affidavit by Harry. A. Elder former bodyguard ...

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP)--Boston's indoor track season will get off to a spectacular start tomorrow night with a star-studded entry list ready to compete in the first renewal of the Veterans of Foreign Wars games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)--William L. Batt, Philadelphia manufacturer, today was elected chairman of the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council, succeeding W. Averell Harriman, railroad executive.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP)-- Nine candidates were named today to run in the $10,000 added San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita Park tomorrow.

The convictions of four defendants in the $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud were reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division and the indictments against them ordered dismissed on the ground that their prosecutions were barred by the statute of limitations.

ROME, Jan. 12 (UP)--Generalissimo Francisco Franco, head of the Spanish State, has offered in a memorandum to Pope Pius XII to collaborate in any move to restore peace to Europe and put an end to the danger of Communist expansion, it was said authoritatively today.

An unusual opportunity was afforded music lovers when the young pianist, Creighton Allen, had the initiative to play all four of Edward MacDowell's Sonatas, the "Tragic," "Eroica," "Norse" and "Keltic," for the program of his recital last night in Town Hall.

The New Mexico Aggies, famed for color and scoring skill a year ago, did not even have color last night as Long Island University bowled over the three-time champions of the Border Conference without raising a bead of perspiration.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 13--Senior statesmen, whose duty it is to select the next Premier, are busily engaged but with little success so far. Prince Fumimaro Konoye is being pressed from all sides to resume the Premiership, but does not conceal his unwillingness, and unless some very special influence is brought to bear it is improbable that he will accept.

Fordham's improving basketball team gave its best performance of the season before 2,000 spectators in the Rose Hill gymnasium last night and registered an impressive 4--3 victory over Syracuse. It was the Maroon's third straight triumph.

LONDON, Jan. 12--After an opening burst of activity in the stock market today, gilt-edge securities failed to maintain their best prices, but gains, on the balance, indicated that the market continued firm, and it is generally considered as almost ready for emission of the contemplated war loan.

BERLIN, Jan. 12--In primitive, horse-drawn wagons, piled high with all their goods, and in milelong railroad trains, 130,000 Ger mans who elected to return to the Reich from Eastern Polish territories, now under Russian rule, have been crossing the RussianGerman demarcation line.

LONDON, Jan. 12--The British Admiralty announced today that three British ships were sent to the bottom of the North Sea by mines or bombs in the last forty-eight hours, and that three others were attacked by low-flying Nazi planes along the east coast. [Another mine victim was reported by The United Press.]

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--Opposition to reapportionment of the House of Representatives, following the 1940 census, has grown so strong that President Roosevelt, to counter it, has written to Representative Matthew Dunn of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Census Committee, urging him to put through legislation.

Public utility borrowing accounted for the bulk of new bond financing this week, aggregating $33,750,000 out of the total new offerings of $38,500,000. This compared with a total of $22,494,000 in new bonds placed on the market last week and with only $1,773,000 offered during this week last year.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 12--Heads of all municipal departments of this city received written orders today from City Manager Raymond J. Whitney to end at once the improper financial practices which were enumerated yesterday in a report on Yonkers affairs by the Division of Municipal Accounts of the State Department of Audit and Control.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday its program of free lectures at the main building and the Cloisters, beginning in February and continuing through May.

JUDGING by the freedom of expression enjoyed by the contemporary novel and theatre, it seemed reasonable to believe, until a few days ago, that American letters were not greatly handicapped by the censor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 --It is believed here that in an atmosphere of strict secrecy Prince Paul, the Regent of Yugoslavia, and King Carol of Rumania met today near the little town of Vrsec, a hamlet near the frontier of the two countries that is famous for its wines and good shooting. The occasion for the meeting was supposed to be a shooting party.

Miss Anne Morgan, sister of J.P. Morgan and head of the American Friends of France, arrived last night on the Italian liner Rex to continue her work of organizing aid for 1,500,000 French noncombatants affected by the war.

ALBANY, Jan. 12--Formation of 1,404 new stock corporations in December sent the total number organized in 1939 to 16,113, an increase of 484 over 1938, when 15,649 were formed, according to a report by Michael F. Walsh, Secretary of State, made public today.
Mr. Stimson's proposal for an American embargo on the shipment of war supplies to Japan has brought a large number of letters to THE TIMES. Some of them are printed elsewhere on this page.

America's yacht builders and their patrons will go into the home stretch of the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace today.
PARIS, Jan. 12--Both material aid and volunteers are passing through France, going to the aid of Finland.

An investigation by Magistrate Matthew J. Troy failed to disclose a "scintilla of evidence" to support a Brooklyn relief recipient's charge that her relief had been cut because she refused to join the Workers Alliance or carry on organizing work for the Communist party, the magistrate announced yesterday in Bay Ridge Court.

True to its policy of building up a repertoire of "the greatest ballets of all times," the Ballet Theatre at the Center Theatre last night turned its attention to that masterpiece of the romantic period, "Giselle."

Stocks returned yesterday to early December levels under a barrage of selling which cut off as much as 3 points in the industrial section, while trading on the Stock Exchange expanded beyond the million-share mark.

Edward Huntingdon Fallows, an attorney, former member of the New York State Assembly, and the first transfer tax attorney appointed for New York City, died yesterday at the Hotel Le Marquis, 12 East Thirty-first Street, after an illness of several months. Mr. Fallows, who was 74 years old, lived in Norfolk, Conn., and maintained offices at 80 Broad Street.

The City College swimming team gained its fourth victory in as many starts by defeating New York University last night, 40--35, in the Beavers' pool. It was the opening meet of the season for the Violet.

There was rejoicing in Detroit and Flint as the 25,000,000th General Motors car rolled off the assembly line. A.G. Spalding Brothers, Inc., closed their fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1939, with a net profit of $22,411 before Federal income tax and extraordinary charges.

Requesting the restoration of virtually all services eliminated from the New York City school system last year, the Board of Education's finance committee yesterday submitted a tentative budget estimate of $158,095,698 for the fiscal year 1940-41.

Owen Taylor, inventor of a system of charting price trends, will be guest speaker today at the weekly economic discussion meeting of customers' representatives of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Alexander Eisemann Co. Customers of the firm have been invited to attend.

Cotton prices declined sharply last week in active trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange oldtype future contracts, calling for deliveries in the present season, declined 17 to 24 points, while new contracts, calling for deliveries next season, lost 36 to 38 points.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14--The Rangers, invincible since last November, lost to the inspired Black Hawks, 2 to 1, before 15,884 spectators tonight. The result not only snapped the New Yorkers' streak of nineteen games without a defeat but dropped ...
WITH THE FRENCH FLEET, Jan, 14--In a statement issued to the press yesterday, Navy Minister Cesar Campinchi gave out the bare statements of what the French Fleet has done since the war began.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Since the war broke out last September the people of Britain have been living in the style to which they were accustomed. Now, the government has decided that the time has come to tell the people that this cannot continue and a major offensive against inflation--the skulking enemy which already has made some headway in this country--has begun.

In one of the most thrilling amateur hockey contests at Madison Square Garden this season the New York Rovers battled the McIntyre Miners of Northwest Ontario to a 3-all tie in the star battle of a twin bill yesterday.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 14--The Marquess of Linlithgow, Viceroy of India, left Bombay tonight for Baroda after a week's stay. Although his visit was primarily private, Lord Linlithgow saw many political leaders and the feeling is growing that these meetings will assist toward a settlement of the current disagreement over Indian support for the British Government in the war.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 (UP)--Business, entering the new year with industrial production about 30 per cent higher than the average for the first half of 1939, can look forward confidently "to at least a pretty good" first quarter, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said tonight in his monthly business review.

Fire Lieutenant Thomas C. Norton, 48 years old, of Hook and Ladder Company 10, was injured seriously and five others, including two high ranking members of the department, were hurt yesterday afternoon while fighting a fire that started at 229 West Street, in the produce market district, and spread to an adjoining building at 99 North Moore Street.

A national appeal for additional contributions for the Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., was made last night over a nationwide hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System by former President Herbert Hoover, chairman of the fund. In Brooklyn 3,000 persons braved the rain to attend an overflow mass meeting of the Scandinavian Christian United Action.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 14-- The villa of United States Minister H.F. Arthur Schoenfeld, twelve miles north of Helsinki, was bombed by Soviet raiders today during a continuation of the large-scale Russian offensive in the air, which has been in progress since the hazy weather cleared.
ROME, Jan. 13--This week's market reflected a satisfactory trend despite the short-lived reactions caused by a temporary calling-in of orders of a speculative nature.

Twenty-five hundred A.F. of L. coal drivers demanded yesterday that fuel dealers in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens sign a new labor contract within fortyeight hours or face a strike that would paralyze coal and coke deliveries to homes, hospitals, office buildings and industrial plants.
James J. Lyons's passionate loyalty to the Bronx, where he is Borough President, sometimes leads him into flights of humor and fantasy.
The ninth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning Monday, Jan. 22, will feature the first performance of Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung," ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Major Gen. Julian L. Schley, Chief of Army Engineers, reported to Congress today that $401,444,660 could be profitably expended in the fiscal year 1941 for flood control and improvement of rivers and harbors.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14--Lessons learned during the World War in 1914-18 are regarded as having an important bearing on the buying of grains and other commodities by the Allies, and developments ...
OTTAWA, Jan. 14--Acceptance of subscriptions to the first Canadian war loan, to be opened at 9 A.M. tomorrow, will be definitely limited to the total of $200,000,000 asked for.

A 411-page digest of records in the official files of Staten Island was completed yesterday by WPA archivists. Intended to aid research workers, public officials, historians, lawyers and writers, the volume traces the history of the island from the days when Raritan Indians called it Egquahous and paid their bills with oyster and clam shells.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan 14-- Colonel Arthur Farragut Townsend, chairman of the board of directors of Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., and manager of its Passaic plant, died here today of a heart ailment at his home, 298 Greenway Road. He was 74 years old.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 14-- Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College, given by Mrs. Edward S. Harkness as an expression of her belief in the importance of religion to college students, was consecrated here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Backed by the knowledge that President Roosevelt is on their side and that the government's financial position favors their argument, economy advocates expressed the belief tonight that for the first time in years they have a good chance to "sell" their colleagues on the idea of adhering to, if not actually cutting, the Bureau of the Budget figures for the 1941 fiscal year.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP)--The loss of the British steamer Atlantic Scout, 4,575 tons, was reported late tonight. Two other ships were reported today to have been sunk from war or other causes and another damaged.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 14--Racing over soft North Shrewsbury ice in southeast rain squalls that almost blinded the skippers at times, Donald Asay, with Borden Hance tending sheet, today sailed his Teal II to a 12-second triumph over Addison J. Howland's Murad, skippered by Steve Olnas.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., Jan. 14--One of the country's most distinguished skiers despite his youth, 19-year-old Bobby Clark, won the open slalom race held under tricky conditions today atop Cannon Mountain. The University of New Hampshire star, running unattached, negotiated the difficult course in the splendid time of ...

LONDON, Jan. 14--The war of nerves rather than guns broke out afresh tonight when on the heels of reports of Belgian and Netherland military preparations and of renewed vigilance on the Belgian and Netherland frontiers the British War Office announced that all British Expeditionary Force furloughs had been suspended temporarily.
Wilbur Evans, Philadelphia baritone, was heard in his first New York recital yesterday afternoon.
The average Englishman probably won't know what to make of Admiral Stark, our Chief of Naval Operations ...

Dr. Walter Clark Montgomery, war-time division surgeon of the Twenty seventh Division, A.E.F., who received many decorations for his services in action, died yesterday after an illness of two years. Dr. Montgomery, whose home was at 214 West Ninety second Street, was 61 years old.

The public statements given out, usually at meetings of their shareholders, by eminent bankers and industrialists reflect quite unanimous rejection of the idea (not long ago ventilated in Congress) of Business clamoring for war because of the profits to be derived from it.

Net asset value of the American International Corporation at the close of 1939 was $18,356,963, or 189 per cent of the principal amount of debentures outstanding and equivalent to $8.66 a share for the common stock, it reported yesterday. The year before the asset value was $11.21 a common share.

Investment bonds, as well as the more speculative issues, lost ground yesterday in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Foreign dollar loans particularly those of neutral countries, were the weakest features as that market reflected the increasing nervousness

The question of governmental action versus free enterprise was termed "a false and mythical issue" by David E. Lilienthal, a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, in an address at the Columbia Graduate Economics Club at Columbia University last night.

BERLIN, Jan. 15--Those Germans who in the future want to take a daily bath will have to use cold water or not take a bath at all. For a decree has just been published allowing apartment house owners to limit the supply of hot water to two days weekly, Friday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--High officials, diplomats of many countries and Washingtonians joined today in paying tribute to Mme. Marguerite Namara, soprano of the Chicago Opera and Opera Comique, and Robert Casadesus, French pianist, at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musical morning in the Mayflower Hotel.

The Brooklyn Daily Eagle was purchased yesterday by the F.D.S. Corporation for $483,000, it was announced by Wilmot L. Morehouse, Federal referee in bankruptcy. The assets were bought for $350,000, the remainder being for debts and other liabilities.

The decline of 1 per cent in the steel rate to 84.8 per cent this week scarcely betokens any important slackening in the active rate of operations in the steel industry. Some commentators, noting the slower rate of incoming orders now, compared...

Seventeen men, most of whom appeared more frightened than revolutionary, were held in $50,000 bail each by Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz yesterday on charges of conspiring to overthrow the United States Government.

The story of being starved for nine days in a French concentration camp because he would not "talk" was described yesterday by Joseph Wagner of Lomita, Cal., a German citizen and a technician for the M.W. Kellogg Company of New York.

Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, told 1,000 bankers dining last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel that this country should strive to have on hand actual munitions reserves and equipment to put 1,000,000 on a war basis in an emergency.
WASHINGTON, Jan.15--The Senate Judiciary Committee approved unanimously today the nomination of Attorney General Frank Murphy to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court.

Two attorneys and two alleged runners pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday as they were about to go on trial with nineteen others on charges of ambulance chasing. Previously they had pleaded not guilty.

LONDON, Jan. 15--Britain canceled leaves today for all men of the Royal Air Force in France, but despite persistent rumors of an imminent German attack on the Netherlands and Belgium, there is a tendency here to believe that they are only another manoeuvre in Germany's war of nerves.

BERLIN, Jan. 15--Official German contempt at what is termed the turncoat policy of the Marquess of Lothian, British Ambassador to Washington, was expressed tonight in an edition of the DiplomatischPolitische-Korrespondenz, which is used to present the most authoritative views of the Wilhelmstrasse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--The socalled budget, which is not a budget at all but a series of detailed executive requests to Congress for money, is a large book of about 150 printed pages.

WITH THE FINNISH ARMY, on the Russian Border, via Rovaniemi, Jan. 15--The debris of the battlefield along the Suomussalmi-Raate Road is being cleared up. It is a long and tedious job. Only the toughest-stomached Finnish soldiers were in the squad that came up to clear the battlefield after the smoke and noise had died away.

Henry Armstrong sparred for the first time yesterday in preparation at the Roxy Gymnasium for the defense of his world welterweight title against Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican, in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 24.

MALONE, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP)-- Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant deferred today the requested appointment of trustees for the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its chief subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, pending a hearing on jurisdiction.

Marking the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding and the sixtieth anniversary of the arrival in this city of its first commissioned officer, the Salvation Army of New York authorized yesterday a financial appeal in its behalf for a minimum of $375,000 to help carry on its services in New York City during 1940. Henry W. Taft, chairman

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15--A demonstration by Washington University students protesting the resignation of Jim Conzelman as head football coach disrupted classes on the campus today and resulted in the announcement by Conzelman that he would reconsider.

Lively debate over whether the City Council should continue its weekly broadcasts over WNYC is expected to dominate the first business meeting of the newly elected body which starts in City Hall at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

Because they don't have to work a pump handle at the well or tote buckets from the spring, city people take it for granted that water circulates as freely and inexhaustibly as the air they breathe. Of course, it doesn't.

St. John's visits the Fordham gymnasium tomorrow night for the sixteenth game in their series, and if the form charts hold true--the betting gentry has taken an unmerciful beating this season--than the Redmen will square the standings at eight victories apiece.

PARIS, Jan. 15--The French Foreign Office warned tonight of possible simultaneous action by Germany and Russia against neutral nations in Western and Eastern Europe and promised the "formidable support" of Great Britain and France to any neutral attacked by the Germans.

A new exhibition has been installed in Gallery D 6 at the Metropolitan Museum. It is called "Heads in Sculpture" and will open with a private showing this afternoon--to the public tomorrow. The work is to remain on view through March 3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Two government departments recommended jointly today that Congress require the return of railroad land grants if it should relieve the carriers of the necessity of furnishing transportation to the government at reduced cost.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--George Q. Lynch, president of the Pattern Makers League of North America (A.F.L.), commenting today on Daniel J. HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 15-- Russian bombing planes swarmed upon Southern Finland from their Estonian bases today, and for the fourth consecutive day carried out what Finnish officials alleged to be a methodical wave of terror against women and children, hospitals and workers' districts.

The earnings report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, parent concern of the Bell System, released yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president, shows a net income for 1939, after all expenses and charges and with results for December partly estimated, of $172,446,000.

PARIS, Jan. 15--Immediate application is being given to the commercial treaty signed last week by France and Spain and in a manner enormously beneficial to both countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--President Roosevelt plans to send a special communication to Congress tomorrow suggesting further financial aid by this government to Finland.

Baseball men speculated yesterday over the possibility that Commissioner Landis's sweeping decision against the farm club operations of the Tigers would increase the Yankees' domination of the American League, The United Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--A Japanese fishing vessel, the Daichs Saiho Maru, was wrecked today on the southeast coast of Guam. The waters where the craft came to grief were in the restricted area fixed by the Navy. The reason for the presence of the vessel in waters closed for ships of all nations except the United States was not explained.

ATLANTA, Jan. 15--In memory of the late Dr. Charles H. Herty, distinguished New York and Georgia scientist, the campaign to found the Herty Forest Institute in Georgia received impetus today as State leaders and organizations joined in a "Doctor Herty Week" observance.

With December advertising equalling the figure for the like 1938 month, total newspaper linage in the fifty-two cities measured by Media Records, registered an increase of 1.5 per cent in 1939, according to figures released yesterday. This compares with a loss of about 13 per cent in 1938.

BERLIN, Jan. 15--Side by side with the reconstruction of damaged homesteads, farms, villages and towns in conquered Poland, Germany is making preliminary surveys for a network of double-lane motor highways linking her new eastern provinces with the web of concrete roads spun throughout the Reich.
The first increase in bread prices here since the European war began went into effect yesterday, when several large baking concerns announced increases of 1 cent a loaf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--House leaders arranged today for consideration next Friday of a resolution to extend for one year the life of the Dies committee investigating un-American activities, with indicestions that $100,000 in expenses would be alloted for the inqury.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP)-- Major Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the army air corps, predicted today in an interview that warring European nations soon would be using bombers with an operating radius "greatly exceeding 1,000 miles."

BERLIN, Jan. 15--The fresh alarm in Belgium and the Netherlands regarding the possibility of a German invasion is treated in Berlin with guarded reticence. Semiofficially this is attributed to a German desire not to dramatize the present nitration and to avoid everything that might lead to an extension of the war's front.
F. Trubee Davison was re-elected president of the American Museum of Natural History at the seventyfirst annual meeting of the board of trustees last night.

BAINBRIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP) --A farmhand whom State police described as "slightly demented" was sought tonight as an aftermath of the finding of the bodies of his employer, employer's wife and their daughter in their burned farmhouse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--President Roosevelt does not choose to seek a third term, according to the current issue of David Lawrence's United States News, and will tell the nation so either on Jan. 20 or March 4, but probably on the earlier date.

ALBANY, Jan. 15--Senator William London, Westchester Republican, introduced a bill in the Upper House tonight allotting to cities or counties operating horse race tracks within their borders a 2 per cent share of the proposed 10 per cent "take" from pari-mutuel betting.

George Blumenthal, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, told of the pressing need for additional funds for the museum to carry on its work at the annual meeting of the fellows of the corporation of the Museum yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)--The House approved today and sent to the Senate two bills authorizing the shift of a statue of Chief Justice John Marshall across Capitol Park to make way for one of George Washington.
PALM BEACH, Fla.; Jan. 15--Mr. and Mrs. Luis Martinez de las Rivas gave a luncheon today at their villa for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Kountze Douglas.

The New York A.C. defeated the Columbia U.C., 5 to 0, on the loser's courts in a Metropolitan League Class B match of the National Squash Tennis Association yesterday. This gave the Winged Foot combination, leader of the loop, a mark of eight triumphs in nine engagements.

Germany scoffs at a new "fear epidemic" in the Low Countries and charges that reports of German troop concentrations opposite Belgium and Holland are "nonsense."

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--The Federal Grand Jury today returned forty-one indictments in the government's investigation of the Chicago building industry. Named on charges of conspiracy to establish restraint of trade in the tile business in violation of the Sherman Anti-trust laws were...

Mrs. Margaret Reinen, 41 years old, mother of five children, of 88-01 236th Street, Queens Village, Queens, was attacked brutally in the kitchen of her home about 1 P.M. yesterday by a man who posed as an electric light company meter reader.

ROME, Jan. 15--The Pope, for the first time in his reign, received today the homage of the Knights of Malta--the Sovereign Sacred Military Order of St. John of Jerusalem, to give them their proper name. In his address to them he told his own little parable, a modern version of the story of the Good Samaritan.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 15--Opening the first session of the Inter-American Neutrality Committee here today, President Getulio Yargas of Brazil declared that the Americas had as much right to proclaim a peace zone as European nations had to proclaim a war zone.
Postmaster General James A. Farley became a "brain truster in reverse" yesterday morning when he went to Columbia University to lecture to thirty students of a college class in American politics.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 15--Captain Wyjker of the Arendskerk, 7,906-ton Netherland motor ship which was torpedoed in the Bay of Biscay today, informed his ship owners, the HollandAfrica Line, at The Hague tonight that his ship had been torpedoed after having been stopped and searched by a German submarine.
A1 Reid, Bronx lightweight, gained the decision over Mickey Farber, East Side battler, in the feature bout of eight rounds before 2,500 at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Golf's prospects for the next twelve months appear to be bright enough, if looked at from the standpoint of the United States alone.

The Ballet Theatre, prodigal with its new works, added two more to its repertoire at the Center Theatre last night. These were Antony Tudor's "Jardin aux Lilas," which had its first production in London four "years ago, and Jose Fernandez's setting of Granados's "Goyescas," which received its world premiere on this occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Edward J. Noble, Under-Secretary of Commerce, who described himself as a Republican business man from Connecticut, endorsed the Administration's reciprocal trade agreements program as being of "incalculable value" to United States industry, agriculture, labor and the nation as a whole in testifying today before the Ways and Means Committee.

The State of California awarded yesterday to Kaiser Co. of San Francisco an issue of $2,000,000 of unemployment relief registered warrants at 3 per cent, plus a premium of $2,170. The warrants, dated Jan. 18, will mature on or about Nov. 27.
A new plea for repeal of the city's one-cent cigarette tax was sent to ithe City Council yesterday by the New York Tobacco Council, representing dealers throughout the city.
RENO, Nev., Jan. 15--Mrs. Helen Strong St. Cyr filed suit for divorce here today against Jean H.E. St. Cyr, charging cruelty. They were married in New Orleans on April 26, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--President Roosevelt forwarded to Congress today a request of the Tennessee Valley Authority for additional power to develop into a vast recreational area parts of the six Southern States embraced in the TVA project. It was the first time that the agency had dwelt at length on the recreational aspects of the undertaking.

MONTREAL, Jan. 15--As befits league leaders, players of the New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins are monopolizing top positions in the National Hockey League scoring race. Of the first seven scorers all except two are members of these teams.

There are sleepy, rural corners in New York City seldom visited by urban folk and unknown to those who live beyond the city's borders. In these dreamy spots men still trudge behind the primitive plow, spend the brief Winter nights reading by kerosene lamps, warmed by stoves almost 100 years old.

BOSTON, Jan. 15--United States Attorney Edmund J. Brandon and special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been working since October on an extensive investigation in Boston of the activities of underground groups aiming at sabotage and a dictatorial form of government, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)--Senator Barbour, New Jersey Republican, sought today a congressional inquiry into the controversy over the use of the Newark and New York City municipal airports.

LONDON, Jan. 15--The Cornhill Magazine, founded in 1859 by William Makepeace Thackeray over illimitable cups of coffee in a noble old house in Waterloo Place, has suspended publication "until paper gets cheaper aid the world gets saner."

The two four-story walk-up apartment houses at 99-15 Thirty-fourth Avenue and 33-54 Ninety-ninth Street, Corona, L.I., were sold by the Kings County Trust Company to a client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers in the deal.
Another major building change is in prospect for the old Murray Hill neighborhood, some parts of which still retain the quiet residential air of a generation ago.

JERICHO, L.I., Jan. 15--George Mallory Pynchon Jr., amateur aviator and son of George M. Pynchon, Wall Street broker, was found dead early this evening in the stables of his home on Brookville Road here. Dr. Abraham Frereich, Deputy County Medical Examiner, said that Pynchon had killed himself by discharging a shotgun into his mouth.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--Organized baseball, jittery from a $500,000 penalty bombshell tossed by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis, tonight pondered a warning that banishment from the game faced officials for future violations of rules against "cover up" methods.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 16--In plain but polite and friendly language, the British Government rejected today the proposal contained in the Declaration of Panama, in which the twenty-one American republics undertook to establish a neutrality belt extending an average of 300 miles from the coasts.

Miss Catherine McNelis, who once was rated among the ten most successful business women in the nation, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison yesterday by Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston. Similar sentences were imposed on her brother, John McNelis, and Joseph E. Flynn.

With new clouds hovering over the European war scene, stock prices were depressed yesterday as much as 3 points, but a last-minute rally due to short-covering permitted many pivotal issues to recoup a large part of the decline.

Continuing its excellent play, the Central Badminton Club blanked the Downtown A.C., 5 to 0, during the week-end Class A competition in the Metropolitan Badminton Association tournament. The triumph was the fourth for Central, which is unbeaten in the series.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UP)--A new complication was injected into Detroit's police shake-up tonight by testimony of two detectives who disappeared coincidently with $1,000 loot from a hold-up.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 15-- The first Class B women's invitation squash racquets tournament of the Bronxville Field Club drew a small but select field of twentythree players today. Two rounds were completed.

Woods, president of the Lincoln Parent-Teacher Association, said many Lincoln parents wanted legal and fiscal separation of their school from the college, and not a merger.

The right of a large corporation to file proceedings under chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy laws instead of under chapter 10, which would bring the Securities and Exchange Commission into the case, was upheld in a majority ruling of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 15-- Against a background of medieval splendor, the Most Rev. John F. O'Hara, C.S.C., was consecrated titular Bishop of Milasa and Auxi liary Bishop of the Army and Navy Diocese in ceremonies this morning at the University of Notre Dame.

ALBANY, Jan. 15--Complete agreement on a State budget was announced tonight by Governor Lehman, after the last of a series of conferences with the legislative leaders of both parties.
