ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 17--Bubbling Boy, ridden by Nick Wall, captured the feature race at Santa Anita today. The winner, timed in 1:37 2-5 for the mile, led Journey On under the wire. Count Atlas ran third. Bubbling Boy rewarded backers with $15.60 to win, $5.20 to place and $3.40 to show.

The four-story private dwelling at 124 East Seventieth Street, with a frontage of 20 feet, has been sold by the estate of Frieda Wimpfheimer to a client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., who will demolish the building and replace it with a residence for his own occupancy.

The ten most important non-fiction books of 1939, selected by the literary advisory board of the magazine Current History, were announced by the Book Sellers League of New York last night in the Hotel Brevoort, Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street, at a dinner attended by 150 booksellers, authors and publishers.

Giuseppe Sturani, veteran conductor who since the season of 1928-29 served the Metropolitan Opera Association as musical secretary, died yesterday morning of a heart attack in his suite at the Hotel Ansonia, Seventy-third Street and Broadway. He was 64 years old.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 17.--With Jim Bennett scoring 24 points, Cornell defeated Columbia in their first Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League meeting tonight, 40--33.
Shoe production in 1939 was 7.4 per cent ahead of the previous year and set a new annual record of 419,500,000 pairs, according to an estimate issued yesterday by the Tanners Council of America.

For the second successive session of the Cotton Exchange the lowest prices of the day were made at the opening under Bombay straddle liquidation, with a later recovery of nearly all the early loss.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 17 (AP) --John Cudahy, new United States Ambassador to Belgium, delivered a message from President Roosevelt to King Leopold today as Belgium continued her precautions against possible invasion.

In a thrilling battle the St. Nicholas Hockey Club came from behind in the final period to gain a 6-6 tie with Clarkson Tech at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. There was no overtime session by agreement. The New York A.C. squad routed the Crescents, 7 to 1, in a preliminary New York Amateur Hockey Association game.

Reversing a long-established trend, the New York City high school enrollment, for the first time in its history, has started to shrink, Eugene A. Nifenecker, director of the Board of Education's research bureau, disclosed yesterday.

Mr. Stochek's violin shop is small. It is crowded with 'cellos. Eight 'cellos rested against the shop walls and on the floor and a ninth was cradled on the work bench. One more 'cello and Mr. Stochek would be out on the landing.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 17--"Fat Stuff" went the way of all pork flesh this afternoon in the yard of the School Street elementary school --into ham, bacon, pigs' knuckles and pork chops. Between 300 and 400 pupils saw "Fat Stuff" die for science.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17 (AP)-- Governor Lehman declared tonight that "the future of our entire agriculture" may hinge on the solution of the problem of voluntary regulation of milk production.
West and East Sides shared the bulk of the new apartment tenancies reported yesterday by brokers and agents.

James Pess, 35 years old, better known as Jimmy Mont, interior decorator, was found guilty last night in General Sessions after trial on an indictment charging him with attacking Miss Dorothy Burns, a lamp shade designer, on May 4.
R.E. Freer of the Federal Trade Commission, urged the retailers of the United States in session here yesterday not to discount the consumer movements.

Fifty-seven more members of the crew of the scuttled German liner Columbus started for home yester day. Being elderly men, women and boys and therefore not subject to military seizure, they took the more conventional route to Germany and sailed on the Italian liner Rex.

Plans to construct a $35,000,000 fully integrated steel plant with American funds in Brazil were reported yesterday to have reached a stage where formal agreements are all that is required to carry the proposal into the building stage.

Some sections of the bond market regained a certain degree of stability yesterday in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The league-leading New York Athletic Club squash tennis players, headed by national champion Harry F. Wolf, cut another notch in their racquet handles last night, giving them an unmarred record in the Metropolitan League Class A race.

The United States Pipe and Foundry Company showed a net profit of $2,570,279 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the preliminary statement for the year 1939, submitted yesterday.

A new low for the Winter was reached yesterday when the temperature dropped to 11.5 degrees at 3 A. M. Weather Bureau reports indicated that the cold wave would continue with sight snow and a possible minimum of 10 degrees this morning.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (AP)--Greater regularization of employment is business management's "number one job," and the reactions of men out of work one of its major dangers, William L. Batt, president of S. WASHINGTON, Friday, Jan. 19-- Senator Borah, dean of the Senate and its best known orator, lay near death early today at his home here, with all hope for recovery abandoned by his physicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--A resolution endorsing President Roosevelt for a third term will be introduced by Senator Joseph F. Guffey at the meeting of the Pennsylvania Democratic State Committee in Harrisburg Feb. 3. The Senator, in making the announcement today, predicted adoption of the resolution.

TOKYO, Jan. 18--Aggressive intentions which, if carried out, would enable the American fleet to cross the Pacific and fight the Japanese fleet near Japanese waters were discerned by the newspaper Asahi in the naval plans now being discussed in Washington.
Major and Mrs. Charles T. Griffith have arrived from their home in Germantown, Philadelphia, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Carbon monoxide fumes took the life of one man and overcame twenty-four others who tried to rescue him yesterday afternoon from the pit of a gas-filled coal silo, a hundred feet above the ground, in the yards of the Riverside Fuel Company at 144th and Exterior Streets, on the Bronx side of the Harlem River.

Otto Prignitz, 55 years old, a man of pronounced military carriage who spoke highly of Fritz Kuhn, the German-American Bund leader now in Sing Sing, was in an extremely nervous state yesterday when he appeared in the Felony Court as a complainant in a robbery case.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 18--Captain Wijkar of the Netherland motorship Arendskerk, which was torpedoed by a German submarine, said in Lisbon, Portugal, today that his ship had been destroyed on the ground that she was carrying goods to a country at war with Germany. This report throws new light on German methods of sea warfare.

Raymond Guest, who has served as head of the United Hunts Racing Association for the past two years, was re-elected president at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday. Retained in office with him were John Hay Whitney, vice president, and Lewis E. Waring, secretary and treasurer.

ALBANY, Jan. 18--Governor Lehman will act as tutor tomorrow, for the eighth consecutive year, at the budget school conducted for the benefit of the newspaper editorial writers and correspondents. The school is split into two classes, with the editorial writers arriving at the Executive Mansion for lunch and the reporters for the second session late in the afternoon.

A flexible tariff law, administered by a non-partisan non-political agency with power to adjust rates solely on the basis of domestic economic considerations, was advocated by William L. Munro, president of the American Tariff League, at its fifty-fifth annual meeting in the Union League Club yesterday.

An internationally known Chinese importing and exporting firm has leased space in the midtown district, where it will open its first New York branch office. The Federal Administration should allow commodity prices to rise moderately, Russell C. Leffingwell of J.P. Morgan Co. said in a statement presented to the Temporary National Economic Committee in Washington and made public there yesterday. He recommended also against changing the price of gold again. He appeared before the committee last month and later wrote a supplementary statement.

HELSINKI, Jan. 18--Money from the Finnish Relief Fund in the United States, of which former President Herbert Hoover is national chairman is proving a godsend to wartime refugees on these desperately cold days. A total of $600,000 from the fund already has reached Finland.

With a blunt warning to coal dealers and drivers that "the city cannot shiver while you quibble," Mayor La Guardia acted yesterday to end the tie-up of coal deliveries by summoning representatives of both sides to a conference to be held at 10:30 A. M. today at City Hall.

Vote-counting is Louisiana has always been slow, and sometimes crooked, work. But the accumulating results from the primary on Tuesday make it clear that for the first time in twelve years the Democratic machine built by Huey Long has had a setback. Huey's brother, the Governor, has missed a majority.

Six International Class racing yachts from the Long Island Sound fleet were practically assured yesterday of being sent to Bermuda for the annual match competition there which will be held in April. The craft will be shipped at the end of March, and the racing of approximately a week, with four out of seven contests to count, will start early in April on a date to be arranged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The House Naval Affairs Committee announced today that it would reduce by about $500,000,000 the $1,300,000,000 originally authorized in the 1939 naval expansion bill as drafted and approved by the Administration.

The figures of the Federal Reserve System coming to hand yesterday covering the week ended on Wednseday showed the excess reserves of member banks of the entire system up $120,000,000 on the week to $5,500,000,000. This is the highest since the week ended on Oct. 25 when the record of $5,530,000,000 was established.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18--A goal by Mac Colville less than three minutes from the end of the game gave the New York Rangers a 1-0 victory tonight over the Montreal Canadiens and sent the Manhattan contingent into a first-place tie in the National Hockey League standing with the idle Boston Bruins.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, in their midwinter board sessions here today, heard a world peace formula and considered consumer relations with business.

An increase of $123,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds in the week ended on Wednesday was revealed yesterday in the combined statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City. This is one of the largest weekly increases on record for the local institutions.

Frank A. Erickson, the bookmaker whom Mayor La Guardia threatened to deport from the city, was sentenced to serve thirty days in the workhouse yesterday by the justices of the Court of Special Sessions in Queens for second-degree perjury.
Red sat up on the lop-sided mattress in Room 36 in the Terminal Hotel. His eyes were tight with hangover. He pulled his underwear into shape and blinked tentatively at the morning light.

A nation-wide effort to elect delegates to the Democratic National Convention who will be for the nomination of Vice President John N. Garner for President, was announced here yesterday by Maury Hughes of Dallas, co-director of the Garner campaign.

With Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, staring coldly at him from a front seat, Nicholas Dozenberg, former Red Army secret agent, testified for the government yesterday at Browder's trial in Federal Court on the charge of using a United States passport obtained by making a false statement.

More than 150 former football players and officials attended the annual dinner of the Touchdown Club of New York last night at the Roosevelt Hotel. The chief order of business was the Touchdown Club award, made each year to the man selected for having made an outstanding contribution of permanent value to football.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 18--In its third start of the ice yacht racing season on the North Shrewsbury River, the Class A Pirate, owned by George Ruppert and George Gillig of New York and handled by Oscar and Frank Brand, today gained its first victory, winning a cup presented by Vice Commodore Harold S. Allen of the North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18 (AP)--Dr. George C. Butte of Texas, former Acting Governor of Puerto Rico, died late today at the American Hospital after an emergency operation for an intestinal obstruction. He was 62 years old.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18--Heirs of J. Louis Comiskey today began a fight to prevent sale of the White Sox, as demanded by the First National Bank of Chicago, executor of Comiskey's estate.
Scattered sales of residential parcels featured the Brooklyn realty activity reported by brokers yesterday.

The accumulations of British and Canadian holdings in United States Steel Corporation common stock over a period of two years were disposed of in the six months ended on Dec. 31, mainly in the period since the outbreak of war in Europe, a survey of the corporation's quarterly report indicates.

John W. Wainwright, proprietor of Wainwright and Smith's Restaurant on the ocean front at Rockaway Beach, Queens, and a leader in the hotel business and civic affairs of the Rockaways for fifty years, died yesterday at his Winter home at the Hotel Palace in Brooklyn after an illness of two years. He was 74 years old.

Billy Conn agreed yesterday to risk his world light-heavyweight championship against Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., at Miami, Fla., during the week of Feb. 26. Speculation in commodity futures assists in protecting necessary commercial commitments and acts as a cushion to absorb the shock of surplus marketing, W.H. Jasspon, president of the Memphis Chamber of Commerce, declared in an address last night before the Commodity Club of New York at a dinner meeting in the Park Central Hotel. Mr. Jasspon's address was entitled "The Economic Function of Speculation."

For the first time since 1937 Harry F. Wolf, national champion, went down to defeat in a squash tennis match last night as he bowed to his 21-year-old New York A.C. clubmate, Frank Iannicelli, in the final of the Clyde Martin Memorial tournament at the Yale Club courts.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 18--The engineer of a Lackawanna Railroad commuter express train, which crashed into the rear of another express on the same track here last night, "failed to observe and act upon" signals indicating there was a rain ahead, it was stated this evening by officials of the railroad in a tentative report.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 18-- The American Clipper, transatlantic plane, arrived from the United States this afternoon and was preparing to continue her flight to the Azores when she was held up for the censoring of European mail.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP)--Viscountess Astor, American-born member of Parliament, suggested today in the House of Commons that supplies to brewers be rationed in view of a shortage of barley for animal feeding.

With virtually a blanket representation from the leading high and prep schools of the metropolitan sector, more than 1,600 athletes from seventy-one schools will compete in the forty-second De La Salle Institute indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory tonight. The entry is the largest in the history of the meet.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 18 --The Brazilian Government's plan to require foreign banks to incorporate in Brazil received a jolt today.

Tenders will be considered on Feb. 8 by officials of Erie County, N.Y., in which is situated the city of Buffalo, for an issue of $6,300,000 of home-relief bonds, for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated Feb. 15, 1940, will mature serially on Feb. 15, 1941 to 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Two bills by Senator Hatch designed to extend the scope of the law prohibiting political activity by Federal employes below the rank of policy making officials were referred today by the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to a special subcommittee for study.

Frank M. Mayfield, head of Scruggs-Vandervoort-Barney, Inc., St. Louis, was elected president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday by the board of directors of the association. Mr. Mayfield succeeds Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Company, who served two terms as head of the retail organization.

Orme Wilson, Baroness Maria Reitzes Marienwert, Mrs. Henry Pierce, Mrs. Newbold Morris, Charles E. F. McCann, Colonel Henry T. Blair, Henry T. Dumbell and Muk de Jari.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 18-- Mrs. W. Woods Plankinton gave a dinner tonight at Casa del Ensuenos for her house guests, Mrs. Dee Bredin of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Dr. Ralph Gauze of New York. Tables were on the lakefront patio.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (AP)--Soviet Russia apologized to Sweden and Norway today for violations of their territory by Red Army planes. In response to protests by the two Scandinavian countries, the Soviet Government acknowledged that its planes "accidentally" flew over their borders, but made no mention of a Swedish charge that Russian planes bombed Kalla Island in the Gulf of Bothnia last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The four-year term of Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, will expire Feb. 1 and the expectation is that he will continue on the board in an interim capacity without reappointment, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18(AP)--The first threat of Democratic opposition to the Administration's reciprocal trade agreement program in the House Ways and Means Committee arose today with an assertion by Representative Disney of Oklahoma that he could not support extension of the policy unless an amendment was adopted "freezing" excise taxes.

New hope for the blind of all ages and creeds in the form of treatment and recreation, training and employment, was promised yesterday when the New York Association for the Blind announced that it would appeal this Spring for $566,356 as the first step in a five-year program to raise $1,583,952 for the expansion of its service to those who live in darkness.

THOSE esteemed military gents of the New York State Athletic Commission, General John J. Phelan, Colonel D. Walker Wear and ExPrivate Bill Brown, are in another jam. That's merely a seasonal announcement like: "Snow today and gone tomorrow."

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--A severe cold wave which embraces most of the Winter wheat and rye producing areas in the Northern Hemisphere brought in heavy professional and commission-house buying of wheat futures today. Kendall K. Mussey, director of the Arden Galleries and long active in music and dramatic schools and productions, died yesterday of a heart attack as he was leaving the art galleries at 460 Park Avenue to keep an appointment.

A series of robberies at the Hotel Plaza appeared solved this morning as the police announced the discovery of a cache of jewelry, linen and clothing, valued up to $100,000, in the apartment of a maid employed at the hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 18 (UP)--The refugee Polish Government in France is collecting extensive reports on developments in conquered Polish territory, where refugees charge that German and Soviet authorities have enforced campaigns of "pillage and maltreatment" of the people.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18--The difficulties not only of commenting upon, under present restrictions, but also of guaging, the exact position of the mercury in the barometer of Soviet-German relations from day to day are well illustrated by the references to Germany in yesterday's and today's Soviet press and broadcasts, which many diplomatic circles are discussing today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Mrs. Roosevelt received at tea in the Red Room of the White House this afternoon Mrs. Roy Fleming of Hot Springs, Ark., "Mrs. Typical Customer of 1940," who came East as the guest of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and participant in its twenty-ninth annual convention this week in New York.

The need for creative work in an era of destruction was discussed yesterday at a symposium on "The Arts and America," held in conjunction with a luncheon at the Hotel Astor given by the trustees of the Town Hall, Inc., in honor of Mlle. Eve Curie, daughter of the late Mme. Marie Curie. More than 1,500 persons were present.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 20 (UP)-- The Foreign Office spokesman said today that Japanese-American commercial relations after Jan. 26 would depend entirely upon the attitude of the Government of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--President Roosevelt today condemned as false economy approval by the House yesterday of the elimination of funds for three government agencies, the National Resources Board, the Office of Government Reports and the Council of Personnel Administration.
Leading deals in the Bronx yesterday consisted of sales of apartment houses and of a vacant plot upon which the purchaser plans to erect a six-story multi-family building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--American transatlantic airplanes may omit Bermuda as a calling point if Great Britain persists in censoring the mail they carry, according to an intimation by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--William E. Borah, dean of the Senate and member from Idaho for almost thirty-three years, died at his home here tonight after an illness which began with a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday morning. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--In the face of reports that his income tax returns were being investigated by the Federal Government, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator and aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that he welcomed any such investigation.

Fourteen important stake events to be run at Belmont Park, nine of them at the coming Spring meeting, will have their closing Feb. 15 under a new arrangement announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association.

EVEN though bookshelves are crowded today with personal histories, the reader is justified in asking these memoirs to move over and make room for one more when its author presents as credentials the fact that she was her father's fifty-first child.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 19-- Miss Jessie Simpson, who refused to permit a crippling accident to cripple her life, was married tonight to the young man who had courted her before she lost both legs under the wheels of a railroad train and gave her daily encouragement during the long months of her recuperation and readjustment.
Tomorrow will be observed as Church Unity Sunday, it being the Sunday within the annual Church Unity Octave which will close Thursday, the Feast of the Conversion of St. Paul the Apostle.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 19-- Swedish voluntary aviators are now taking an active part in the Finnish-Soviet war. Current promotion of toothbrushes at reduced prices will be intensified in March, when the Pro-phy-lac-tic Brush Company, Florence, Mass., inaugurates an advertising campaign on its new "bonded" toothbrush.

Kennedy of Brooklyn declared yesterday that the evidence against the seventeen men arrested as Christian Front members plotting the overthrow of the United States Government and held in $50,000 bail each on that charge would be presented to a grand jury next Wednesday or Thursday.

Henry Armstrong, who is to risk his world welterweight title Wednesday night in Madison Square Garden against Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican, yesterday passed a medical examination ordered by the State Athletic Commission.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses may have the end in sight at last. For yesterday, in his report on the accomplishments of an unusually fertile period, he mentioned "the end of 1941" as a time when there will be few neglected sections of the city without adequate playrounds, when the intricate parkway ...

Women players from the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club continued to set a fast pace in the Class A division of the Metropolitan Badminton Association tournament, defeating Central, 5 to 0, to register their fifth triumph in as many starts in the series.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address broadcast from the White House tonight for the White Hoicse Conference on Children in a Democracy:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Pope's reply to President Roosevelt's Christmas peace appeal was delivered to the White House today by the Apostolic Delegate in person.
LONDON, Jan. 19--A lone German Heinkel bomber, flying high in a mist near Aberdeen, Scotland, was driven off by a Royal Air Force fighter after a brief machinegun battle today.

The New York City offices of the American Auxiliary Committee of the Union des Femmes de France, a group of French women closely allied with the French Red Cross and engaged in relief work for French war victims, will be opened Wednesday at 56 East Sixty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Sales of reporting members of the National Retail Furniture Association in December showed an increase nationally of 10 per cent over 1938 and of 29 per cent over November, 1939, while the increase for the year as a whole was 9 per cent.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 20--Expressions of respect for Senator Borah's sincerity, but of disagreement with his opinions on European affairs marked comment in the British press today on the Senator's death.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19 --Russia and Germany are reported to have agreed on delimitation of their frontier in conquered Poland and Nazi troops are said to be moving into the valuable Drohobycz oil district in Southwestern Poland.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 19--Last night, in a blizzard-like snowstorm in a sub-zero temperature, 2,500 people packed the municipal theatre to hear an orchestral concert conducted by Willem Mengelberg.
A large garage and several residential properties in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn were among the realty parcels in that borough reported yesterday to have changed hands.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 (UP)--A decree issued today by the Governor of Warsaw imposing heavy penalties for profiteering on foodstuffs draws additional attention to difficulties the German authorities are having in providing food for the population of the former Polish capital.

Young Alan Hillman, Bayside High ace, who is wasting no time earning for himself the position of No. 1 schoolboy miler in the city, added another important triumph to his record last night when he ran away from the field in the onemile open run at the forty-second De La Salle Institute indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Columbia's swimming team, undefeated this season, scored its fifth victory yesterday, conquering Cornell, 46--29, in the Morningside Heights pool. Continuing to turn in faster times as the season progresses, the Lion mermen triumphed in every individual event.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--After conferring today with Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, and officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan expressed the belief that a compromice proposal for United States financial aid to Finland would be presented to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee at its meeting next Wednesday.
The uncertainty of direction that has characterized the movement of stock values during the week still held yesterday, as the share market was pretty much of a standoff affair.

PARIS, Jan. 19--In response to queries on reports that volunteers and material have been sent to Finland from France, the Quai d'Orsay spokesman declined today to give figures, but said that the volunteers were "many" and the material "important."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--A situation illustrative of the problems of Federal power officials in providing ample electrical facilities for national defense in areas served by debt-ridden utility companies was presented today in a case decided by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19--Dr. Walter Mendelson, physician and former alumni trustee of Columbia University, who retired twenty years ago after a career of more than forty years, died last night in his home in Germantown after an illness of three months. He was born in Germantown eighty-two years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Favorites tumbled, par took a beating and spectators were numbed by chill winds today as golfers battled through two rounds of the $5,000 San Francisco open match play tournament.
The National Ski Association officially announced yesterday that it would aid in the drive for the Finnish Relief Fund. From Roger Langley, president of the N.S.A., came this message:

RIGA, Latvia, Jan. 19--Information has reached this correspondent about the immediate intentions of Soviet Russia.

PARIS, Jan. 19--By a unanimous vote and with only four of its members abstaining, the Senate this evening passed the bill which was adopted by the Chamber of Deputies on Tuesday invalidating all Communist Senators and Deputies who had not by Oct. 26 last categorically repudiated their adhesion to the French Section of the International Communist party.

Paintings from the estate of Clendenin J. Ryan, son of the late Thomas F. Ryan, added $152,000 last night to the proceeds of his art collection, which is being dispersed at the Parka-Bernet Galleries, Inc. With the final session to be held this afternoon, the total now is $338,110.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 19-- Edward Everett Hughes, retired steel executive and husband of Mrs. Mina M. Edison Hughes, widow of Thomas A. Edison, died this afternoon at Glenmont, the Edison home in Llewellyn Park here, after an illness of six months. His age was 77.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 (UP)--Propapanda Minister Joseph Goebbels, speaking tonight at a mass meeting in the former Polish city of Posen [Poznan], said that a German peasantry would arise in the seized Polish territories "which will keep watch to the East."

Leases with a number of notables in The Murray, apartment hotel at 66 Park Avenue, figured in the recent rental acttivity there which has filled the building to capacity, according to Louis Carreau, Inc., managing agent.
An exhibition of sculpture by the great nineteenth century French anamalier, Antoine Louis Barye, opens today at the Metropolitan Museum.
Swedish volunteer fliers helped the Finns harry retreating Russian forces in the Salla sector yesterday as Soviet bombers again struck.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Word of Senator Borah's death spread quickly in the national capital and brought tributes from President Roosevelt, Cabinet officers and members of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Approbation of the work of the Dies committee was voted this morning by directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at their midwinter meeting here. Under the rules for such sessions, only emergency resolutions may be passed and the measure was submitted in that status by Mrs. Harry W. Smith of Durham N.H., chairman of resolutions.

IN walked Major R. Ernest Dupuy of the United States Military Academy. He was wrapped in greatcoat and muffler. Being of the artillery branch of the service, he began firing as soon as he had unlimbered.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 19--A secretly built warship--a combination raider, supply and prison ship--was reported tonight to have been the auxiliary vessel that accompanied the Nazi raider Admiral Graf Spee over three oceans and carried 300 prisoners under conditions that British captives said recalled the "days of slave traders."

Following almost complete disorganization in the market for the securities of the Standard Gas and Electric Company yesterday morning, the Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation into dealings in the securities of the utility, it was disclosed yesterday.
The tribute paid Ernest Peixotto by artists and city officials at the dinner in his honor became a paean of praise for what he has done for his art and especially through it for his city.

Glenn Cunningham, a past master of pace, will give handicaps up to forty yards in the mile special, feature of the annual Grover Cleveland-Osceola Club handicap track meet at the Seventh Regiment Armory tonight, and is expected to get them all back before the race is over.
The thermometer dropped in the city this morning below yesterday's low of 12 degrees and there were indications that the decline would continue, as predicted by the Weather Bureau.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19--Renewal of the struggle between church and State in Mexico is seen as a possibility as a result of the opposition to the recently approved fundamental law regulating the educa tion of youth expressed by the Mexican episcopacy in a circular of instructions ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Supply contracts having a total value of $11,478,235 were awarded during the week ended Jan. 13 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department reported today.

With increases granted to those deemed deserving, a pay slash decreed for only one and the rest asked to accept the terms they received last season, the Yankees yesterday mailed 1940 contracts to thirty-one players on their roster.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 19--A fullpage advertisement published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday not only brout immediate reaction through the medium of telegrams and air-mail letters reecived today, but caused Mayor Chancey of this city to pay a splendid tribute to the "pull" of TIMES advertising.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 20 (UP)--The new Chinese Government to be formed by former Premier Wang Ching-wei in Nanking will follow a foreign policy parallel to that of the Japanese Government, Mr. Wang told Domei, the Japanese news agency, last night.

The Federal Government, through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has become a factor in the city's rapid transit unification program, it was disclosed yesterday, when Jesse H. Jones, head of the lending agency, revealed its readiness to advance at least $2,000,000 to the B.M.T. to help that company carry out its agreement to sell its properties to the city for $175,000,000.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 19--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio raised a question tonight whether President Roosevelt has accepted the view of the country that the United States must stay out of war, except a war of defense.

The hundred and thirty-third anniversary of the birth of Robert E. Lee, commander of the armies of the Confederacy, was celebrated last night at the Hotel Plaza. Nearly 1,000 persons, many of them deseendants of famous Southern families, joined in the ceremonies,

Pittsburgh, Pa., will be in the market on Feb. 6 with $2,398,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1940, at a to mature on Feb. 1, 1941 to 1960.

Supporters of Carmine De Sapio from the First Assembly District, West, last night transformed a routine meeting of the Democratic County Committee at Tammany Hall into one of great disorder, at which resolutions fixing delegate representation at the national convention and membership on the State Committee were adopted with few at the meeting able to hear what the resolutions were about.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19--The first big test of the Florida racing season, the Hialeah Stakes, exclusively for 3-year-olds and primarily a tryout for the $20,000 Flamingo, will be run at Hialeah Park tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 19--The sudden revival of the feud between Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King so soon after a sort of concordat seemed to have been reached has created a profound stir in political circles in Ottawa.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19--J. Bertram Lippincott, chairman of the board of directors of the J.B. Lippincott Company, who had been active in the book publishing field for sixty-four years, died today at his home, 1,712 Spruce Street. He was 82 years old.

Leading from shortly after the start, Franklin School's basketball team scored another victory in the Northern division of the M.A.A. P.S. by defeating Fieldston, 26 to 18, at the Heckscher Gymnasium yesterday, and strengthened its hold on the league lead.

A virtual collapse in the market for Standard Gas and Electric issues on the Curb Exchange featured trading in bonds yesterday.

The itinerary of a trip to the Pacific Coast by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, was announced yesterday at the Dewey campaign headquarters, 100 East Forty-second Street. Mr. Dewey will make one formal speech at a Lincoln Day meeting at Portland, Ore., under the auspices of the Multnomah County Republican Committee.

Warning that New York City's school costs had skyrocketed high enough, taxpayers and real estate groups attending yesterday's first open hearing on the 1940-41 Board of Education budget demanded a drastic reduction in the educational expenditures of the city.

Sharp declines in cotton quotations in both the Liverpool and Bombay markets brought yesterday a resumption of active straddle liquidation on the Cotton Exchange here. Although the list rallied at one time, closing figures showed losses of 4 to 11 points.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 19-- Michigan tonight scored a cleancut swimming victory over Yale in the Payne Whitney Pool, 46-29, leading from the first event and having a ten-point advantage when the final race, the 400-yard relay, was reached.
BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 19 (UP)--The death of Senator Borah touched deeply the Idaho people he represented, not so much because they had lost a statesman but because they had been deprived of a friend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--In the first six months of the current fiscal year the Federal Government collected $224,527,913 less from internal taxes than in the same period a year earlier, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 19-- Within the next few days every man, woman and child in Finland will be insured against death, injury or property damage caused in the war with Soviet Russia.

New bond financing this week aggregated, only $22,246,000, the smallest volume of new offerings for any week since the period ended Nov. 24, last year, when only $20,069,250 in new bonds were marketed.

PARIS, Jan. 19--Germany's publication of another White Paper has stimulated sales of the French Yellow Book on pre-war diplomatic relations. To date 235,000 copies of the Yellow Book have been issued. The demand, which had fallen to 5,000 a day, has now increased to 13,000 a day.
A Yorkville taxpayer was among East Side properties that passed to new control in deals announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Leaders of the travel industry of the United States and Canada, meeting here today at the invitation of Secretary Ickes to lay plans for implementing President Roosevelt's proclamation of last week declaring 1940 to be "Travel America Year," unanimously pledged their efforts to make the program a success.

Thirty-five hundred pupils from seventy-five public, private and parochial schools saw and heard Verdi's "Aida" yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House at the second of the season's junior performances of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Margaret Long, a maid in the Hotel Plaza, admitted in the police line-up yesterday that in the past two year's she had looted more than 100 hotel rooms of jewelry, clothing and perfume valued by the police at $100,000, but denied that she had profited from the thefts.
The coal deadlock remained unbroken last night despite a demand from Mayor La Guardia that deliveries be resumed pending agreement on the terms of a new contract between dealers and drivers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19--Republicans of Pennsylvania looked forward today to a harmonious primary campaign as Jay Cooke, Philadelphia Republican chairman, announced his candidacy for the party's Senatorial nomination and his only announced rival, John W. Kephart, former Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, retired from the running.

A Polish pageant and ball were given last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre under the auspices of the Helios Foundation, Inc. Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador; Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, William Jay Schieffelin, Robert J. Caldwell and George Gordon Battle were honorary chairmen of the event, net proceeds from which will be divided between the Polish "Save a Child Fund" and the Helios Foundation's music scholarships for talented children.

ALBANY, Jan. 19--The results achieved in treating dementia praecox patients with insulin continue to be encouraging, the State Department of Mental Hygiene noted today in its annual report to the Legislature.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 20 (UP)--It was reported without confirmation in Peiping that a Japanese warship on Jan. 4 shelled Siulam, Kwangtung Province, damaging the American United Brethren Mission Hospital.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 19--Rated as the outstanding contestant in the field by all five judges, 11-year-old Miss Dorothy Goos of the Rye Figure Skating Club today won the women's novice title as the third annual Eastern amateur figure skating championships opened at the Playland Ice Casino.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Clair Wilcox, Professor of Economics at Swarthmore College, told the Monopoly Committee today that cartel arrangements similar to those in Europe existed widely in the United States, through trade associations.

With the statement that he aims to secure "as much money as I can by all possible devices," former President Herbert Hoover made an appeal to the colleges for the Finnish Relief Fund yesterday when he spoke to representatives of some fifty-five universities at the annual convention of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics at the Hotel Biltmore.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 19--General J.B.M. HAVANA, Cuba, Jan. 20--The opposition parties last night issued a manifesto reiterating their demand that the Constituent Assembly provide the island with a new Constitution before the general elections.

DETROIT--Production remained firm in automotive plants here last week with the total down only a few thousand units from the previous week. The decline, registered largely by General Motors, was due probably to normal fluctuations in schedules rather than a downward trend.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 20--Professor Auguste Piccard and Max Cosyns of Brussels, Belgium, are coming to Buenos Aires to cooperate with Argentina's preparations for the first stratosphere flight in the Southern Hemisphere, it was announced today by the committee that is preparing for the flight.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 20 (AP)--Governor Earl K. Long called the Louisiana Legislature into special session today and presented twenty legislative proposals for enactment within six days, asking the speed to permit early renewal of his campaign for re-election. WASHINGTON, Sunday, Jan. 21 (AP)--Major Gen. Omar Bundy, who retired in 1925 after a brilliant army career extending from the Indian campaigns to the World War, died early today at his home here. He was 78 years old. He had been ill since he suffered a paralytic stroke two years ago.

Slowly rising temperatures to break the wave of abnormal cold that has claimed 361 lives throughout the United States and caused damage mounting into the millions to Southern crops were predicted last night. BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 27 --A journey from Budapest to Bucharest suggests as well as anything the effect of war in this socalled neutral zone. There are no sleeping cars and the train coaches are overcrowded.

Increasing perplexity mixed with growing irritability seemed to mark the attitude of local baseball men yesterday as they mulled over the latest blast from Commissioner K. M. Landis--a 3,000-word letter from his Chicago office Friday that recommended virtually the abolition of chain-store baseball.
THERE comes a night when the wind lulls away, the temperature slips down toward zero and out of the sky drifts Winter's frozen breath. Dawn arrives to a whitened countryside. The snow has come.

Declaring the country is "nearly in chaos today in regard to the youth situation," Henry I. Harriman of Boston, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, urged that the Federal Government take aggressive action in developing work programs for young people who cannot find private employment.

NEW YORKERS, known for their addiction to jay-walking and their fondness for peering into building exca vations, have recently been demonstrating that they are, in still another way, mostly small-town folk at heart.

Barnard College has opened new fields of study for its social science students by using New York City as a research laboratory for investigating cellar clubs, relief work and radio, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 27--Organized labor in extremis--politically--is the picture presented tothe nation this week as a result of several incidents, the most notable of which was John L. Lewis's public break with President Roosevelt and the New Deal at the convention of the United Mine Workers of America.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27-- Mrs. Gretchen Wilson Hearst, former wife of John Randolph Hearst, was married here today at noon to Woolworth Donahue, son of Mrs. James P. Donahue and the late Mr. Donahue and grandson of the late Frank W. Woolworth, founder of the 5-and-10-cent store chain, and the late Mrs. Woolworth.

WALTER BAGEHOT, who was born in 1826, was prescribed reading for college students in Eng lish a few decades back. One could do much worse for oneself than to read this contemporary in criticism of Arnold and Walter Pater, for he avoids both the pontifical attitude of Arnold and the stylization of Pater, and is nearer the American mind than either.

A photographic display of garden and horticultural subjects will be staged from Feb. 1 to 10 at the offices of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue. General views, close-ups and photographs of members' gardens will be ...

W. Burke Harmon of the Harmon Organization sees a distinct threat to realty interests in a booklet entitled "Rent Control in War and Peace," recently published by the Citizens Housing Council of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--The call of his public has once again become too strong for him, Representative Robert L. Doughton said today in stating that he will run in November for re-election to represent the Ninth District of North Carolina. He recently said that he would retire at the end of the session of Congress, which is the fifteenth consecutive one in which he has represented his constituency.

EUROPE'S general belt-tightening for war pinches particularly the use of motor vehicles. In strong contrast to unhampered motor travel in the United States, nearly all Old World nations have adopted since the outbreak of fighting strict limitations for saving gasoline. These take the forms of fuel rationing, travel restrictions and special permits for vehicles.

An outstanding development in real estate last year was the steady increase in the number of families who purchased small homes, declares Frank O'Hara, past president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

Filing of final papers has completed negotiations whereby the Consumer Distribution Corporation is turning over the Greenbelt Consumer Services, Inc., at the government housing project at Greenbelt ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (U.P.)-- The National Monopoly Committee reported tonight that recent widespread increases in the prices of bread exceeded corresponding increase in costs of raw materials.

With St. Francis, Manhattan, Fordham and Brooklyn College running into defeats, L.I.U. held to one of its lowest point totals in memory and N.Y.U. forced to come from behind to beat Colgate, metropolitan college basketball teams found last week none too pleasant.
We were astonished the other day to learn that it took psychologists and statisticians to figure out the Mile-of-Dimes table set up in Grand Central Station for the 1940 Paralysis Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Secondary climax of some ten days of festivities in honor of President Roosevelt's birthday, the President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight made one of their rare joint appearances at the theatre to see a request performance of "Life With Father."

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 28--Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., minority leader of the House, seemed tonight to be the possible "dark-horse" candidate for the Republican nomination for President that party leaders have been looking ...
"Easy-chair Christians" who expect to be transported to heaven on a "feather bed" were chided by the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg yesterday in solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The church must proclaim heresies, "fully and uncompromisingly," as a step in its task to inspire again those men and women who have drawn away from their faith in these times, the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventyfourth Street.

When Lotte Lehmann sang Schubert's "An die Musik" at, her recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the eminent soprano seemed to be asserting in that eulogy her own deep adoration of the tonal art, which gradually has led her to a new restraint and simplicity effecting a magical change for the better in her work this season.

STOCKHOLM, aweden, Jan. 28-- It is being said, on the one hand, that German spies in Narvik, Norway, are reporting England-bound shipments of Swedish iron ore by means of portable radio sets and, on the other, that Swedish Communists ...

LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 28--Leo Freisinger of Chicago captured the senior men's crown and Miss Madeline (Maddy) Horn of Beaver Dam, Wis., won the women's title for the fourth time in the national outdoor speed skating championships today.

The Vicar General of Gniezno is Father Edoardo van Blericq. When the Germans made their military occupation he was prohibited from exercising ecclesiastical jurisdiction. The Archdiocese Curia has been closed by the Gestapo.

JUST recently this observer encountered the dapper Mr. Conn Smythe, managing director of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the big-time hockey circuit. It was Mr. Smythe who put into a Boston paper an advertisement that was answered by the Boston Bruins in a body on skates.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP)--Minor league executives gave the same mixed response today as did officials in the majors to Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis's latest plan for rebuilding the chainstore structure in baseball.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28--Despite substantial slowing up in new steel business since the first of the year, and notwithstanding the fact that fresh orders last week still disclosed no upward tendency, steel company officials are not apprehensive.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28--Scattered liquidation developed in American wheat markets last week, resulting in a decline in prices to around the lowest levels in about two months.

ROVANIEMI, Finland, Jan. 28 (U.P.)--Finnish leaders were anxious tonight to learn the fate of fifty to sixty long overdue American pursuit planes, about one-fifth the number of foreign planes that they say are necessary to clear the skies of Russian bombers.

PARIS, San. 28--Comments on the sudden switch in Germany's policy toward Finland are made in the monthly report of the German Social Democratic party, published here with the view of giving to the world data on events in Germany.

LAKE PLACID, N,Y., Jan. 28-- Streaking down the snow-covered mountainside at breakneck speed, William Diston, 17-year-old Saranac High senior, achieved the fastest time in the third annual New York State downhill skiing championships held under ideal conditions today on Whiteface Trail.

LONDON, Jan. 28--Deposits in Barclays Bank, Lloyds Bank, the Midland Bank, the National Provincial Bank and the Westminister Bank, Great Britain's "Big Five," amounted to 2,094,100,000 at the end of 1939, against 1,950,100,000 twelve months before.

Probably it was absence of any definite trend, either in domestic industry or in activities at the war front, which was responsible for the stationary attitude of last week's stock market. Not much attention was bestowed even on the fall of 3 cents in wheat or to the temporary reaction in cotton.

Tax exemption for new industries plus guarantees for those already established that they will no longer be annoyed by "officious city departments" will be sought by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens as a means of checking the steady flight of factories from New York, he announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 (U.P.)--The Deutsche Diplomatisch Politische Korrespondenz, organ of the Foreign Office, today termed yesterday's speech of Winston Churchill, Britain's First Lord of the Admiralty, "a reproach to the neutrals for shrinking from what is alleged to be 'their' war."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)--A move to sidetrack legislation to impose an embargo on exports to Japan but extend additional financial aid to China is gaining some headway in the Senate.
DETROIT, Jan. 28 (AP)--the Detroit Red Wings ran their string of games without defeat to four straight tonight by defeating the world champion Boston Brutins, 4 to 2, before 7,111 fans.

The disease which is most widely known as infantile paralysis comes unannounced; it strikes in all parts of the world, in all climates, in congested areas and on farms alike. And despite the name even old persons are susceptible, though a high percentage of adults is found to be immune.

Peter A. Juley Sons, Inc., photographer are being forced out of the building they have occupied for thirty-five years at 219 East Thirtyninth Street because the property there is required by the City of New York as a site for part of the approach to the new midtown tunnel.

TWO hundred and fifty years ago this week, up in Massachusetts Colony, there appeared what is said to be the first paper money ever printed in this country. It consisted of official bills of credit dated Feb. 3, 1690, with nominal values ranging between two shillings and 5. Clever gentlemen soon got busy, and after a while so many counterfeit notes were in circulation that the legitimate series had to be withdrawn.
After declining sharply early in the week because of weakness in foreign markets, the cotton market in the last part of the week retraced about one-half of its recession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Every Republican who has been mentioned as a possible Presidential nominee and scores who have not will speak at Lincoln Day celebrations during the period Feb. 8-16, according to an announcement today by the Republican National Committee.

As usual, war gives literature the boot. Recently the Publishers Association of Great Britain and Ireland gave notice that henceforth the price of common seven-and-six novels would be jacked up to eight-and-three. Longer and fatter fiction--the sort that seems a sure thing in the United States-- would cost from nine shillings to nineand-six.

Friends of the Metropolitan Opera, ranging all the way from Joe Wasp, truck driver, to Herbert Hoover, former president of the United States, rallied yesterday to the support of the campaign to raise $1,000,000 to perpetuate the opera.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 28-- There's a big boom on the Swiss sample market these days. It provides only lean pickings for Swiss merchants, but every little bit helps in the drive to compensate for war-lost trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court may hand down tomorrow a number of important decisions including a ruling on the constitutionality of New York City's 2 per cent sales tax on products brought into the metropolis from another State.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP)-- Stanley M. (Larry) Doyle, special investigator, today took steps intended to purge himself of any contempt of which he may have been guilty in his appearance before the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee here.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28--Police are searching for five masked and armed bandits who early this morning robbed Miss Constance Bennett and Miss Anita Louise, actresses, of jewelry valued at $33,095.

A specal memorial service for Prince Christopher of Greece, who died last week in Athens, was held yesterday following a solemn high mass at Holy Trinity Cathedral of the Greek Orthodox Church, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Jan. 20 to 26 are give in the appended tabulation:

DETROIT, Jan. 28 (U.P.)--The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin suggested today that "those who sit in the seats of the mighty" were responsible for a movement to investigate his activities, possibly "to rid the world of a troublesome priest."

The return of Giuseppe De Luca, Italian baritone, after five years' absence; the debut of Licia Albanese, Italian lyric soprano, and the season's first performance of "Madama Butterfly" will feature the eleventh week of the Metropolitan Opera, which will begin on Monday, Feb. 5.

The number of workers employed by private contractors on Public Works Administration projects in this State has declined from 26,554 in September to a present total of 13,354, Colonel M.E. Gilmore, Regional Director of the PWA, disclosed yesterday.

The Army and Navy Munitions Board is concerned over American exports of tin and rubber. Of neither of the two commodities does the United States produce an appreciable amount. Years of effort have failed to develop a genuine American tin mining industry: 1938 domestic output, although the highest on record, totaled only 168 tons, a ...

TOKYO, Jan. 28--A new antiComintern pact grouping, omitting Germany, was suggested by Count Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, in a recent conversation with Eiji Amau, the Japanese Ambassador, in Rome, according to a dispatch ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The heaviest foreign liquidation of domestic securities since the Treasury began keeping records on the present basis occurred in October, the second month of the European war, when foreign interests made net ...

Daniel Frohman's fifty-eighth annual benefit for the Actors Fund of America was held last night at the Winter Garden, where a capacity audience was entertained by the stars of stage, screen, radio and night clubs. Standees lined the wall back of the orchestra seats.

A definitely more confident attitude among national consumer goods advertisers has developed since the first of the year as the result of maintained business activity and advertising schedules are beginning to reflect this improvement, according to agency executives. Prior to the New Year, the chief worry had been fear of an inventory pile-up in consumer goods, but this apparently has not developed and merchandise is moving steadily from consumer shelves.

Buyers visiting the market were numerous last week, and a substantial volume of business was placed, especially in the apparel, accessories, piece-goods and home furnishings divisions, although a spirit of caution was noted with regard to covering future needs. Costumes, ensembles and jacket dresses were stressed, but a shortage of one-piece dresses was noted.

Dr. William Wallace Whitelock, educator and author, died yesterday at his residence, 1,240 Park Avenue, after an illness of several weeks, never having recovered completely from injuries received when he was struck by a drunken vagrant on the street a year ago. He was seventy years old.

A plan to limit unemployment insurance benefits for workers who quit their jobs voluntarily is being considered by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department, it became known yesterday.
ROME, Jan. 28 (U.P.)--Nedo Nadi, former international fencing champion and one of the greatest swordsmen who ever lived, died here tonight at the age of 45.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28--Members of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, arriving for the council's quarterly meeting opening here tomorrow, declared today that organized labor would take a "strictly independent", attitude in the coming Presidential campaign and that no candidate would receive a "blank check" from the A.F. of L.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Larger shipments of cotton to Great Britain, China, Spain and Sweden discounted decreases in export to Japan, Germany, Poland and France last year and brought the total export to a figure 5.6 per cent greater in quantity and 6.6 per cent greater in value than in 1938, the Department of Commerce reports.

LONDON, Jan. 28--Impetus given to the stock markets by the government's conversion scheme continued throughout last week although with the slackening recently it may be regarded that the "top of the hill" draw's nearer.

PHALSBOURG, France, Jan. 28 --Phalsbourg, in Alsace, is the only place in the army zone from which a correspondent may date a dispatch. It lies not much more than twenty miles from the fighting line, almost due south of Zweibruecken.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Treasury's $2,000,000,000 Currency Stabilization Fund showed net earnings of $l,195,298 from June 30 to Sept. 30, 1939, according to a balance sheet printed in The Treasury Bulletin for January, made public today.

Restoration of the psychiatric, psychological and allied professional services eliminated from the State prison system by legislative action last year is recommended to the current session of the Legislature in the ninety-fifth annual report of the Prison Association of New York, made public yesterday.

The Association to Promote Proper Housing for Girls, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the premiere on Tuesday night of Christopher Young's moving picture in color entitled "30,000 Miles to Ski." The show will be presented, with Mr. Young as interpreter, at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

A trend to higher temperatures was seen throughout the country yesterday after a night of bitter cold temperatures that reached down to Miami, severely damaging the Winter crops of vegetables and citrus fruits in Florida and across the South through Louisiana and Texas.

The Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria presented a brilliant scene last night when members of society and operatic and concert stars appeared in "Variations of 1940," a musical fantasy designed by Tom Lee as the fifth annual benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Vincent ...

NICE, France, Jan. 28--Norman Kerry, former, Hollywood film star, and Tommy Lehman, wealthy American journalist, have joined the French Foreign Legion. They enlisted here on Friday and later entrained for Lyon, whence, it is reported, they will be sent to Africa.

PARIS, Jan. 28--There was not the slightest activity on the Bourse last week. With trading extremely restricted, prices slumped from day to day without any important reaction and ended with a general decline from the preceding week.

Captain Richard Peters, said to be the oldest soldier in the Allies army during the World War, died at 12:05 o'clock this morning at Doctors Hospital. He was 92 years old on Jan. 11. He was taken to the hospital a week and a half ago after ...

Mayor La Guardia assailed the Judges of Kings County Court once more yesterday for failing to correct alleged abuses in the court's probation division and announced he would appeal again to the Legislature to correct a situation in which, he said, the city as well as the State Probation Commission and Governor Lehman are helpless.

Completion of four new school buildings providing 8,908 seats for school children was announced yesterday by Daniel Paul Higgins, chairman of the committee on buildings and sites of the Board of Education. Construction of the buildings cost $6,700,000 and the sites $2,000,000.
PARIS, Jan. 28--The French High Command today reported renewed naval attacks against what was described as "a new wave" of German submarines preying on the Allies' shipping.

In urging support of a labor boycott against his stocking store until an electrical workers' strike is settled and the picketing of his shop is discontinued, Philip E. Schmid, manager of the Glenmore Hosiery Company at 3 Clinton Street, yesterday won the commendation of ...

The Christian church is not divided and therefore does not need to be united, the Rev. W.H. Rogers, pastor of the First Bap tist Church, Broadway at Seventyninth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

ROME, Jan. 28--Details of mass shootings, manhunts by German Gestapo [Secret Police] agents, plundering and persecutions conducted with cold-blooded brutality and ferocity are contained in a memorandum published today describing what is held to be the situation of the Catholic Church and of the Polish people in the archdioceses of Gniezno and Poznan.

Intellectual freedom in the United States is threatened, and the liberal forces in the nation should unite in a fight against legislative and other movements to restrict civil liberties, speakers declared yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Complaint that a cosmetic manufacturer, two concerns engaged in selling cosmetics and forty-four individuals conspired to evade the ban on promotion of the sale of merchandise by fake prize contests through the medium of an advertising company which continually was being dissolved and then again merging under another name, has been made by the Federal Trade Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 28--Resistance is not enough for victory. That is the inner meaning of the speech at Manchester yesterday by Winston Churchill, First Lord of the Admiralty.

One of man's most glaring inconsistencies is his practice of "believing" when concerned with matters of everyday life and his "refusal to believe" when religious truths are concerned, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday in St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries, in a report for the thirteen weeks ended on Nov. 25, 1939, to be released today, show a net operating profit of $642,129 after all charges, including amortization, depreciation and Federal income taxes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28--A brisk foreign demand for American cash corn developed last week and sales were estimated at more than 2,000,000 bushels. The business was without effect, however, as a pricemaking influence of consequence, and closing in corn yesterday on the Board of Trade here showed losses of 1 to 1 cents a bushel for the week.

Police Commissioner Valentine announces in general orders issued this morning 317 awards to members of the department for meritorious conduct in the period ending Dec 31, 1939. The awards included twelve of honorable mention, 110 of commendation and 195 of excellent police duty.

Mayor La Guardia's bill to provide reorganized pension systems for the Police and Fire Departments, now pending before the City Council, was criticized yesterday as unsound and unfair by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission.

The Communist party should be barred from the ballot, Raymond J. Kelly, national, commander of the American Legion, declared in an interview here yesterday in which he termed the party a "criminal conspiracy and a revolutionary movement and not a bona fide political party."

HEADQUARTERS OF FTNNISH NORTHERN ARMY, Jan. 28--Another Soviet division is now on its way from Archangel, Russia, to the central part of the Eastern Front to strengthen the considerable forces already facing the Finnish troops in this area. This division will raise the Soviet strength in that particular sector to approximately 50,000 men.

BERLIN, Jan. 28--In the absence of new issues and considering the reluctance of present holders to part with their shares and bonds even at higher prices, the situation is developing into a speculative stock market boom, which, for many reasons, the government considers undesirable.

Clement J. Heaton, painter of stained glass whose windows decorate churches here and in Europe, died Saturday night in Lenox Hill Hospital from injuries received in the afternoon, when he was struck by an automobile while crossing Park Avenue at Eighty-first Street.

Statements made by speakers at meetings of the Birth Control Federation of America here last week and the publicity given to them constitute a "subtle" and "insidious" persecution of the Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. John F. Fitzgerald declared in a sermon yesterday at the Church of St. Paul ...

ALBANY, Jan. 28--Enactment of a "little Hatch bill" in the State is one of the first purely political matters to arise in the current session of the Legislature. Two measures, similar in whole or in part to the Federal measure designed to end election and pre-election pressure by government office-holders, have already been introduced.

PARIS, Jan. 28 (UP)--The Duchesses of Windsor and Kent today wrested the title of world's best dressed woman away from Mme. Antenor Patino, the "Tin Princess" whose husband is heir to one of the world's biggest fortunes, a poll of Parisian dressmakers showed.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 28-- The veteran Lyon Mountain crew, piloted by Big Bill Linney, won its second major four-man bobsledding championship today by capturing the Adirondack A.A.U. title on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run. Victorious in the Sam Packer ...

Lawrence W. Cramer, Governor of the Virgin Islands, announced yesterday in Washington that he had arranged with two steamship companies to have their ships make nine stops in the islands during the Winter travel season.

Jules Bledsoe, Negro baritone, who first sprang into the limelight with his singing of "Ol' Man River" in "Show Boat" some fifteen years ago, gave a recital last night in Town Hall, where he was well received by an audience of good size.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28--Dr. William David Haggard of Nashville, Tenn., noted surgeon, who had headed several medical organiza tions, died in his sleep of a heart attack at a hotel here early this morning. His age was 67.

Although the home skaters failed to get a tie-breaking marker in the overtime session, young Frankie Boucher's goal with only ten seconds of the regular contest to go more than pleased the 13,366 spectators as the New York Rovers battled the vastly improved River Vale ...

BERLIN, Jan. 28--The contrast between Germany's financing methods in the present and in the last war is most strikingly illustrated in the role that tax revenue plays in meeting the Reich's expenditures in 1939, compared with 1914.
DEL MAR, Calif , Jan. 28 (AP)-- Ed Oliver of Hornell, N.Y., captured his first major golf prize today-the fourth annual $3,000 Bing Crosby open with a thirty-six-hole score of 68, 67--135.

PARIS, Jan. 28--After five consecutive communiques announcing that there had been nothing to report, tonight's official bulletin from the Western Front declares that outpost and patrol activity has been resumed at several points.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 28-- The characteristic of the present phase of the war is that the neutrals are under greater stress than the belligerents. The struggle outside of the fighting lines is as real and costly as the conflict itself.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 28-- Mayor Frank Hague, the State Democratic leader, revealed through a spokesman today that, a petition pledging the New Jersey delegation to the national convention to support a third term for President Roosevelt would be filed "within one week" with Thomas A. Mathis, Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--With the economy drive in the balance, the House this week faces the decision of denying parity payments to farmers in an election year or granting them in the face of no provision to meet their cost and ...

The Misses Lillian McArdle, Susan Hernsdorf, Margaret Sanderson and Ferne Bramhall, representing the Shelton Dolphins, yesterday captured the national junior 440-yard relay championship which featured the A.A.U. program at the Women's Swimming Association pool.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--President Roosevelt, it was reported authoritatively today, has been sounding out recent White House callers on possible Democratic PresidentialVice Presidential combinations for 1940, and has often mentioned Mayor La, Guardia of New York City as a possibility for second place on the ticket.

Amid the hubbub befitting a star, John Barrymore arrived here last night from Detroit for his opening Wednesday evening in "My Dear Children," which will mark his first Broadway stage appearance in fifteen years.

The New York Board of Trade, declaring that "tax rates can destroy tax sources, "has asked Mayor La Guardia to lead the protests against the State budget and tax increase at the hearing in Albany on Feb. 12.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 28--Dr. John Joseph Cloonan, a practicing physician in Stamford for more than forty years and long active in banking and civic circles, died at Stamford Hospital today after a brief illness. His age was 72.

A two-goal deficit meant nothing to the New York Rangers in their clash with their city rivals, the Americans, at Madison square Garden last night. Lester Patrick's blue-jerseyed stick wielders overcame this advantage and then went on to score two more goals, to encompass a 4-to-2 defeat of the courageous Dutton Dusters.

With a scant two inches of powdery snow in the woods and only a few scattered patches of snow on the sunny slopes, the past week-end wasn't productive of the best conditions for foxhunting in the Connecticut hills, but we had some good runs just the same.

The three rebels from the Sixtyninth Regiment A.A. ran in Boston last Saturday against the orders of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. and were wondering today whether or not they had run themselves out of the Millrose carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

BEAR, MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 28--Joe Bree made a successful defense of his interstate outdoor speed skating champion today on Hessian Lake and Mrs. Edna Hanley Strachan of Staten Island became the new women's titleholder in the meet conducted by the Middle Atlantic Skating Association and the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 --A hint was conveyed today to the Balkan Entente conference opening here Friday, that Germany would not tolerate any departure from the neutral policy to which the Entente had adhered so far and that she likewise would oppose any efforts to create a more far-reaching Southeastern bloc.
Play in the metropolitan Class B badminton tournament at the old Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory was concluded yesterday with the finals in all five of the sections taking up the entire session.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan, 28--Victor in three straight heats, two yesterday and one this morning, William D. Smith's ice boat Hot Toddy of the Rumson Country Club today annexed the championship of the Eastern division of the International Skeeter Association and is eligible to compete in the international championships set for Feb. 4 on Lake Geneva at Oshkosh, Wis.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America, speaking yesterday morning at the 130th anniversary celebration at St. James Church, Madison ...

A proposal for a study of the city's tax structure by a committee of public officials, laymen and experts will be presented to the City Council at its meeting tomorrow, Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, minority leader, announced yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 28-- Official figures on the first half of the Winter season's sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club were announced today by Race Chairman Arthur Knapp to the assembled skippers and crews, who could not start the second session because of the ice-clogged condition of the harbor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The American Federation of Labor reported today that 1,358,000 more persons were at work last December than in December, 1938, thus reducing unemployment rolls about 800,000 and providing for the 550,000 youths who were added to the country's working population during the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Jan. 28-- Jed Harris, Broadway producer, will enter the field of motion-picture production this year with Lewis Milestone, it was learned today. Harris declined to discuss his plans or confirm the reported formation of a new company, saying that he had nothing to announce at this time.

Sixteen lots on the south side of Yellowstone Boulevard, between Sixty-seventh Avenue and Sixtyseventh Road, Forest Hills, L.I., were sold by Samuel L. Norman to a client of Louis D. Cohen for investment. This is the third plot on this street sold in two weeks by the same broker to builders.

If sketchy reports of the eight-day battle on the northern shores of Lake Ladoga are confirmed, the Finns have won a stirring victory indeed--a victory over an army and not merely the destruction of an isolated division. So far, however, there is nothing in the official Finnish communiques to support such reports.

A PORT IN CANADA, Jan. 28-- One might fittingly date this dispatch Atlantic Ferryhouse, for that is what the port is. From it goes out unceasingly a stream of supplies, human and material, to aid France and Great Britain in their war to end Hitlerism, and there comes in with the same regularity another stream.
