While defending labor's collective bargaining rights against the opposition of a small minority of "social illiterate" employers, the Rev. Dr. John P. Boland, New York State Labor Relations Board chairman, speaking yesterday at Fordham University also voiced strong condemnation of communistic, dictatorial and "racketeering" elements of which labor now is trying to clean its own house.
Tomorrow is a fateful anniversary, On Jan. 30, seven years ago, the aging President von Hindenburg appointed Adolf Hitler Chancellor of Germany at the head of a coalition Cabinet.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 27--Since the beginning of the second invasion scare on Jan. 15, which now has evaporated, securities markets in the neutral countries, almost without interruption, have persisted along a listless course. Activity, while the disturbing reports were circulating, was as good as at a minimum.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and his supporters decided yesterday to enter the Illinois Presidential preference primary on April 9 in hope of winning the support of that State's fifty-eight delegates to the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--In spite of the termination of the United States-Japanese trade treaty one of its articles will, in effect, remain in force. This is Article XV, the patents and trademarks section of the dead treaty, which reads:

TIENTSIN, China, Monday, Jan. 29--Electrically charged barbed wire barriers and Japanese sentries today retightened the blockade around the British and French concessions, creating a severe food shortage in the foreign-controlled areas.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 28-- The attention of military observers here today was centered on the fighting northeast of Lake Ladoga-- now in its second week--and on the question whether the Russian forces there would suffer disastrous defeat or escape from the Finnish circle.

L.F. Sanman was the major winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He captured the high-over-all scratch cup with 95 of 100, took the handicap trophy in Class A with a total of 99 and paced the scratch and handicap 155-target field with a card of 143--5-148. S. Milligan triumphed in Class B with a full card.

So many "new records" were made last year, in American industrial production and consumption that the course of the very important building construction industry deserves particular attention. There were months last year in which residential building contracts were the largest in dollar value since 1929.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28--Liberal receipts of hogs and lower prices for the latter, combined with hedging pressure, resulted in a moderate decline in lard last week.

The annual report of the Carriers and General Corporation shows a net asset value of $6.20 a share at the close of 1939, against $4.84 a share on June 30 and $6.19 at the end of 1938. Total assets were $5,892,442, with securities at market values, against $5,078,038 at midyear and $5,908,972 at the end of 1938.

Business recessions are not caused by the failure of consumers' purchasing power, according to the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York. In taking this stand, the publication disagrees with President Roosevelt's budget message to Congress.

PAULDING, Ohio, Jan. 28--The carefully aimed rifle shot which Oscar Ball, a farmer, fired from a second-story window killed a man holding Ball's 19-year-old son, Richard, at pistol point to force payment of "blackmail" money, Police Chief Frark Wallar reported today.

The publication Science quotes from The Times of London an account of an incident that would have seemed incredible in a Copernican world if it had not been vouched for by high authority. That it occurred in the University of Cracow, where Copernicus pursued his studies, makes the act more abhorrent.

ALBANY, Jan. 28--The Week which has passed since the submission by Governor Lehman of his budget and tax program to the State Legislature has witnessed the upsetting of the revenue side of that program. The feeling in Albany is that the recommendation for a $15,000,000 increase in the personal income tax is dead.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 29 --The Rumanian interest in the week-end meeting of the Balkan Entente at Belgrade centers in the attitude of Yugoslavia. That country is regarded here as the uncertain quantity in the conference, which has for its real object not merely the discussion of Balkan problems, but the adoption, if possible, of a common front toward the war.

Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, in an address last night at the Stevens Alumni dinner at the Hotel Astor, attended by a distinguished group of industrialists, engineers and financiers...

Mr. and Mrs. Otis T. Bradley gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,160 Park Avenue, taking their guests later to the benefit performance of "The Male Animal" at the Cort Theatre in aid of the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association.

In a fortnight or so Sixth Avenue is to have its first extensive preSpring tree planting. Mr. Herbert Askwith, a perfervid and persuasive man who is New York's Johnny Appleseed, burbled in with the news yesterday.
MONTREAL, Jan. 29--Milt Schmidt of the Boston Bruins, rated by Manager Art Ross among hockey's all-time stars, has taken a clear lead in the race for National Hockey League scoring honors.

ALBANY, Jan. 29--Governor Lehman's proposal of a $15,000,000 in crease in the personal income tax to balance the State's budget for the coming year was buried tonight as members of the Legislature, returning from the week-end visit to their constituencies, declared that they could not vote for any new tax this year.

PARIS, Jan. 29--After a two-day thaw which caused immense flooding more snow and sleet fell today all over. Eastern and Northern France, reducing war activity to some artillery and rifle fire and a few air reconnaissances.

Edward Stephen Harkness, railway financier and heir to one of the country's largest fortunes, who devoted the greater part of his lifetime to distributing more than $100,000,000 in philanthropies to educational and welfare agencies in various parts of the world, died at 5:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon at his home at 1 East Seventy-fifth Street.

Ice crusted the 137-foot threemasted schooner Director II at the foot of East Nineteenth Street yesterday and great floes swept by in the river, but below decks all was rosy with the glow of a sendoff.

TIENTSIN, China, Tuesday, Jan. 30--Japan's economic warfare against British interests in North China took a new turn yesterday when the Japanese-controlled Peiping Regional Government began enforcement of a decree rescinding a previous exemption from exchange control regulations of export's valued at 100 yuan [about $7] or less.

Perhaps lured by word of a widespread tie-up in Britain resulting from wintry weather [Page 3], fifteen or more German bombers swept over 400 miles of the eastern British coast yesterday, bombing and machine-gunning a dozen ships in the war's most ambitious aerial operation. [Page 1.] In Finland, too, planes were active ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Mrs. Roosevelt has enlisted Cabinet and Congressional wives in a "hospitality campaign" on behalf of the delegates to the American Youth Congress which will conduct a citizenship institute here next month...

OTTAWA, Jan. 29--Canada and the United States, it was learned from authoritative sources here today, have reached complete agreement on the St. Lawrence waterway scheme as devised in Ottawa and Washington, and the treaty is now being prepared for signature. The signing may take place any day in the immediate future.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29--Liquidation developed today in the wheat market and prices dipped to new low levels since the middle of December and closed almost on the bottom. Net losses on the Board of Trade here were 2 1/8 to 2 cents a bushel.

In the current issue of Harper's Magazine appears an article by Stuart Chase called "Capital Not Wanted." It expresses a conclusion which is not only erroneous but which, if seriously accepted, would be capable of doing a great deal of harm. This conclusion is that "American business enterprises have little use for the savings of the public, and what use they have is declining."

The conservatism which many merchants have shown in covering their initial Spring requirements in women's ready-to-wear will react beneficially upon the manufacturing trades in that it will insure a steady flow of reorders as the season advances, according to reports on Spring buying in merchandising quarters yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29--The highest Japanese Army circles in Shanghai deny reports from Paris and London to the effect that the SovietJapanese border negotiations, recently held in Harbin, have broken down.

A special meeting of the registration committee of the Metropolitan Association A.A.U. will be held tomorrow night, with the automatic suspension of three Sixty-ninth Regiment A.A. athletes the main topic to be discussed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP)-- Secretary Hull lashed out at critics of the Administration's trade treaty program today, particularly the "artful persons" who sent him a letter "under the name," as he said, of Representative Roy O. Woodruff, Republican, of Michigan.

Revocation of the license to practice law held by former Assistant District Attorney Alexander R. Baldwin of Brooklyn has been recommended by Official Referee Isaac M. Kapper, it was disclosed yesterday as the Appellate Division in Brooklyn reserved decision on a motion to confirm the referee's report.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 29-- Irked because bills increasing the expenses of Westchester County had been submitted to the State Legislature without first receiving endorsemeent from the Westchester Board of Supervisors, the board adopted a resolution today rebuking the sponsors of such measures.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29 --The last-minute diplomatic checking here that is preceding Friday's Balkan Entente meeting centered tonight on Bulgaria. It is apparent that all sorts of efforts are being made by various powers to line up that strategically placed country, which controls the heart of the Balkan peninsula, although it is not a member of the Entente.

Arrangements have been made for a merger of Merrill Lynch Co., Inc., E.A. Pierce Co., and Cassatt Co., Inc., to become effective at the close of business on March 30, according to an announcement made jointly yesterday by Charles E. Merrill, E.A. Pierce and T. Johnson Ward, heads of the three institutions.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29--Suspension of all locals affiliated with the International Typographical Union, with a total membership of about 80,000, from all city central bodies and State Federations of Labor was ordered today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, meeting here in its midwinter session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The national capital "went Hollywood" today as motion picture stars in droves assembled to regale the populace at six balls and two shows in honor of President Roosevelt's birthday tomorrow night.

The firm name of Soucy, Swartswelter Co., of Boston has been changed to Soucy Co. The firm holds membership in the New York, Cleveland and Detroit Stock Exchanges and also is an associate member of the New York Curb Exchange.

Herbert Hoover, national chairman of the Finnish Relief Fund, and Mayor La Guardia, New York chairman, thanked the people of the theatre last night for contributing their services in special performances of plays for the benefit of the women and children of Finland.

HAVANA, Jan. 29--A mass meeting attended by 15,000 persons was held last night in Central Park by the Opposition parties, which have refused to participate in the general elections set for March 28 and are demanding that the Constituent Assembly draft a new Constitution before elections are held.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Congress was asked today by President Roosevelt for supplemental 1940 fiscal-year appropriations totaling $34,267,381 for sixteen agencies, nearly half of which was accounted for by requests for funds to continue or complete reclamation and irrigation projects in the Southwest and West.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 29-- Russian fliers violently bombed many Finnish cities and towns today, and it is unofficially reported that more than fifty persons were killed and many more wounded. The air raids included one that destroyed a hospital in the Viborg district, killing twenty-three, of whom seven were nurses and the rest patients.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio, a dark horse Republican Presidential possibility, made his campaign year bow here today with the promise to do all in his power "to secure the nomination for Senator Robert Taft." At the same time he said Ohio would sue the Federal Government for $1,338,000 of withheld Social Security funds which Congress failed to grant over President Roosevelt's veto.

DETROIT, Jan. 29--"Religious disunion is a fact which must be faced," the Rev. Edward J. Hickey, chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit, told the 500 delegates to the general assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds tonight.
A net profit of $6,268,360 after depreciation, interest, taxes and other charges was reported yesterday in the preliminary statement for 1939 by the Safeway Stores, Inc.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 29 (AP)--Arizona Bill, who hated a bed worse than a rattlesnake, died in one yesterday.

The gifts Edward S. Harkness distributed to preparatory schools and colleges revolutionized secondary and higher learning in private institutions, Dr. Lewis Perry, principal of Phillips Exeter Academy at Exeter, N.H., said last night over the telephone from his home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Except for the arms embargo repeal and the thirdterm puzzle, the question of aid to Finland has produced more discussion in Washington than any subject during the past year. And the longer Congress looks into the matter, the more hesitant it seems to do anything on its own responsibility that will approximate the immediate monetary and munitions

Cool thinking and swift action by a Consolidated Edison Company service man probably saved the life of a small boy yesterday afternoon after a thunderous explosion had rocked the vicinity of Third Avenue and 185th Street in the Bronx, injuring three persons seriously and smashing windows within a fourblock radius.
The three Transit Commissioners declined indignantly yesterday Mayor La Guardia's offer of other official jobs in return for their cooperation in abolishing the commission.

After several members had reported that Mayor La Guardia's recent attack on Grade A milk and advice to use Grade B had hurt sales of certified milk, the Metropolitan Certified Milk Producers and Certified Milk Producers Association of America adopted a resolution at their annual joint meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday...

The Yankees yesterday announced the signing of Steve Sundry and Lee Grissom, pitchers. According to custom President Ed Barrow did not reveal the salaries. It is understood, however, that Sundra received an increase over last year's stipend.

The opinion that "un-American activities" should be investigated by joint House and Senate committees or Presidential commissions, is expressed in the report of a survey of "The Opportunity and Task of United Protestantism in Brooklyn," presented yesterday to the opening session of a two-day conference at tha Hanson Place Methodist Church, St. Felix Street and Hanson Place, Brooklyn.
No change occurred yesterday in the pattern of trading in the stock market, and with the volume off sharply from that of Friday, shares closed easier and mixed after irregular gains.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29--An appeal for the development of the local production, of foodstuff and consumers goods is made in Pravda today by Trade Commissar of the Russian Soviet Pavlov. As frequently occurs here, there is a footnote to the article stating that it is published as a topic for discussion.

Defending curtailments in State expenditures, Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Assembly ways and means committee, declared yesterday that "the State has not got the money to make up any of the cuts of last year," including the reduction in State aid for education.

HAVANA, Jan. 29--Two races in the fourteenth International Star Class series for the Bacardi Cup were sailed today, with Harry Nye's Gale of the Southern Lake Michigan fleet taking the lead with a total of 27 points by winning this afternoon's race.

The Durieux Chamber Music Ensemble, conducted by Willem Durieux, gave the first of two concerts at the Town Hall last night. The guest artists were Kathleen Parlow, violinist, and Katherine Bacon, pianist. They were soloists with the ensemble of ten strings players-- nine of whom are women--in the infrequently heard Concerto for Violin, piano and strings, Op. 21, by Ernest Chausson.
THE obvious comment to be made on this case is that there was something wrong with the football Dodgers and they called in the doctor. He's in charge now and the patient is expected to recover.
The Drottningholm, the only vessel of the Swedish American Line now in transatlantic operation, arrived here yesterday with 507 passengers, 155 of whom were American citizens and 200 German refugees.

Earl Reeves, writing in the magazine Events, tells of a "chaos of incompetence, a mass of sullen terror, a morass of ignorance" in the Russian military machine. The Metropolitan Opera Fund's campaign for $1,000,000 to perpetuate the opera in its historic home at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street has met with a popular response that has already produced more than 10,000 letters enclosing contributions, and a number of larger gifts ranging from $1,000 to $11,000.

Their stepfather fighting in the Finnish Army against Russia, their mother and three small brothers and sisters back home in a little town a few miles from the seaport of Abo, Arne and Salme Soderlund, twin brother and sister, just 14 years old, arrived yesterday in an alien land to take up a new life.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29--After eight straight public choices had tasted defeat at Hialeah Park, F.J. Buchanan's Charlieinfeld took the Tavernier Purse, a six-furlong dash for 3-year-olds, today. However, the gelded son of Zacaweista was the shortest-priced winner of the meeting, paying $2.70 for $2.

ROME, Jan. 29--Conditions is German-held Poland have become even worse since the end of December, when the report submitted to the Vatican and the Polish Green Book were drawn up, August Cardinal Hlond told your correspondent in an interview today.

Reports of a wild white swan disporting itself daily among the ice floes of the Hudson River about a half mile from Nyack, of numbers of huge bald eagles foraging daily off Dyckman Street, of a rare barred owl that lately has taken up roost in a tree at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, and stories of seldom seen marine fowl straggling into Long Island bird sanctuaries from the Far North--all were received here yesterday.

Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, turned critic yesterday on various phases of his profession in an address to the New York City Visiting Committee at its annual meeting at the Russell Sage Foundation.
Donald Lamont Brown, president of the United Aircraft Corporation, died yesterday morning at the New York Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 49 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Admiral H.R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, speaking for the Navy Department before the House Commitee on Naval Affairs today, expressed the navy's regret that the pending expansion bill was not to be enacted in the original form sponsored by the department.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. MeLaughlin ruled yesterday that the city could drop twenty-one employes of the Queens County Clerk, whose duties and functions recently were transferred by statute to the State Motor Vehicle Bureau. The dismissals represent an annual saving of $39,901.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Subjected to continuous defeats at the hands of the House Appropriations Committee economy bloc, which already has slashed the 1941 fiscal supply bill for the Agriculture De partment by almost $100,000,000...

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 29 --Benny McCoy, 23-year-old second baseman who broke into the major leagues last year, signed a two-year contract at $10,000 a year with the Athletics today and got $45,000 for doing it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today it would hold a public hearing on Feb. 5 on the application of the Louisville Nashville Railroad for approval of the issuance and sale of $60,000,000 of collateral trust bonds.
PARIS, Jan. 29--Premier Edouard Daladier this evening, in a radio address to the people of France, said what he thought of the Nazi regime in Germany and its aims.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29-- Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt gave a dinner tonight at their villa. Jeffrey Roche of New York is their house guest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Mrs. Roosevelt attended today Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's 117th musical morning at the Mayflower Hotel, entertaining in the Presidential box a party including Mme. Martins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador; Senora de Escalante, ...

Play continued to follow form yesterday in the DeWitt Clinton Eastern Interscholastic indoor tennis championship tournament as seven of the eight seeded players survived their third-round tests and progressed to the quarter finals at the 369th Regiment Armory. Quentin Vaughan of Boys High 7, was the only seeded player eliminated, bowing before Al Roser of Clinton, 6-2, 6-1.

BERLIN, Jan. 29--The German Government, it was learned today, has made formal representations to the Vatican against the use of the Vatican radio for broadcasting charges of German persecution and slaughter of priests and civilians in German-occupied Poland.

WASHINTON, Jan. 29--President Roosevelt conferred for half an hour today with Torkild Rieber, American oil executive, who has returned from Germany where he had a conversation lasting more than two hours with Field Marshal Hermann Goering, whom Chancellor Hitler has selected as his heir in case of his death.

Eddie Shore, one of the greatest play-makers and scorers in hockey and for almost fifteen years the big gun on defense for the Boston Bruins, will skate out on the Madison Square Garden ice tonight for the first time this season and for the first time in his career as a member of the New York Americans.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29 (UP)--The Communist party of Mexico is seeking a strong "popular front" to fight "Yankee imperialism" and advocates an armed reserve to thwart the danger of a reactionary rebellion in connection with this year's Presidential election, it was revealed tonight.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick foresaw a substantial improvement in the city's financial standing yesterday, basing his prediction on the assertion that the city would attain its goal of a $100,000,000 unencumbered debt margin by 1944, a full year earlier than had been expected.

The two vacant plots on the north and south sides of East Seventyfirst Street, 200 feet west of First Avenue, each about 125 by 100 feet, were sold by 88 River, Inc., Leo Silver, president, to the Lenox Hill Apartments, Inc., and the Lenox Hill Development Corporation, respectively.
With contracts in Liverpool off the full 25 points permitted in one day and further weakness in the Bombay market, prices on the Cotton Exchange here lost 13 to 17 points yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Jack Davis, a Philadelphia regional attorney for the National Labor Relations Board, told the House committee investigating the board today that he urged members of an independent union not to seek withdrawal of charges filed against their employer by a C.I.O. union.

LONDON, Jan. 29--The stock markets opened today slowly owing to transport delays caused by heavy snowfalls. The general tendency was firm under the lead of gilt-edge securities. British funds gained up to 5 shillings, the largest rise being shown by the war loan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Barnsdall Oil Company will offer its common stock interest in Bareco Oil Company to the public, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29--At its final session on the West Coast, the Senate Civil Liberties Committee inquired today into a movement to get the boards of supervisors of various California counties to adopt ordinances requiring all labor organizers to take out licenses.

In our Topics of The Times recently, something was said of the tribute paid by the Nazi Government and army commanders on the birthday of Frederick the Great; recalling his memory, not only as a great soldier and the builder-up of Prussia, but as an example which Germans of today must imitate.

Kansas was admitted to the Union on Jan. 29, 1861. So yesterday was Kansas Day, as usual, celebrated both solemnly and joyfully by the Kansas Day Club, resonant and Republican. As usual, too, Eastern Republicans were on hand, some of them agents of Republican hopefuls who think the view from the White House windows the finest in the world.

The price war in the electric refrigeration industry is expected to give newspapers a greater portion of the total advertising budgets than in 1939 and at the same time to increase the expenditures of all manufacturers, according to advertising managers in the field.

LONDON, Jan. 29--The censor won't let a correspondent tell what kind of weather, but just the same the weather has caused more confusion around here in the past twenty-four hours than all the air raids this country has had since the start of the war.

Speaking to the members of the Committee of French-American Wives, which has headquarters at 18 East Forty-sixth Street and which is working for the relief of evacuated French people, Professor Robert Valeur said yesterday that a mililon French had been moved from their homes because of the war.

Dr. George Shattuck Whiteside, industrial and genito-urinary surgeon and World War veteran, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 1,212 Fifth Avenue. His age was 66.

The city of Miami, Fla., will be in the market on Feb. 5 with $28,160,000 of refunding bonds of 1940, for which bidders are to specify rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The City of New York led a veritable victory parade of local, State and Federal taxing authorities before the Supreme Court today, winning sweeping approval of its 2 per cent sales levy as applied to goods moving into New York in interstate commerce.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was the dullest yesterday since Aug. 31. Most of the leading issues had drifted irregularly lower by the close. The day's turnover in all bonds amounted to only $4,643,450, compared with $5,797,000 last Friday, the last previous five-hour session.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP)--Subzero temperatures began a retreat from the South today, but left behind much suffering, more than a hundred dead and damages estimated is the millions in Florida's citrus and vegetable growing area alone.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29--It was learned here today that the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry had asked the members of the foreign diplomatic corps not to invite government officials to receptions or meals at legations or embassies. ALBANY, Jan. 29--The Senate adopted and sent to the Governor tonight the Ives bill, giving the State Labor Relations Board greater leeway in picking its trial examiners. The measure had previously been adopted by the Assembly. It eliminates the requirement that Labor Board examiners shall be chosen on the basis of competitive examinations. They remain under other civil service requirements. The Senate vote was unanimous.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 29-- Boasting the best snow conditions since it entered the Winter sports picture thirty-four years ago, this pioneer Adirondack resort is now enjoying a record-breaking--skiing season.

The League of Nations not only has not died but probably will be called upon to perform the all-important task of organizing the peace conference in the present war, Dr. James T. Shotwell, retiring president of the League of Nations As sociation, declared last night at a dinner given in his honor at the Hotel Biltmore.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29--Dan Topping, owner of the football Dodgers, announced today Dr. John B. Sutherland, former Pitt coach, had agreed to coach the Brooklyn team for three years at an undisclosed salary, believed to be $10,000 to $12,000 a year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29-- Paulette Goddard today was assigned by Paramount to the role of Loupette in Cecil B. De Mille's "Northwest Mounted Police." Miss Goddard will be featured with Gary Cooper, Madeleine Carroll, Joel McCrea and Robert Preston. Shooting will start in March.

The appointment of nineteen persons to the faculty of Queens College in Flushing was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul Klapper, president. The new appointees, all but two of whom will assume their positions when the Spring semester begins Feb. 13, have been recruited from eight other schools.

A substantial number of buyers, particularly from Middle West stores, arrived in the wholesale markets yesterday. Merchants from the South and Southwest were fewer in number, with reports indicating that the unexpected cold wave in many sections had reduced January trade.

Hearings got under way yesterday before Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein in several actions brought to vacate as American Labor party indorsement given M. WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Admiral Byrd announced in a report under date of Jan. 26, received today by the Legislative Committee of the United States Antarctic Service, that in a three-hour flight he had penetrated deep into unkown regions and had charted more than 300 miles of coast line east of Little America.

With the huge Soviet Pavilion at the World's Fair being partitioned by workmen and rapidly nearing demolition, it became known yesterday that Finland had signed a contract to maintain its attractive pavilion at the Fair during the 1940 season, which begins May 11.

The two permanent trophies presented each year by the Tuna Club of Catalina, Calif., for the largest marlin and tuna taken on tuna club regulation tackle, which has a maximum of twenty-four-thread line and sixteen-ounce tip, have been awarded for 1939.

BERLIN, Jan. 30--While Chancellor Hitler in his address tonight significantly ignored last night's speech by Premier Daladier, the German press unanimously described it as "an outbreak of rage that reveals the internal difficulties of France as clearly as it reveals the desire to harness the neutrals to the Franco-British war machine."
The United States will not challenge Australia for the Davis Cup this year, Holcombe hard, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, told The United Press yesterday.
The American Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission that 50,000 shares of $10 par capital stock had been sold for $36.50 a share or $1,825,000 at private sale.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,611,600 barrels, a decline of 25,850 from the 3,637,450 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 41,900 barrels in excess of the calculation of 3,569,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for January. A decline of 11,000 barrels in the daily average output of California was the most important change.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 30 --President Roosevelt has approved in principle the creation of an insular reconstruction authority, according to Governor William D. Leahy, who has just returned from Washington, where he conferred with the President and other officials of the Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--"The real source of the present financial risks to customers" lies in "the broker's banking activities involving the possession and control of customers' funds and securities aggregating billions of dollars," the Securities and Exchange Commission said in its annual report, made public today.

The Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company notified customers yesterday that its service was subject to delay and that in some cases it was advisable to reroute commercial messages because of difficulties with some of its employes.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP)--Governor Lehman joined tonight with Raymond J. Kelly, national commander of the American Legion, is urging "adequate preparedness" to assure peace in the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--A State wageshours bill, sponsored by the American Labor party, which would set up a minimum wage rate of 40 cents an hour and a maximum work week of forty hours, was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Kleinfeld, Democrat of Brooklyn, and Assemblyman Boccia, Republican-Laborite of Manhattan.

One man was burned to death and seven others suffered burns, injuries and exposure last night when one of two tugboats, which collided in the East River off Montgomery Street, burst into flames.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A representative of a law firm in Louisville, understood to have been acting for Midwestern banking interests which have sought to wrest the underwriting of important security issues from Morgan Stanley Co.

Four more jurors were selected yesterday to try Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and three others charged with running a racket in the flour trucking industry, bringing to nine the total number sworn in during the three days since the trial started in General Sessions Court before Judge John J. Freschi.

An increase of 50 per cent in the annual license fee for package liquor stores and a measure requiring payment within ten days of delivery on all purchases of liquor by bars and grills appeared to be the most controversial points in a legislative program being sponsored by the State Liquor Authority and submitted to leaders is the industry here yesterday.
New York City has escaped so far the influenza epidemics that have appeared in various parts of the country in the last fortnight, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, noted yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia has consented to serve as honorary chairman of the sponsors' committee of the program to maintain and advance the Metropolitan Opera as a national music center, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Fund.
A number of leases calling for quarters on Park Avenue featured the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

St. Francis Prep's basketball team defeated Brooklyn Cathedral Prep, 60 to 19, on the losers' court in a Brooklyn division game of the C.H.S.A.A. yesterday. This was the eighth triumph in nine league starts for the winners, who are out in front in the race.

Television, limited hitherto to a range of about fifty miles is ready now for public operation over networks covering a much greater area, the Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday. Development of the radio relay method of transmitting makes it possible for a station is New York City, for example, to reach receivers in cities as far distant as Boston and Washington, D.C., the announcement said.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Opposition to a bill recommended by the Judicial Council which would permit appeals to the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court from judgments of the Court of Special Sessions in New York City was expressed here today by Special Sessions Justice Nathan D. Perlman at a public hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WITH THE FINNISH ARMY, on Central Northern Front, Jan. 30 --The war, quiescent here since early in January, when the Finns rounded off their Suomussalmi victory by destroying the Forty-fourth Red Army Division, is blazing up along Finland's eastern frontier.

LONDON, Jan. 30--The stock markets were quieter today and generally dull. Gilt-edge securities, however, attracted considerable attention and most prices in this section followed the lead of the war loan which went to its highest level in some time before easing.

ROME, Jan. 30--An attack on Communist sympathizers throughout the world was made over the Vatican City radio in two English broadcasts today. It was directed particularly at those who say that Stalinism and not communism is to blame for Russian policy since the war started.

An improvement in foreign cotton markets stemmed liquidation on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and prices recovered 4 to 10 points. Residents of the East Side last night listened to the Republican, Democratic and Communist candidates for Congress from the Fourteenth Congressional District speak from the same platform at the Manhattan Plaza, 66 East Fourth Street.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Jan. 31 --Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is hastening his measures to consolidate Chinese control of Tibet, according to advices from Chungking today, and expects during this year to make that formerly semiindependent State an integral part of Nationalist China.

With the Metropolitan High-Goal Indoor Polo League entering its final stages with the games at Squadron A Saturday night, notices have been mailed to clubs for the next major engagement of the season, the thirteenth annual invitation midwinter tournament of the New York Athletic Club.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 30--Senator C.F. Clarkson, Minister of Posts and Telegraphs, introduced a motion in the Senate today calling on the Upper House to confirm the South African Government's war policy. The Senate adjourned before a vote was taken.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30 --The German oil shortage has resulted in the compulsory transfer to the Reich of 3,000 tons of lubricating oil from Prague railroad stations, it was learned tonight from a reliable Czech source.

William M. Robbins has been elected president of the General Foods Sales Company, it was announced yesterday by C.M. Chester, chairman of General Foods Corporation. WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--Opponents of a bill to clarify and strengthen Federal regulation of dangerous cargo by water carriers said today it would constitute an injury to local sovereignty unwarranted by safety requirements.

After many diversions which have prevented a local stage appearance since his return engagement in "Hamlet" at the Manhattan Opera House in 1923, that latter-day Til Eulenspiegel, John Barrymore, returns tonight at the Belasco as the most extravagantly publicized phenomenon of the season.

A new concert hall seating about 500, the gift of Mrs. John Hubbard, will be dedicated at the Manhattan School of Music, 238 East 105th Street, next Sunday evening, it was announced yesterday. Mrs. Hubbard made the gift in memory of her husband, John Hubbard, and her brother, Dr. Ernest Fahnestock. She is the daughter of the late H. C. Fahnestock.
Earnings of the first 100 companies to report for the full year 1939 were 67 per cent larger than those in 1938, according to a compilation issued yesterday by The Associated Press.

LONDON, Jan. 30--Great Britain's first army casualty list, giving war losses up to the end of 1939 was issued by the War Office tonight. It contains 758 names, almost all officers and men who have died from illness or accident.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 30 (AP)-- Three stockholders of the American Tobacco Company petitioned Chancery Court today to vacate a consent decree dismissing a suit against the company in July, 1933. The petitioners contended the court was imposed upon and induced to issue an improper decree.

Arthur Wellington Teele, certified public accountant, partner in and one of the founders of the firm of Patterson, Teele Dennis, accountants and auditors at 120 Broadway, and a former president of the New York Athletic Club, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. Mr. Teele was 72 years old.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 30-- All the favorites won their first round matches in the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship over the Miami Biltmore Country Club course at Coral Gables today.

In an effort to speed up England's airplane pilot training program, the Canadian Government has opened, more or less quietly, negotiations in this country to obtain experienced American fliers for instructors' positions in the Dominion, it became known here yesterday.

Adequate care for what he termed "borderline" cases remains a necessity, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in opening officially the benefit at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn under auspices of the borough women's division of the Federation of Jewish Charities of New York and Brooklyn.

Bond quotations, in general, continued to drift irregularly downward in listless trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. There were, however, numerous individual exceptions to the trend, notably among the public utility issues and certain railroad loans.

An operating profit of $2,221,470 was shown in 1939 by the Maryland Casualty Company, according to the report of Stewart McDonald, chairman of the board, submitted to stockholders at the annual meeting of the company yesterday in Baltimore.

HAVANA, Jan. 30 The fourteenth International Star Class series for the Bacardi Cup was won by Harry Nye's Gale of the Southern Lake Michigan fleet when she was first over the finish line this morning to accumulate a total of 41 points for the three races. Her time was 1 hour 40 minutes 20 seconds. Walter Etzbach acted as crew.

Of the 58,696 relief workers dropped from WPA rolls here in July and August under the eighteen-months continuous employment clause, 7,808 or 13.3 per cent had found jobs in private industry by November, it was disclosed yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.

After a sharp dispute yesterday between Mayor La Guardia and the Democratic majority in the City Council, the Mayor's bills reorganizing the pension systems of the Police and Fire Departments were adopted by unanimous vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Securities and Exchange Commission approved conditionally today a revision of the capital structure of the Philadelphia Company, probably the most profitable subholding company in the Standard Gas and Electric system, but not without warning of the eventual necessity for corporate simplification along the lines laid down in Section 11, the "death sentence" provision, of the Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--The office of the Dies Committee issued a statement tonight saying that a witness had admitted at a secret committee session that he forged letters purporting to connect Representative Dies with the Silver Shirt Legion.

Registration of passenger and commercial automobiles in New York City for 1946 is running about 37,500 ahead of the corresponding period of last year, it was reported yesterday by I. James Brody, Deputy State Motor Vehicle Commissioner.

LONDON, Jan. 30--Britain's reply to Chancellor Hitler's speech tonight was swift and bitter. In the opinion of the Foreign Office it was a remarkable combination of bad history and bad manners, an inferior imitation of his own tirades in the past.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP)--Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant approved today transfer of the reorganization proceedings of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its chief subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, from the Northern to Southern New York District.

The close of business today will mark the end of the period allowed by the city for deposit of the required 90 per cent of the collateral securities of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Rapid Transit Corporation in the city's plan to acquire the lines for unified municipal operation.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 (U.P.)--The Propaganda Ministry offers to tell foreign correspondents all about the war, but will show them nothing.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Establishment of a State mortgage board which would handle mortgage moratorium cases from the present time until July 1, 1946, was proposed in a bill sponsored in the Senate today by Lazarus Joseph, Democrat, of the Bronx.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 30-- Donald Lamont Brown, president of the United Aircraft Corporation, who died yesterday at a New York hospital, was buried here this afternoon in Cedar Hill Cemetery. The funeral services were held at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church, which was filled with friends from Hartford, New York, Washington and other cities.
WITH THE FRENCH ARMIES, IN THE FIELD, Jan. 30--At the front now every soldier and regimental officer displays a badge in addition to the insignia indicating his arm of the service.

LONDON, Jan. 30--In the air over the narrow strip of open water along the British east coast a series of battles was fought today between British fighter planes and German bombers which rained explosives on ships entering and leaving harbors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--President Roosevelt told Congress today that "the most elementary health needs are not being met" in many rural areas and requested an appropriation of from $7,500,000 to $10,000,000 for building fifty hospitals under the supervision of the Public Health Service as a modest beginning in improving present conditions.

Registration of out-of-town buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered well below the preceding week, and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Last week the arrivals were 947 as against 1,435 in the previous week and 1,025 in the same period last year. Visiting buyers reported yesterday totaled 361 which compared with 644 listed a week ago.

Steeplechasing at the Belmont Park Spring meeting, took on a rosy's hue yesterday with the announcement that the Westchester Racing Association and the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association had completed arrangements increasing the total added value of the cross-country stakes from $10,000 to $14,500.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--President Roosevelt's fifty-eighth birthday was the occasion of a celebration here today which began well before noon and continued far into the night.

Mr. Shaw is not improving in his playwriting. In "Geneva," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening, he makes logic and wisdom about great matters very difficult to listen to. It is his fiftieth play, first produced at the Malvern Festival in 1938 in another era before war broke out.

Nearly every financial institution, contractor and building material manufacturer operating in the New York district has received this week from the Federal Housing Administration a copy of the expanded program for FHA insurance on allyear homes costing $2,500 or less.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30-- Claudette Colbert will be featured in "Reap the Wild Wind" by Thelma Strabel, which was purchased last week by Paramount. Miss Colbert will be seen as Loxie, the tempestuous heroine in the story of piracy off the Florida Keys during the early nineteenth century.

The New York Americans signalized Eddie Shore's debut with their team by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal, 4 to 1, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The accomplishment was no great one, though, for the Canadiens had lost six of their seven previous games, with only a tie in the other.

The British public prefers Neville Chamberlain to Winston Churchill as Prime Minister and favors less strict blackout conditions, according to surveys being made by the British Institute of Public Opinion.

Because American business today is not actively going into the capital market to raise new funds for expansion some writers have drawn the strange conclusion that American industry today does not "need" new capital. This is a fatal error. It assumes that there is a sufficient supply of new capital when there is merely a shrunken demand for it.

A report on how American contributions had helped in the evacuation of an additional 45,000 refugees in Lappish Finland was received yesterday by Herbert Hoover at headquarters of the Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., 420 Lexington Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30--While liquidation and stop loss selling caused an early decline of about 1 cent a bushel in wheat futures today, the selling did not come up to expectations. JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 30-- Ralph W. Fistere, industrial secretary of the Y.M.C.A. here, president of the Industrial Secretaries Association of the United States and Canada and president of the National Association of Secretaries, died of a heart attack at his home in Jersey City this morning at the age of 51.

PAINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31-- Professor Edward Gleason Spaulding, a member of the faculty in philosophy at Princeton University for thirty-five years and a prominent writer and lecturer, died at noon today in Princeton Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 66 years old.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, reminded taxpayers last night that there "is no back door to the Secretary's office" and that his department conducts an "incessant and never-ending fight" to run down fraud and eliminate illegal tax evasion.

BELLMORE, L.I., Feb. 2--A third of the nearly 1,200 students at Wellington C. Mepham High School here were dismissed an hour earlier than usual this afternoon and were taken in buses and automobiles to thirteen churches in Bellmore, North Bellmore and Merrick for religious instruction.

Mann, director of the National Zoological Park of the Smithsonian Institution.

Glenn Cunningham has reached the question mark stage. His victories are no longer taken for granted, and hence a capacity crowd of 16,000 will assemble at the ever-spectacular Millrose A.A. carnival in Madison Square Garden tonight to see if the Old Master can win another Wanamaker Mile.

Jussi Bjoerling, the Swedish tenor, celebrated his twenty-ninth birthday last night by appearing in recital at the Town Hall. He observed the occasion as an artist should, singing with taste, discrimination and honest musicianship. It was, in truth, a song recital, not an opera singer's holiday.

Not four horsemen of destruction but nine ride today's world, former President Herbert Hoover said last night in outlining the role the United States must play if catastrophe is to be averted.

The stock market yesterday broke out of its six consecutive days of weakening prices, but the fact that the upturn came on the eve of the week-end brought on late selling which eliminated a good share of the gains.

H.R. Reeve, sturdy Bayside Tennis Club star, and E.A. Mays Jr. of the Harvard Club yesterday reached the final round in the Monte Sterling Trophy tournament, one of the year's outstanding squash tennis events. The tourney is annually held at the New York Athletic Club.

Thomas Jefferson High's undefeated basketball team extended its string to eleven games when it routed Brooklyn Tech by 42--16 in a Section 1, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. battle on the Jefferson floor yesterday. The victory was the seventh in league play for the Jefferson representatives, who led by 20--7 at the half.
After the highest opening since the break of ten days ago, prices on the Cotton Exchange held to within a narrow range yesterday and ended unchanged to 7 point higher than on Thursday.

The five-story garage at 329-33 East Twenty-first Street has been sold by the Wintown Realty Company, Max Rosenberg, president, to the East Twenty-first Street Realty Corporation, A. Cari, president. It is on a plot 75 by 100 feet and has a setback above the second story.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)--Acting Chairman Starnes of the Dies Committee tonight cleared four members of the House of any "collusion" or "concerted action" to abolish the committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2-- Many dinners were given tonight before the Romany Chorus' production of Gilbert and Sullivan's "H.M.S. Pinafore," which was presented at the Bath and Tennis Club, where seats filled the patio surrounding the pool in which the ship floated.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2--Rodin, a 4year-old whose underpinning is none too stalwart, was sent out by the veteran Frank J. Kearns so fit and ready today that he eked out victory in the Winter Haven Claiming Handicap, main event on Hialeah's program.

The discovery of the cause, prevention and cure of a serious and prevalent form of hitherto incurable blindness, affecting thousands of young and old, is announced in the current issue of Public Health Reports, published by the United States Public Health Service.

The work of Vocational Adoption, Inc., in placing orphaned boys and girls in employment was commended yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt with the suggestion that the activity might be extended throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Congressional economy drive rolled over President Roosevelt himself tonight when the House passed and sent to the Senate the $722,000,000 Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill, $66,900,000 below the "bedrock" estimates in the budget message of Jan. 4.

HAVANA, Feb. 2--The American yacht Gale, sailed by Harry Nye Jr., representing the Southern Lake Michigan fleet, was first across the finish line today in 1 hour 43 minutes 17 seconds to win the Cuba Cup in the fourteenth international Star Class series. Gale's score in the trophy competition was 24 points, made by winning all three races.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (UP)--A Russian promise that "the Finnish bandits will be destroyed and exterminated," taken from an editorial in the official Communist organ Pravda, was broadcast today by the Moscow radio.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Based on a test of the retail buying mood by the apparel and giftware shows opening hire this week, observers look for the Chicago Spring Market, beginning Monday, to show small gains over last year in the number of buyers registered and a fairly substantial increase in dollar sales totals.
LONDON, Feb. 2--Incomplete reports of unrest on the Northwest Indian frontier, with disorders at Waziristan, and the arrest in Bombay of seven foreigners reached London today.

BERLIN, Feb. 2--All indications are that the Balkan countries do not wish to embark on any new course, the end of which would be unpredictable, writes the Diplomatisch-Politische Korrespondenz on the occasion of the Balkan Entente meeting.

Offerings of new bonds to the public this week were restricted to three State and municipal loans aggregating only $5,340,000, the smallest volume for any period since the week ended Nov. 10, last, when $2,392,000 in new bonds were marketed.

"Das Rheingold" opened the special matinee Wagner cycle yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House and the performance was a happy augury for the remainder of the series. For the presentation was admirably fused in the dramatic and scenic sense and Mr. Leindorf conducted one of the best readings he has given.

TOKYO, Feb. 2.--Details of the arrest of James R. Young of Springfield, Ill., correspondent of the International News Service, on charges of spreading slanderous rumors regarding the Japanese forces in China were disclosed today by Yakichiro Suma, spokesman of the Japanese Foreign Office.

Strong opposition to the proposed air academy at La Guardia Field came yesterday from Board of Education officials, who disclosed that they had already completed plans for a $470,000 public aviation school on the grounds.
Nine young men were ordained as Roman Catholic priests by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday morning at a low mass at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Joseph Meyerrose, former Sheriff of Queens and in the early Nineteen Hundreds prominent in Queens Democratic politics, died yesterday at his home, 83-23 116th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, after a brief illness. He was born on a farm in what is now the Ridgewood section of Queens on May 12, 1859.

Edwin T. Rice, assistant treasurer, trustee and member of the board of directors since its organization of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, died suddenly of a heart attack late yesterday afternoon while attending a committee meeting at the society's offices in Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street. He would have been 78 years old tomorrow.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made the presentation of $100 prizes to four newspaper women for professional achievement during 1939 at the eighteenth annual party of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, called the Front Page Ball, held on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

A tale of continuous extortion that covered a period of more than six years was told in General Sessions Court yesterday by Aaron Held, officer of the United Flour Trucking Company, who took the witness stand as the first prosecution witness against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and three co-defendants charged with running a racket in the flour and baking industry.

The Rockefeller interests are paying about $60,000 annually in city realty taxes for the right to maintain as a private thoroughfare the three-block street that runs north and south through the heart of Rockefeller Center, a study of the city's new property assessment rolls revealed yesterday.

An amended plan of reorganization of the Auburn Automobile Company, approved by the Federal Court at Fort Wayne, Ind., and by committees representing the different securities and principal creditors, has been forwarded to holders of securities by the company.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP)--Dr. Arnold Volpe, founder of the New York Stadium Concerts and conductor of orchestras in Washington, Kansas City and Miami, died today at the age of 70 after an illness of several months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--A fight was developing in Congress today against the new Commerce Department program of asking monthly reports on inventories from a large "cross-section" of the American manufacturing industry. Leading Republicans and Democrats in both houses assailed the undertaking as an impediment to business or "another blow against free enterprise."

After an ownership of nearly half a century, George H. Fletcher has sold to Charles O. Banks, organist of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, the three-story residence at 214 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn. The new owner plans to alter the building for use as a music studio. Charles E. Rickerson was the broker.

The light of free speech is indispensable to the maintenance of free institutions, speakers declared last night at a dinner of the board of trustees of Town Hall, where plans to raise $1,500,000 by 1944 for revitalizing public discussion of national issues and completing the building of Town Hall as a national discussion center were made public.

The Press Photographers Association of New York, Inc., held a preview yesterday afternoon of its fifth annual exhibition of press photography on the fourth floor of the Empire State Building. It will be open to the public from Monday to Feb. 24, from 10 A.M. to. 10 P.M., except Sundays.
LONDON, Feb. 2--The French Embassy in London delivered to the Foreign Office today a diplomatic document purporting to be an authentic neutral report of German atrocities in Poland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Roundlot trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 13 was 4,633,300 shares, compared with 3,808,250 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The city of Newport, R.I., will be in the market on Feb. 20 with an issue of $3,100,000 of water bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 2 per cent. The bonds, dated March 1, 1940, will mature serially from 1941 to 1971 and are to be payable from water revenues. Also they are backed by the general credit of the city.

Melio Bettina had his revenge last night in Madison Square Garden. Before a crowd of 12,369 persons who paid $33,218 for the return battle between the former light-heavyweight champion and Fred Apostoli, once ruler of the middleweight class, Bettina knocked out Apostoli --and ended the Californian's ring career.

Sir John Simon's statement in the House of Commons regarding the prevention of inflation in Great Britain indicates that the British Government has become concerned about this problem.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2-- Hugh Herbert will be featured by Universal in "La Conga Nights," in which the actor will play six roles, all the principal parts. Paul Gerard Smith has been working for some months on the script, and it will go before the cameras on Feb. 12, with Lew Landers directing. Herbert will play himself, four sisters and a mother.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Larger unemployment insurance benefits, urged by the leadership of both the A.F.L. and C.I.O., were endorsed today by the Social Security Board.

The Grace Line has agreed to buy from the Maritime Commission three fast new cargo ships for the company's Pacific coast freight service, it was announced yesterday by Fred L. Doelker, vice president and Pacific coast manager of the line, who is here to confer with other officials.

The F.W. Woolworth Company and its Canadian subsidiary showed a net profit of $29,310,353 after deductions fur depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes, interest, foreign exchange loss and other charges, according to the annual statement for 1939, made public yesterday.

Earl Russell Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, won the right yesterday to have his name appear on the ballot in the special election in the Fourteenth Congressional District. Both the Supreme Court and the Board of Elections refused to bar him.

Mass., Feb. 2--Dartmouth assumed first place in the ski meet that opened the annual Winter sports carnival at Williams College today when Jack Tobin won the downhill race, negotiating Thunderbolt Trail down Mount Greylock in less than 3 minutes. GUAYMAS, Sonora, Mexico, Feb. 2 (AP)--General Francisco Manzo, exiled from Mexico after leading rebel troops in the Escobar revolution of 1929, died here yesterday. When President Lazaro Cardenas took office he allowed General Manzo to return to this country.

The City Tax Commission probably did not expect its announcement of tentative real estate valuations for the next year to be received with satisfaction, and they have not been. Total valuations are about $3,300,000,000 below the 1931 peak.

The 1939-40 debutante season was brought to a close last night when the third and last of the Junior Assemblies of this Winter was given in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton. The dance was held on its traditional date, the first Friday in February.

LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 4--Motorboat racers shattered three competitive world records today in Lakeland's annual regatta.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 4-- Henry R. Barrett, this city's "first citizen" and for the last twenty-two years secretary of the Westchester Republican County Committee, died suddenly of a heart attack shortly after noon today in his home at 33 North Broadway.

PARIS, Feb. 4--On the Western Front the outposts seem to be reverting to the activity that ruled before Arctic weather came as a paralyzing factor. Several German raiding parties, for instance, attempted to surprise French posts today, but they were driven off by machine-gun fire.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4--Samuel Matthews Vauclain died shortly after noon today at Broadlawn, his Rosemont home, of a heart attack at the age of 83.

Mayor La Guardia sternly declined yesterday to grant "a little boy in the Bronx" amnesty from taking a bath because of the water shortage, officially decreeing that, come what may, the neck and behind the ears of every child in the city must be scrubbed clean.

Domestic cotton prices last week moved within a narrow range in relatively light trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange active oldtype futures contracts registered net declines of 2 to 8 points, while new-type contracts were 2 points up to 7 points down.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Total retail sales in the United States in 1939 were about $37,950,000,000, a gain of $2,500,000,000, or 7 per cent over 1938, the Department of Commerce reported today.
