In an attempt to get well-informed, cultured teachers into the New York City school system, the board of examiners will broaden the scope of the tests for teaching licenses to include general information in addition to spcialized subject matter, Dr. William A. Han-...

CHICAGO, Feb. 6--With attendance estimated at 8 to 10 per cent ahead of last year by Paul W. Kunning of the Chicago Association of Commerce staff, Spring market week events here developed a better momentum than anticipated on its second day.
Too many sales executives consider advertising as entirely automatic salesmanship and place the entire burden of moving goods on advertising alone, John W. Hubbell,...

TOKYO, Feb. 6 (AP)--A leader of Nationalist elements in Parliament tonight bitterly denounced as "obsequious diplomacy" the Japanese Government's attempt to appease the United States by announcing a plan to reopen the lower Yangtze River in China to international trade.
Realizing the need for the recodification and clarification of the rules and regulations that have been governing baseball for more than three decades, the National

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6-- George Brent was named today by Warners for the male lead opposite Merle Oberon in "The House on the Hill," an adaptation of Somerset Maugham's "The Villa on the Hill," which will go before the...

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 6--Justus A.B. Cowles, retired New York lawyer, former president of the Pejepscot Paper Manufacturing Company in Maine and former village president of Rye, died here today at his Home after a two years' illness. His age was 78.

ROME, Feb. 6--Pope Pius has sent a letter in his own handwriting to Jean Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, which is taken in Vatican circles as an indication that he considers France to be fighting for civilization against German Nazi paganism, it was learned today. The letter was sent on the occasion of the tenth anniversary of Cardinal Verdier's elevation.
The concert given by Artur Rodzinski and the Cleveland Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall gathered a big audience and was accompanied by exceptional enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--President Roosevelt returned to the White House today from a weekend visit at Hyde Park to assume personal command over the Administration effort to head off drastic cuts in his budget estimates. He warned in a statement at Hyde Park yesterday that these cuts might hate unfortunate results for the nation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--In order to avoid involvement in the political campaign, the Temporary National Economic Committee will not issue its final report until late in November or December, Senator O'Mahoney, chairman of the committee announced today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6-- Grizzled men, who remembered the escapades of their spirited student days, gathered tonight at Harvard's historic Memorial Hall in tribute to Charles Robert (Charley) Apted, veteran chief of the Harvard "yard cops," who had been the Paul Revere of many a midnight ride to rescue them from trouble.

The fortune of Edward Stephen Harkness, railroad financier, by his will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, will go to charitable and educational institutions after the death of his widow, the former Mary E. Stillman. He directed that Mrs. Harkness hold the property in trust for life.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 (AP)--The Belgian General Staff announced today that soldiers would receive an extra five days on their leaves if they were getting married.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6--Plans for a nation-wide organizing drive among white-collar workers and in miscellaneous industries, with special emphasis on the South, were announced here today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor. The council hopes to bring into the fold by October 500,000 workers in "fields which have hitherto resisted unionization." Hundreds of local and county affiliates will cooperate in the campaign.

Sir Louis Beale, Commissioner General in charge of the British exhibit at the World's Fair, has rented an apartment at 3 East Sixtyninth Street. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., negotiated the lease.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that on Feb. 15 it would offer for sale $33,000,000 of general and refunding fourth series 3 per cent bonds due in 1976.

CRACOW, German-Held Poland, Feb. 6--German authorities are exercising all measures possible to increase the agricultural productivity of the former Polish territory. A central agricultural bureau has been established with control over all farms larger than 247 acres.

SOMETHING should be done about misleading book titles. This ready reader long ago reg istered a complaint against Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars of the Bronx Zoo, author of a book entitled "Snakes of the World."

ROME, Feb. 6--Mail from the American ship Excambion, which left New York on Jan. 6, is just arriving in Rome, having been held by the British censors in Gibraltar for about three weeks. It was brought here by the Manhattan, for...

PARIS, Feb. 6--News reached Paris via Rome tonight of nervousness in the Near East, with Iran and Afghanistan taking military precautions in the expectation of a Russo-German drive toward the Persian Gulf. Italians are very interested in the Near and Middle East, and their observations are considered here as generally accurate. There is significance, therefore, in the conclusion reached in this Italian dispatch, namely:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The Department of Justice has granted as of Jan. 31 a ninety-day continuance of the Federal anti-trust action against the Postal Telegraph and Western Union companies, officials revealed today.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 6 (AP)--Japanese military spokesmen today announced that their northern forces had penetrated Ningsia Province, in far Northwest China, for the the first time since the war started.

BERLIN, Feb. 6--Following Chancellor Hitler's last speech, in which he characterized the present war as a social conflict between rich, predatory and hypocritical democracies and great nations that had been cheated of their share of the world,

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, took issue yesterday with President Roosevelt's opinion as to the fiscal position of the nation, charging that the President was "nine billion dollars wrong" in his calculation of the national financial status.

The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday through its New York City attorneys that it would contest the order of the National Labor Relations Board directing the company to refrain from "disparaging" or "criticizing" labor organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The War Department plans, if Congressional approval is forthcoming, to recall into active service about 300 retired officers to serve as instructors in next Summer's R.O.T.C. camps, it was learned today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 6-- The newspaper Pester Lloyd makes a hostile editorial comment on the Balkan conference today and, since the close relations of the paper to the Hungarian Foreign Ministry are known, this might be accepted as an indication of the official Hungarian reaction.

Miss Unity Freeman-Mitford, the pro-German daughter of Lord Redesdale who was brought home to England several weeks ago suffering from bullet wounds received in the Reich, did not inflict the wounds herself, in the opinion of her uncle, Captain John FreemanMitford, who arrived here on business yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Lancastria.

Appointment of the Securities and Exchange Commission as trustee in the reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company was recommended to Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday by a representative of the Treasury Department.

The directors of the LibbeyOwens-Ford Glass Company authorized yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for the first quarter of this year, payable on March l5, to stock of record on Feb. 29.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 7-- Despite a new series of bombings attributed to the Irish Republican Army and appeals for clemency from both Ireland and Great Britain, two men convicted of the I.R. A. bomb plot of last August, when five persons were killed in Coventry, were executed this morning.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 (AP)--A woman who said she was his commonlaw wife caused postponement for several hours today of the marriage of Ludwig Lewisohn, author, and Miss Edna Manley by rushing into Har Sinai Temple Center with her 6-year-old son and declaring "this wedding must not take place."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)-- Charles Stewart Mott, former vice president and largest single stockholder of the General Motors Corporation, has given shares valued at more than S5,200,000 to a trust established for his wife and two children.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--The intention of the legislative leaders to move with speed after next week's hearing on the State budget was manifested today when they arranged to consider the next most important problem, enactment of a parimutuel enabling act. A hearing on pari-mutuel legislation was set for Feb. 26, two weeks after the budget hearing.

A modest improvement in prices spread over a broad front in more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market seemed to gain some encouragement from the moderate rise in stocks and, although the im

Real estate deals are being made almost daily in Manhattan in which the purchase price is well below the assessed valuation, and the fact that a buyer may pay less than the figure carried on the city's tax books ordinarily no longer constitutes startling news.

BOMBAY, Feb. 6 (UP)--Mohandas K. Gandhi, Indian Nationalist leader, said today that Great Britain and the Indian Nationalist Congress would never settle their dispute until Britain allowed India to determine her own constitutional status.

ROME, Feb. 6--Pope Pius XII, in his capacity of Bishop of Rome, this morning received about seventy Lenten preachers in the churches and monasteries of the city and all the parish priests of Rome, deliver

ALBANY, Feb. 6--The New York State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance, in its annual report to the Legislature today, declared the Federal Social Security Board was trying to use "the power of the purse-strings" to encroach on administration of the State Unemployment Insurance Act.

PARIS, Feb. 6--Yesterday's meeting of the Allied Supreme War Council in Paris is described as the most important yet held, but wherein its importance lies is being kept as secret here as is the date of Chancellor Hitler's offensive.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6--Wheat dipped fractionally in the early trading today, but the market turned upward on short covering induced by firmness in securities, sales of 200,000 barrels of flour by Southwestern mills to a chain bakery and relative strength in Winnipeg.

The greenkeepers, those unsung heroes of golf who make life livable for the three to four million followers of the ancient and honorable game in this country, began their annual meeting yesterday, the...
Some one said, "On the fourthfloor at 1 East Forty-second Street you will find divers Valentines ancient and new, and a man who knows the Valentine legends."

Representative Shannon of Blue Springs, Mo., took occasion of the issue of a commemorative stamp in honor of Mark Twain to stamp hard upon the military record of that most illustrious of Missourians. Mr. Shannon said that Mark, after his first battle, started to run and didn't stop until he got to Keokuk.
OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press)--The total deficit in government financing for the fiscal year ended on March 31 last was $50,891,744, or about $5,000,000 less than...

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 6 --A $130,000,000 advertising campaign to sell to the American people "its active self-interest in keeping at peace" was suggested by Paul Hollister, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., in an address at Williams College here today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6--Fines aggregating $54,150 were imposed today by Federal Judge F.P. Schoonmaker upon fifty-seven electrical contractors, union leaders and corporations who had pleaded no defense to charges that they conspired to defraud the government on PWA electrical costs.
Visiting buyers reported in the market for the week ended yesterday fell below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Two large apartments at the northern end of Manhattan, one in the old Fort George section and the other in Inwood, figured in the realty deals yesterday.

M. Michael Edelstein, Tammany District Leader and firm advocate of the New Deal, was elected a member of the House of Representatives from Manhattan's Fourteenth Congressional District yesterday in a special election by an overwhelming margin.

Italy made war so willingly on Ethiopia and Albania that at first sight it may seem strange to see her in the role of peacemaker in the Balkans. Her past adventures are, however, the most convincing explanation of her present prudence.
Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey is expected to issue a statement today. He has been asked to do so, it appears, by members of...
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 7--The high point in New Zealand's centenary celebration was reached yesterday with the re-enactment of the landing of the first Governor, Captain William Hobson,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The special House committee which has been investigating the National Labor Relations Board decided today to ask the House for a second $50,000 appropriation to continue the inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)-- Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, in charge of anti-trust enforcement, told the Supreme Court today that an effort by Midwestern oil companies to raise prices constituted "an attempt to set up the NRA again without control."
Gross sales of the National Biscuit Company increased last year to $98,078,477 from $97,486,877 in 1938, according to the preliminary annual report released today.

General Virgilio Caccini who, in 1910-14, constructed the fortifications facing France on the eastern side of the Maritime Alps and Graian, died at Messina, Sicily, on Jan. 27, it has just been learned here.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Reb. 6-- The tax rate in this city will be increased from $48.38, to $53.13 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, it was predicted today by Mayor Frank Hague after the 1940 budget was introduced in the City Commission and tentatively approved. The budget totals $44,315,002, an increase of $1,511,466 over last year.

LENOX, Mass., Feb. 6--Miss Mary Parsons of New York and Lenox, a leader in the social, civic and charitable life of this place, died today of pneumonia at Stonover, her home, after being ill for two weeks. She would have been 78 years old on Feb. 21.

PARIS, Feb. 6--An American field ambulance service for the Polish Army in France is to be formed soon by a group of young Americans headed by Princess Hohenlohe and her brother, Theodore Schulze, stepchildren of the United States Ambassador to Poland, Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) --A plea either to conduct intercollegiate athletics without subsidizing and proselyting or to frankly pay athletes for their services was sounded over an international chain of short-wave broadcasting stations tonight by William J. Bingham, Harvard athletic director.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 6--Paul V. McNutt, a Democrat, and Thomas E. Dewey, a Republican, "are probably the best dressed men in the political arena," the Merchant Tailors and Designers Association decided today at its national convention.

Production of steel in January amounted to 5,017,588 gross tons of open hearth and bessemer ingots, a decline of 3 per cent from the output of 5,164,420 tons in December, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Right Rev. Mgr. Robert J. Byer, pastor of St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Union City, N.J., for the last twentyseven years, died today at the age of 71 in Memorial Hospital here after a long illness.

The marriage of Miss Zorah White, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. White of 1,095 Park Avenue to Charles A. Gristede, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gristede of this city and Truesdale Lake, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of Sherry's. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Patrick F. O'Connor, rector of the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King, the Bronx.

LONDON, Feb. 6--Prime Minister Chamberlain announced today in the House of Commons a partial settlement with Japan in the dispute over a British cruiser's seizing of twenty-one Germans from the liner Asama Maru Jan. 21.

Some 100 new creations in Spring daytime frocks, spectator sportswear, sports apparel and uniforms, all by American designers, were presented by the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.
LONDON, Feb. 6--The stock markets today enjoyed a moderately good session which was enlivened by activity in heavy industrials on news of an increase in the armaments program.
William F, Moore, senior partner in William F. Moore Co., will be entertained tomorrow at dinner by his Wall Street associates and friends at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn.

The Department of Justice pressed yesterday its policy of invoking the Sherman anti-trust law against labor unions with the announcement here that an investigation into the electrical equipment industry was being undertaken.

Charges of fraud against three present and two former officers of a once-prosperous $3,000,000 investment trust are contained in a suit by Attorney General Bennett to liquidate the now insolvent corporation, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 6--With government assistance the race tracks of the Paris region have been reopening this year and racing fans and society have been turning out for the Winter meetings at Vincennes with much enthusiasm.
A thick, murky fog, described as the heaviest in several years, last night delayed ferryboats--and indirectly trains--and slowed traffic on city streets and the highways of the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Feb. 6--Food Minister W.S. Morrison announced today that fresh meat would be added to the list of rationed foods which already include sugar, butter and ham and bacon. The meat ration will become effective March 11.

MINEOLA, L.I., Wednesday Feb. 7--A verdict of guilty of manslaughter in the first degree was returned this morning against Alvin J. Dooley, suspended Long Beach patrolman, who was on trial for the slaying of Mayor Louis F. Edwards of Long Beach in county court here.
Mrs. John C. Prizer of Chestnut Hill, Pa., reached the semi-final round of the Junior League's tenth annual invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday with three triumphs.
Eight seconds after the start of play, the Detroit Red Wings had a goal against the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night.
Securities and commodities markets moved higher yesterday as technical factors permitted stocks to break out of their rut under the leadership of the steel issues.
"Two on an Island" will be moving Feb. 19 from the Broadhurst to the Hudson. The Group Theatre's "Night Music," which originally was headed for the Plymouth, will open at the Broadhurst Feb. 22.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, was re-elected yesterday at the organization's annual meeting at 11 Broadway. R.J. Baker, secretary and treasurer, and John J. Burns, general counsel, were also renamed, as were the ten directors of the board.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Feb. 6 --No one, to date, has accused Joe Louis of being short of artillery, but the Brown Bomber, nevertheless, is developing a new cannon for the fireworks display with which he is planning to entertain Arturo Godoy in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

The report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company for 1939, which is being forwarded today to shareholders, shows net earnings applicable to the company's capital stock, after all charges, of $2,304,826, compared with $2,261,130 in...

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6--Despite the warning from Commissioner Lithgow Osborne that the future of trout fishing in this State would be endangered if the sportsmen would not agree to a reduction in the creel limit and open season this year,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Part of the President's statistical defense at Hyde Park of the record of the New Deal suggests that he was again fresh from a triumph over the "business man"-- sometimes the "publisher"--who comes to see him occasionally, walking in like Tom Dewey and out like Henry Mor

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6-- Mrs. Peytoa Van Rensselaer entertained with a tea and cocktail party today at her villa. Many of the younger set were among her guests. Those honored were Princesses Francesca and Camilla Rospigliosi, the Misses Lillian and Isabelle Manger, and Mrs. John R. Drexel Jr., who is visiting Mrs. Van Rensselaer.

The fifty-ninth annual fatherand-son drill of the Knickerbocker Greys was staged in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon with all the stir and color of military pageantry.

Mayor La Guardia suggested yesterday that music take a lesson from baseball and that the Philharmonic Symphony Society set up a musical minor league where talent could be developed for the Philharmonic in the manner that baseball teams build up their players through a system of "farm" clubs.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Feb. 7 (UP)--The Apostolic delegation announced early today that Pope Pius XII has elevated the Right Rev. Monsignor Joseph M. Corrigan, Rector of Catholic University, to the episcopacy as titular Bishop of Bilta.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)--The Miami (Fla.) resort area was described to Congress by J. Edgar Hoover today as an underworld mecca for "vicious hoodlums" who operate without interference from local authorities.

Tammany Hall will make public today the make-up of an uninstructed delegation of twenty-two which it proposes to send to the Democratic National Convention to be hold in Chicago at an undetermined date to select party candidates for President and Vice President.
Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C. successfully began the defense of his honors in the opening round of the annual Whitehall Club invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday.

The World's Fair of 1940 was hailed yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, as a much-needed common meeting ground where Americans can exchange ideas and work out plans for world peace along sound economic lines.

The beginning of the penitential season of Lent will be observed today at Ash Wednesday services in churches of many denominations throughout the city. The services will open the series of Lenten devotions to be held daily or weekly, according to the custom of each denomination, until Easter.
MIAMI, Fla. Feb. 6--Jockey Don Meade, hero of the hour at Hialeah Park in 1939, was soundly booed today after he had won with W.H. Berri's Broad Vision on the grass course.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6--A new scale of rations for Canadian troops, far exceeding anything previously sanctioned, was announced by Norman Rogers, Minister of Defense, today. It includes fresh milk, eggs, fish, fresh vegetables, raw apples and a wider variety of meats.

Slashes in marine war risk insurance rates on imports from England were announced here yesterday by insurance underwriters. The cuts, ranging from 50 cents to $1 a $100 on cargo valuation go into effect today.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 (UP)--Federal agents moved again today in the government's campaign to crush subversive activities, arresting twelve reputed Communists and fellow-travelers who are accused of recruiting soldiers for the Spanish Republican Army.

The Thomas Jefferson H.S. basketball team routed Bushwick, 75 to 17, on the Jefferson court in a Section 1, Brooklyn Group, game of the P.S.A.L. yesterday. This was the eighth victory in as many loop starts for the pace-setting victors.

The late Alexander Hamilton, who took such a lively interest in The New York Post 139 years ago, wouldn't know his favorite newspaper in its new dress. Neither would he have known it in its old dress. Times change, and the policies as well as the appearance...

A small majority of persons questioned in a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, favors a United States governmental loan to Finland to purchase non-military supplies, according to a statement released yesterday by the institute. For years John B. Campbell, racing secretary and official handicapper for the New York tracks, has, at the close of the season, rated the 2-year-olds, then about to become 3-year-olds.

The good old Aldermanic custom of spending part of the Winter in Florida saw a rebirth yesterday when the Democrats in control of the City Council decided to lay aside their legislative cares for a month or so to provide a vacation interlude.

The former Frederick S. Wheeler estate, consisting of ten acres of land with a thirteen-room dwelling on Forest Avenue, Rye, Westchester County, occupied for the past seven years by the Noble School, has been purchased by a group of New York investors, J.W. Frost,

A new series of symphonic concerts at prices that compare favorably with neighborhood movie scales was launched last night at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project. The orchestra was the New York City Symphony, with Georg Sebastian conducting and Adolf Busch the violin soloist. Mr. Sebastian and Mr. Busch contributed their services.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 6 --Home Run King Jimmy Foxx of the Red Sox insisted today that the Sox won't toss in the towel when they meet the Yankees.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--Holding that the American Student Union by its recent actions had shown itself to be a "Communist Front organization," Senator Martin, Syracuse Republican, today introduced in the Senate a resolution calling upon the Boards of Education and Higher Education in New York City to refuse to permit the organization to use school buildings for meetings.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 6--Bradley Tech got the jump on Manhattan's basketball team tonight and steadily increased the margin to register a 57-to-35 triumph.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is expected to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission within the next week or so a registration statement covering the proposed issuance of approximately $102,000,000 of new refunding bonds.

While a crowd of 100 or more persons looked on last night, Miss Cecelia Ritchie, 23 years old, disarmed a hold-up man in a Times Square shop and with Miss Clara Kranichfeld, also 23, held him until the police arrived.
The mood of the approaching Spring as it will be expressed in women's fashions in new day and evening clothes laid emphasis on gay costumes and floral accessories yesterday when B. Altman...

A high-ranking military officer and a senior Federal judge joined yesterday in calling for an army, navy and air force "flexible and adequate enough to meet any emergency" and to prevent any possible invasion of the Western Hemisphere.

Former President Herbert Hoover will be guest of honor tonight at the "Help Finland Cabaret," which will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Finnish Relief Fund, of which Mr. Hoover is national chairman. Mrs. George B. St. George, executive chairman of tonight's benefit entertainment, will give a dinner for Mr. Hoover in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf before the event.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,498,800 barrels, a decline of 112,800 from the 3,611,600 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The figures which Mr. Roosevelt gave to the newspaper correspondents at Hyde Park on Monday are offered as a defense of the spending policies of his Administration. They show the gains which have been made toward recovery since he took office. Comparing 1939 with 1932, national income has increased by 71 per cent. Farm income has risen 82 per cent. Dividends are up 55 per cent. Exports, 97 per cent. Industrial production, 64 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Representative Frank E. Hook, Democrat of Michigan, apologized to the House today for inserting in The Congressional Record letters tending to link Chairman Dies of the Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities with the Silver Shirts and the Christian Front.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 6-- With bitter memories of a war boom that boomeranged twenty years ago, business and civic leaders are trying to discourage boom psychology in this busy industrial capital of Connecticut today, but are welcoming a rush of orders for war materials and general industrial products that are rapidly bringing back prosperity.
Strength in the guilder and the Cuban peso featured an otherwise dull foreign exchange market yesterday.

Prizes were announced yesterday for the annual combined exhibition of the New York Water Color Club and the American Water Color Society, which will open with a private view tomorrow evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition opens to the public Friday and will be current through Feb. 25.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply yesterday to . the highest figures since the decline of two weeks ago and ended with gains of 7 to 14 points.

The board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild, meeting early yesterday morning in Hollywood, appointed a committee consisting of Walter Abel, Lucile Gleason and Noel Madison to review the controversy over "one big actors' union," according to word received at the guild's Eastern office, 545 Fifth Avenue.

The gross volume of all receivables acquired by the Commercial Credit Company during 1939 amounted to $625,868,943, as compared with $524,345,720 for 1938, according to the twenty-eighth consolidated annual report issued by A.E. Duncan, chairman of the...

Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor spent two hours and fifteen minutes yesterday before one of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand juries testifying about his charge that the case of Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, acquitted a week ago of stealing 7,200 police records, had "the smell of a frame-up."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The opposition of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to any amendments to the National Labor Relations Act which would weaken that law for labor was voiced today by Philip Murray, vice president of the C.I.O. and chairman of the Steel Workers' Organizing Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (UP)--British naval authorities announced today that the enemy had sunk eight British ships, totaling 25,069 tons, and six neutral vessels of 17,546 tons in the week ending at midnight Sunday.
Gene Venzke's entry for the classic Baxter Mile, one of the feature events on the program of the New York Athletic Club track meet at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 17, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--President Roosevelt can win the Democratic nomination and break down the third-term tradition, in the opinion of many Democratic leaders who favor drafting him, but members of the Democratic National Committee, many of whom hold the same view, went to the White House today to shake hands with the President and came away having learned nothing from him about his attitude.

In an effort to overcome the unpleasant connotations of motherin-law, parents of this designation, at the second annual meeting yesterday of the Mother-in-Law Association in Saks Thirty-fourth Street store, accepted the term "kinmother."

Metropolitan Opera House employes have given $357.50 to date toward the $1,000,000 which the Metropolitan Opera Fund, under the chairmanship of George A. Sloan, is raising to support and expand the opera as a national music center.
The Grace liner Santa Lucia returned here yesterday from the west coast of South America, and the American Republics liner Uruguay from the east coast. Each ship had 110 passengers.
Long Island University's basketball team will oppose Duquesne in part of a double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight, in the first game of which Fordham will engage City College.

At least twenty-three distinguished Americans who died between 1910 and 1915 will become eligible this year for the first time for nomination to the Hall of Fame on the University Heights campus of New York University when the ballot for the ninth quinquennial election is prepared this Summer.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 (AP)-- The Mardi Gras Handicap, one of the principal races of the Winter meet at the Fair Grounds, was won by Mrs. V. Wyse's Orcades over a muddy track and under unpleasant weather conditions today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The system by which surplus food commodities have been distributed to persons on direct relief will soon be extended to cover cotton goods, Secretary Wallace revealed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Mrs. Roosevelt attended the Navy Relief Ball tonight, having previously entertained sixty-five guests at luncheon at the White House.
The furniture industry was well represented in the business rental activity reported by brokers yesterday when wholesalers and retailers took new quarters or extended their present space.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6--Two metropolitan New York contestants won their first-round matches in the annual women's golf championship of Palm Beach today.

For the second time in three years the International Business Machines Corporation won highest honors in the 1939 State-wide Accident Prevention Campaign conducted by the Associated Industries of New York State, Inc., it was an-...

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 6--Arthur Nelson Macdonald, designer and engraver of bookplates, died early this evening in the Orange Memorial hospital after a long illness. He would have been 74 years old on March 31. His home was at 182 North Seventeenth Street, East Orange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The amended plan for reorganization of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., New York, a Delaware Corporation, as put forward by its trustees, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 6--After a day of rest the Russians unexpectedly and more vigorously than ever before continued their offensive against the Mannerheim Line in the Summa region yesterday. Following violent, night-long artillery fire, Soviet infantry attacked at daybreak, covered by hundreds of tanks.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6--Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, fainted in his bath at Rideau Hall this morning and fell, striking his head against the wall and sustaining a concussion that left him unconscious for an hour. His scalp was cut by the fall, but there was no fracture of the skull.

BERLIN, Feb. 12--All enterprise in warring Germany has been subordinated to the "general welfare" of the nation in its struggle with the Western powers. Even the newspapers have not escaped, for in the effort to conserve the paper supply for other purposes.
BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Feb. 12--Further confirmation of the extent of Germany's defensive measures to protect her communications with Russia was received here tonight.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 12.-- Charles Killgore, president of the New York drug firm of Charles Killgore, Inc., who was an early manufacturer of compressed tablets for the pharmaceutical industry in this country, died today at his home here after a week's illness. His age was 90.
Wire services expect to set a new record tomorrow for transmission of Valentine's Day sentiments, written and crooned. They're counting on heavy Leap Year traffic.
NOTRE DAME, Ind., Feb. 12-- The Rev. Francis T. Wenninger, for the last seventeen years dean of the College of Science at Notre Dame University, died this morning at the age of 51.

LINCOLN'S NEW SALEM, Ill., Feb. 12--In the heart of the restoration of the village where Abraham Lincoln began his public career the government on the 131st anniversary of his birth, re-established today the postoffice he served as postmaster from 1833 to 1836.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16--M. Lewin Hewes, chairman of the board of directors and first president of the Standard Fire Insurance Company and one of the bestknown fire underwriters in the East, died today at his home in this city. His age was 78.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The farm policies of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the "biggest farmer in the United States," were described to the Temporary National Economic Committee this afternoon in a session which ended in such hostility between the ...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 16-- Professor Edward Bliss Reed of Yale University, an outstanding authority on English lyrical poetry, who retired from the faculty several years ago, died last night at his home here. He had been ill of a heart ailment since August.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 16--Dartmouth's basketball team strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by defeating Cornell, 39--36, tonight in a super-defensive game.
Building plans filed yesterday included specifications for an apartment house on the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, to cost $200,000.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 17-- Two Finnish railroad towns north and northeast of Summa, center of the heaviest fighting of the Russian-Finnish undeclared war, were reported by the Leningrad military headquarters to have been captured by Red Army troops yesterday along with twenty-two more Finnish "defensive fortifications."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Representative Smith of Virginia, chair man of the committee investigating the National Labor Relations Board, said today that he hoped the committee would have a preliminary report within two weeks dealing with amendments to the labor act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Licenses were issued to France for the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States valued at $81,572,301.72 during January out of a total of $86,131,664.43 for all countries, according to the monthly report issued by the State Department today.

An East Side taxpayer that had been held at $240,000 passed to new hands yesterday when the Randick Realty Corporation sold the twostory building at 716-18 Lexington Avenue, near the southwest corner of Fifty-eighth Street, to Henry Goelet, operator.

LET those Baxter Mile runners hold back a few minutes. There's a shorter matter that will be noted first. There came to hand recently a small book of verse tastefully set up, bound and illustrated and offered as the combined effort of two young Negroes of considerable talent. The author of the verse was identified as David Wadsworth Cannon Jr. and this reader liked his verses, if that's any satisfaction to him or his publishers.

An investing client of Louis M. Rogovin, broker, has purchased the recently completed six-story apartment house at 645 East Twentysixth Street, running through to Amersfort Place, in the Brooklyn College section of Brooklyn.

More than 100 members of the junior class and their escorts attended the annual junior promenade of Barnard College, which was held last night in the WaldorfAstoria. Guests were received in the Basildon Room and dancing tools place in the Jade Room. Supper was served at midnight in the Astor Gallery, where several students sang popular songs from the forthcoming junior show.

Four men described as members of a ring of "card sharps" reported to have fleeced a group of Eastern business men of $250,000 in the last few years were convicted yesterday by a jury in Kings County Court of second-degree grand larceny for the swindling of the owner of the Edelbrau brewery in Brooklyn.

The 15 per cent agency discount system was considered unsatisfactory by 72 per cent of a group of advertisers, media executives and research organizations polled by Cowan Dengler, Inc., the agency announced yesterday. The system was called satisfactory by 22 per cent, while 6 per cent had no fixed opinion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Department store sales during the week ended Feb. 10 were at the same level as for the corresponding week last year, while for the four-week period ended Feb. 10 sales were 4 per cent greater than for the similar period of 1939, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales for the week ended Feb. 3 were 9 per cent higher.

Harry Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, perennial national champion, and Thomas D. Flynn of Bayside, who has moved brilliantly through the tournament to date, will fight it out Monday in the final round of the invitation, squash tennis tournament of the Whitehall Club.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (AP)--Germany is supplanting Britain and France in Russia's trade relations since Soviet trade with the Allies has been "reduced practically to nothing," the government newspaper Izvestia said today.

Advances on many fronts toward greater uniformity of motor vehicle regulation and the promotion of highway safety were disclosed yesterday at the fifth regional conference of nine Eastern States, called by the New York joint legislative committee on interstate cooperation and the counsel of State Governments at the Hotel Roosevelt.
"He wasn't any champion," the man explained, "just a run-of-themill foxhound. But he was my dog. The only dog I had. Why should that man deliberately kill him?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 27 was 3,376,540 shares, compared with 3,662,140 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

A banking group headed by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago and including Alex Brown Sons, Braun, Bosworth Co. and Campbell, Phelps Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $800,000 of water and sewer bonds of the Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., on a bid of 100.42 for a fixed interest rate of 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The attempt of the Bear, flagship of the United States Antarctic Expedition, to penetrate far into the heart of the Antarctic ice pack hae failed temporarily, because of heavy ice and other unfavorable conditions. A message from the expedition to the Navy Department read:

BERGEN, Norway, Feb. 16--The British destroyer Intrepid today seized the German steamer Altmark inside Norwegian territorial waters near here, placed a prize crew aboard and was heading for the open sea when Norwegian warships intervened.

A spectacular rise of more than 4 cents a bushel in prices of wheat overshadowed yesterday another dull and irregular stock market. Not unlike some of the hectic trading sessions that were witnessed often years ago when bulls and bears in the grain pit battled for the upper hand was the scene that took place yesterday in the final ten minutes of activity.

LONDON, Feb. 16--Britain and France are reopening their markets to a large range of imports from each other under a commercial agreement announced tonight. The compact will come into force March 3 and will considerably relax prohibitive measures imposed by both countries at the outbreak of the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Without a record vote, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a Naval Appropriation Bill carrying a record peace-time total of $965,772,878. For the second year in succession funds for improvement of the harbors at Guam were eliminated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Sharp advances of recorded United States shipments since the war started to five neutral countries adjacent to or near Germany have given rise to some suspicion here that sizable leaks exist in the British blockade system.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. LANG, Feb. 16 (AP) (Via wireless)--Presi dent Roosevelt today approved a series of emergency projects to meet blizzard and storm damages in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16--Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of Boston University, and Mrs. Marsh, who are at Whitehall, were honor guests today at a luncheon given by Ernest G. Howes in the Gray Room of the Everglades Club.

Thomas Jefferson's five clinched the Section 1 Brooklyn P.S.A.L. championship yesterday by routing Boys High, 56 to 24, on the latter's floor. It marked the tenth success in the league and also the fourteenth victory in as many starts this season for the Orange and Blue tossers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16--The strongest field to be named for any race this year was listed today for tomorrow's $10,000 added McLennan Memorial Handicap, which will give a line on what horses may do in the $50,000 Widener on the final day at Hialeah Park. Headed by The Chief, Easy Mon and Sir Damion, nineteen names were put in the entry box for the mile-andan-eighth test.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 16 (AP)--Governor Lehman lauded before a farm and home audience here today the cooperation between people and government in solving New York's rural problems as "a highly important example to the nation in a period when democratic action is being challenged all over the world."

Winter is not congenial to sidewalk superintending, but members of the fraternity haven't been able to resist looking in on the problem of snow clearance. This week they have seen nearly 30,000 men at work on the main traffic arteries.

The city's purchase of the privately operated rapid transit lines here in the largest railroad merger, from the standpoint of finances and passengers carried, in the nation's history, became a virtual certainty yesterday.
The 1939 annual report of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries, released yesterday by N.R. Powley, president, shows a consolidated net profit for the year of $19,131,610.

A canvass of the few remaining private banking firms that will be left in Wall Street after J.P. Morgan Co. incorporate under the State banking laws on April 1 revealed yesterday that these partnerships have no present plans for incorporating. In one or two instances, spokesmen indicated that they were quite satisfied to maintain their present status.

BERLIN, Feb. 16--Wooden shoes may become the rage in Germany. At any rate, in Sprottau, in Silesia, some 10,000 pairs are in process of manufacture. They are modeled on Netherland wooden shoes and are designed chiefly for workers and school children.

The appearance of $98,500,000 Triborough Bridge Authority bonds swelled the total of new bonds offered to the public this week to $126,532,930, the largest for a like period in six months, or since the weelt ended Aug. 11, last year, when $165,240,000 in new issues was placed on the market. Bond financing last week amounted to $34,073,000, and during this week last year was $20,906,000.

PANAMA, Feb. 16 (AP)--Foreign Minister Narciso Garay said tonight he had sent to the other American republics a request from Brazil for consultation on a possible collective protest to Britain "against a new violation" of the Pan-American neutrality belt.

Discovery of evidence of a cosmic cataclysm in which two island universes, each composed of billions of stars, crashed into each other hundreds of millions of years ago, was reported here yesterday by Professor Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard University Observatory, in a lecture at Town Hall on new explorations among the stars and galaxies.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission requiring the Eastern railroads to reduce their coach fares on March 24 to a flat two cents a mile brings this class of rate back practically to the levels prevailing twenty-five years ago. CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 16-- Along with balmier weather and sunshine, nine more Dodgers, including those two enthusiastic golfers, Wesley Ferrell and Roy Cullenbine, popped into uniforms today for the second day's workout. They were just in time for the backbending and muscle-stretching exercises that delight Trainer Artie McGovern.

Most of yesterday's trading on the New York Cotton Exchange took place in the last hour, when a sharp rise in the wheat market stimulated buying operations and brought gains of 2 to 8 points. March contracts ended 34 points above middling quotations at the Southern markets, where transactions aggregated 14,000 bales, against 5,000 a year ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 16 --An offering of bonds to raise funds to revive the New York, Westchester Boston Railway as a public enterprise would not be feasible unless the project were subsidized by the communities benefiting from it, bonds experts reported today to the Westchester Mayors Committee that is trying to reopen the line through the creation of a Public Authority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The German war aims were outlined tonight as a re-establishment of the Holy Roman Empire by Dr. Edmund A. Walsh, regent of the Foreign Service School of Georgetown University, before a capacity audience in Memorial Continental Hall in the first lecture of his annual series.

Attended by a bridal party of twenty-two, Miss Nancy Campbell Blagden and John Nelson Borland Pell were married yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed in an allwhite floral setting by the rector, tho Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

Gilbert Miller has selected March 26 for the premiere of "Ladies in Retirement," starring Flora Robson, at Henry Miller's Theatre following a two-week tour of Canada beginning March 11. Recent additions to the cast are Estelle Winwood, currently appearing in "When We Are Married," and Evelyn Ankers.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 16-- Dartmouth'a supremacy in intercollegiate skiing this season continued to be sternly challenged today as the Green forces gained a slender lead in the first half of the annual Middlebury College Carnival.

BOSTON, Feb. 16--A magnificent loan exhibition called "Art of the Middle Ages" opened with a private view this evening at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts--opened in spite of snow that still makes transportation about the city all but impossible.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 16--The 500-acre estate of the late John D. Rockefeller here has been offered as a gift to Ocean County, but the County Board of Freeholders has yet to decide whether to accept it, according to information obtained today from Freeholder Harry E. Newman.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb, 16 (AP)--Out of a maze of corrections in computing time handicaps, William Labrot's 54-foot yawl Stormy Weather emerged today as official winner of the 184-mile yacht race from Miami to Nassau for the fourth consecutive year.

LONDON, Feb. 16--A German submarine was bombed and "possibly destroyed" in the North Sea today by a Royal Air Force plane, according to an announcement tonight. The British pilot reported he made two direct hits, causing patches of oil on the sea and death gasp air bubbles.

Mrs. Mary Stevens Baird of Bernardsville, N.J., brought suit yesterday against the New York Stock Exchange for $127,758, said to represent the value of securities embezzled from her by Richard Whitney. The action was filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

Solly Seeman, former lightweight boxer, went on trial in Federal court yesterday with four other men, accused of membership in a nation-wide ring of bond thieves. It was understood that Jack Dempsey, James J. Braddock and Benny Leonard would be called to testify as character witnesses for the former fighter.

An afternoon thaw helped the weather-bound city in its struggle to clear the streets yesterday. However, the hard-pressed Sanitation Department was faced with the possibility of a new snowfall tomorrow. The official forecast was for snow or rain then in this region and Southern New England.

A net income of $5,163,023 for the year ended on Dec. 31 was reported yesterday by the Quaker Oats Company and its wholly owned domestic and Canadian subsidiaries. The net was after deductions for depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and a charge of $259,829 for adjustment to market of securities and foreign net current assets.

The Alumnae Association of the Nightingale-Bamford School gave a supper dance last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza to augment the school's pension fund, which provides retirement incomes for teachers. Many of the subscribers gave dinners before the dance.

Declaring that a letter sent to Representative John E. Rankin regarding provisions of the Widows and Orphans Pension Bill he introduced in Congress had not been answered, the Willard Straight Post of the American Legion yesterday made public the questions it asked.
Trading along the West Side yesterday was featured by sales of apartment houses.
Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the baton of Serge Koussevitzky, gave superlative performances last night in Carnegie Hall, in a program which consisted entirely of French music.

HELSINKI, Feb. 16--Finnish civilians will be able to see for themselves a fair sample of when their soldiers are doing at the front when they visit an exhibition of war booty captured from the Russians, which opened here today in the hall built for indoor events at the 1940 Olympic Games. A two-cent admission is charged for the benefit of service men's families.

LONDON, Feb. 16--The new German policy of treating neutral ships as belligerents if they call at Allied contraband control points, willingly or unwillingly, is seen here as an attempt to increase friction between Britain and neutral countries like the United States, which has protested against the forcing of merchantmen into waters forbidden to them under the Neutrality Act.

The task of transforming a part of Grand Central Palace into a replica of the great outdoors was successfully under way yesterday, and by noon today waterfalls and ponds, trees and brush, birds, fish and animals should be in their respective places for the opening of the National Sportsmen's Show.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 16--President Ismet Inonu is the answer to a persistent question. The first successor to a modern dictator, he inherits power when his country faces dangers and decisions more crucial than ever fell to Ataturk's lot.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 16-- Charles D. Noyes, president and treasurer of The Norwich Bulletin Company, publishers of morning, afternoon and Sunday newspapers in this city, died at Miami, Fla., this morning in his ninetieth year. He was stricken with pneumonia on Feb. 5.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Congress was told in effect today not to be disturbed too much about the present reverses of Finland in the face of Russian advances; that Finland will survive and pay her debts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Supply contracts having a total value of $6,744,677 were awarded during the week ended Feb. 10 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department reported today.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, yesterday sent a sharp reprimand to Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner for the Board of Education, questioning his professional ethics in making public a report on the mental condition of several teachers in the city system.
